item.title: Process
item.description:
See also: Air sacs / Transport of respiratory gases




Pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the heart to the capillaries surrounding the air sacs.


Oxygen in inhaled fresh air dissolves in the water film on the inner surface of the air sacs, and diffuses across the alveolar wall and capillary wall into the blood down a concentration gradient to combine with haemoglobin in red blood cells.
Carbon dioxide in the blood diffuses across the alveolar wall and capillary wall into the air sacs down a concentration gradient, it is then removed in exhaled air when we breathe out.


Blood is oxygenated and returns to the heart by the pulmonary veins.

Involved in gas exchange:

Oxygen: inhaled air (21%) > exhaled air (16%)
Oxygen diffuses into the blood in the air sacs and are then taken up by body cells for respiration.
Carbon dioxide: inhaled air (0.03%) < exhaled air (4%)
Carbon dioxide is produced by body cells during respiration and diffuses from blood into the air sacs for exhaling.
Warning Exhaled air does not contain more carbon dioxide than oxygen.
Other substances:

Nitrogen & noble gases: unchanged (78% + 1%)
These gases are not used or produced by body cells.
Water vapour: variable → saturated
Exhaled air is moistened by the water film in the air sacs and the mucus in the respiratory tract.
Temperature: variable → ~34°C
Exhaled air is warmed by the blood capillaries surrounding the air sacs and lining the respiratory tract.

item.title: Process
item.description:
See also: Lungs and associated structures
Ventilation refers to an active movement of air into and out of the lungs to help maintain a steep concentration gradient of gases so that gas exchange can occur efficiently. It is brought about by the movements of intercostal muscles and the diaphragm.

Tip
Changes in lung volume also changes the pressure in the lungs.
Changes in lung volume is the result of the changes in volume of the thoracic cavity.



Intercostal muscles contract, the rib cage moves upwards and outwards.
Diaphragm muscles contract, the diaphragm becomes flattened.
Volume of thoracic cavity increases, the lungs expand and lung volume increases.
Air pressure in the lungs becomes lower than atmospheric pressure, air is drawn into the lungs.



Intercostal muscles relax, the rib cage moves downwards and inwards.
Diaphragm muscles relax, the diaphragm returns to its original dome shape.
Volume of thoracic cavity decreases, the lungs deflate and lung volume decreases.
Air pressure in the lungs becomes higher than atmospheric pressure, air is forced out the lungs.

Ventilation pattern:

Changes in lung volume (inspiratory / expiratory):

item.title: Oxygen
item.description:
Transport methods
Transported in the blood and carried by Red blood cells (>98%)
Transported as dissolved oxygen in blood plasma. (<2%)


In the lungs:

Oxygen concentration in the air sacs is higher than plasma as fresh air is inhaled continuously.
Oxygen dissolves in a thin water film on the inner wall of the air sac, and diffuses across the wall of air sac into plasma as oxygen concentration is lower in blood.
Oxygen diffuses from plasma into red blood cells to combine with haemoglobin to form oxyhaemoglobin, which gives the blood its bright red colour.
Oxygenated blood is transported to tissues by the circulatory system.
In body tissues:

Oxygen content of tissue fluid is lower than that of blood, as body cells continuously take up oxygen from the blood for respiration.
Oxyhaemoglobin dissociates to become oxygen and haemoglobin, with oxygen leaving the blood and diffuses into the tissue fluid.
After releasing most of its oxygen, the blood becomes deoxygenated and is dark purplish red in colour.


Transport methods
Transported as hydrogencarbonate ions in the plasma. (~70%)
Transported by binding to haemoglobin in the red blood cells as carbaminohaemoglobin. (~23%)
Transported as dissolved carbon dioxide in blood plasma. (small amount)


In the lungs:

Carbon dioxide content in body tissues is higher than plasma, as carbon dioxide is continuously produced by cells during respiration.
Carbon dioxide enters the tissue fluid from the cells and diffuses into the plasma, which then diffuses into red blood cells, where carbon dioxide chemically react with water to form bicarbonate ions.
Carbon dioxide then diffuses from red blood cells to plasma, and are transported to air sacs of the lungs in this form.
In body tissues:

Carbon dioxide concentration in the air sacs is lower than plasma, as air in the air sacs is exhaled continuously.
Bicarbonate ions diffuses into red blood cells and undergo a chemical reaction with water to re-form carbon dioxide.
Carbon dioxide moves into plasma from red blood cells and finally diffuses into the air sacs and exhaled.

item.title: Air sacs
item.description:
See also: Gas exchange in the air sacs

Adaptations:

Air sacs are very numerous in number, providing a large surface area for diffusion of gases.
The inner surfaces of the air sacs are covered with a moist water film with watery mucus. This allows oxygen to dissolve in it and diffuse across the alveolar wall more readily.
The alveolar wall is one-cell thick and composed of only one layer of epithelial cell, providing a short distance for diffusion of gases.
Air sacs are surrounded by a dense network of blood capillaries, providing a rich blood supply to readily transport gases between the blood and the air sacs and maintain a steep concentration gradient of gases.
The alveolar wall lie close to the blood capillaries, reducing the diffusion distance for diffusion of gases between the blood and the air sacs.
Tip The outer walls of air sacs contain elastic protein fibres, which makes the air sacs elastic, allowing them to expand and shrink.
Once the intercostal and diaphragm muscles relax, the air sacs shrinks (recoils) and return to their original size. This allows exhalation to occur even without muscles contractions of the lungs or air sacs themselves.


Patients with lung inflammation may have fluid accumulated in the air sacs.

It increases the distance for diffusion of gases.
It reduces the surface area of the water film for dissolving gases.

When dusty air is breathed in, the mechanisms to filter out the dust may be overwhelmed, allowing dust to deposit on the surfaces of the air sacs.

It forms a barrier and increases the diffusion distance.
Significant portions of the inner surface of the air sacs can be blocked by dust, reducing the surface area for diffusion of gases.
Hardened layer of dust can reduce the elasticity of lungs, and reduces the volume of the lungs when it inflates.

item.title: Lungs and associated structures
item.description:
The lungs are two spongy, pinkish organs close to the heart in the thoracic cavity.

Bronchioles end in clusters of air sacs inside of the lungs.
Slight negative pressure within the thoracic cavity aids in keeping the airways of the lungs open.

See also: Mechanism of ventilation


The lungs contain no muscles, and cannot expand or contract on their own.
Breathing is brought about by the movements of intercostal muscles and the diaphragm. The diaphragm is a dome-shaped sheet of muscles below the lungs that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity.


The lungs are surrounded and protected by the rib cage.
The rib cage is formed by 12 pairs of ribs, the sternum and the vertebral column, with the intercostal muscles lying between them.
Tip The lung is an elastic structure that tends to decrease its size at all volumes. If there is a leakage of air, the lungs would collapse.


Pleural membranes:

Each lung is enclosed by two pleural membranes. The inner membrane is attached to the lungs, while the outer membrane lines the thoracic cavity.
They form a narrow space between the two membranes called the pleural cavity, which always maintain a negative pressure.
They secrete pleural fluid into the cavity to reduce friction between the lungs and the rib cage during breathing movements.

item.title: Nostrils
item.description:
Nostrils are the entry for air.

They are lined with nasal hairs, forming a physical barrier to filter out dust and other particles from air.

Nasal cavity is the space inside the nose.
Types of cells:

The wall is lined with mucus-secreting cells secreting mucus, which traps dust particles and bacteria and also moistens the incoming air to a saturated level.
The wall is also lined with ciliated epithelial cells. The cilia extending out of these cells beat in a wave-like manner. This beating action sweeps the mucus towards the pharynx (throat) where it is either swallowed or coughed out.
Adaptations of the wall:

It is well supplied with blood capillaries which helps warm the incoming air.
The cells on the wall are closely-packed, forming a physical barrier to prevent pathogens from entering body tissues.

item.title: Pharynx and larynx
item.description:
Structures:

Pharynx is a passage for both food and respiratory gases. Respiratory gases continue down the larynx, while food and drinks enter the oesophagus.
Larynx is a passage for air only. It rises during swallowing.
Epiglottis is a flap that covers the trachea (glottis) during swallowing, ensuring food does not enter the lungs and prevents choking.
Vocal cords are two thin elastic membranes within the larynx and vibrates to produce sound when air is forced through them.

item.title: Trachea, bronchi and bronchioles
item.description:
The trachea is a passage for air that runs next to the oesophagus, with C-shaped rings of cartilage in its walls to keep it open for air to pass through freely, while allowing the oesophagus next to it to expand when food passes down it.
The bronchus is supported by complete rings of cartilage.
The bronchioles does not have cartilage.
Tip If there is no cartilage to support the trachea, it would collapse due to the negative pressure created during inhalation.
Note The inner walls of trachea, bronchus and larger bronchioles are lined with ciliated epithelial cells and mucus-secreting cells.

item.title: Breathing system
item.description:
Breathing system helps maintain homeostasis by moving fresh air into the body and removing waste gases.
Overview of the breathing system:

Path taken for inhalation of gases:
nostril → nasal cavity → pharynx → larynx → trachea → bronchus → bronchiole → air sacs

item.title: Transport of food substances
item.description:
Routes for transport from small intestine:

Monosaccharides, amino acids and other water-soluble food substances are transported to the liver by blood through the hepatic portal vein.
Lipids are transported by the lymph in the lymphatic system and empties into blood vessels near the heart.
Usage of food substances:

The liver may store or process food molecules, it returns to the bloodstream through the hepatic vein when released from the liver.
All absorbed food molecules finally enter the bloodstream and are transported to different parts of the body for respiration to release energy or storage.


Regulation of blood glucose level
The liver removes excess glucose from the blood and converts it into glycogen. Glycogen can be converted back to glucose when blood glucose level falls below a normal range.
Deamination of excess amino acids
Deamination

Production of bile
Produces bile from breaking down red blood cells to help speed up the digestion of lipids.
Storage of glycogen, iron and fat-soluble vitamins
Store excess carbohydrates as glycogen as 'short-term' energy reserve.
Store iron from broken down old red blood cells and can be used to make new red blood cells.
Store fat-soluble vitamins (e.g. vitamins A and D) and carotene (can be converted to vitamin A).
Detoxification
Converts certain toxic substances (e.g. hydrogen peroxide, alcohol, drugs) in the blood into harmless substances. Wastes formed are excreted in urine or bile.

item.title: Methods of digestion
item.description:
Digestion is a process by which large food molecules are broken down into smaller, soluble molecules. It begins in the mouth cavity, and continues in the stomach and the small intestine.
Absorption occurs in the small intestine and the large intestine.


Breaking up of food into smaller pieces by physical means, without changing the chemical structure of food (and does not form new food substances). This increases the surface area of the food for the action of digestive enzymes.
Examples:

Chewing: Teeth mechanically cuts food into smaller pieces and mix food with saliva during ingestion.
Peristalsis: Waves of muscular contractions along the alimentary canal.
Churning: Rhythmic, muscular contractions of the stomach
Emulsification of lipids: By bile salts in the small intestine

Breakdown of large, complex food molecules into small, simple molecules through chemical reactions (e.g. hydrolysis). Reactions are catalysed by digestive enzymes.

Mouth cavity and oesophagus
Stomach
Small intestines
Large intestines

item.title: Human digestive system
item.description:
See also: Human nutrition

The alimentary canal is the pathway by which the food we eat passes from mouth to anus for further process of digestion. It starts at the mouth and ends at the anus, receiving digestive juices secreted by salivary glands, gastric glands, the liver, the pancreas and intestinal glands.
Path taken for digestion of food:
mouth cavity → oesophagus → stomach → duodenum → ileum → caecum → colon → rectum → anus



Ingestion
Digestion & absorption
Assimilation

item.title: Ingestion
item.description: Ingestion is the process by which food is taken in through the mouth. Food is chewed into pieces by teeth in the mouth cavity by mastication.

item.title: Egestion
item.description:
Undigested materials from the small intestine reaches the caecum.
Colon absorbs more water, minerals and some vitamins from the remaining undigested materials.

Egestion, or defecation, occurs at the rectum and anus to expel faeces.

Rectum acts as temporary storage before it is expelled.
Contents of faeces:

Contains mainly dietary fibres, bile pigments, mucus, dead cells from linings and large numbers of bacteria.
All of the digested food and most of the water have been absorbed.
Process:

Rings of muscles called anal sphincters control the removal of faeces.
When the anal sphincters relax, muscles of the rectum contract.
Warning Egestion should not be confused with excretion. Undigested materials that are not metabolic wastes.

item.title: Saliva
item.description:
Saliva is a digestive juice produced by salivary glands in the mouth.

It mixes with food during ingestion as food is cut into smaller pieces by teeth, and they are rolled into a mass called bolus by the tongue.
Composition:

Water: Moistens and softens food (99.5% of saliva is water)
Salivary amylase: Catalyses the breakdown of starch into maltose
Mineral salts: Maintains a slightly alkaline pH (~7.5) for the optimum action of salivary amylase
Mucus: Sticks food pieces together and lubricates the food to make it easier to swallow

The bolus is swallowed through the pharynx into oesophagus by a series of actions that ensures the food enters the oesophagus but not the trachea or nasal cavity.
Series of actions:

Tongue rises to force the bolus to the back of the mouth cavity.
Soft palate is pushed upward to close the nasal cavity at the back.
Larynx moves upward and forward. Epiglottis covers the entrance to the trachea, preventing the bolus from entering the trachea.
The beginning of the swallowing process is voluntary. It becomes an automatic reflex action once the bolus reaches the back of the mouth.

Peristalsis is a physical digestion process where waves of alternative muscle contractions that push the bolus along the entire canal and helps mix food with digestive juices to speed up digestion.

Cross-section of the alimentary canal ⤴
Smooth muscles in the wall of the alimentary canal:

Outer longitudinal muscles: Run along the canal
Inner circular muscles: Run along the canal

Movement of food along the alimentary canal by peristalsis ⤴

item.title: Digestion
item.description:
The duodenum secretes intestine juice and receives bile and pancreatic juice.
Peristalsis of the small intestine helps to mix food with digestive juice and increase the chance of contact with enzymes on epithelial cells with food molecules. The result is a watery emulsion called chyle.

Contents:

Bile salts: Emulsify lipids (breaking down fat into very small oil droplets)
Increases the surface area of lipids for the action of the enzyme lipase.
Sodium hydrogencarbonate: Makes the bile alkaline
<span class="hi-green"Neutralizes the acidic chyme from the stomach.
Provides alkaline pH (7.6 ~ 8.6) for intestine enzymes.
Bile pigments: Green, break down products of haemoglobin from red blood cells
Warning
The bile contains no digestive enzymes.
Emulsification of lipids is caused by bile salts, and is a physical process.
Secretion:

After bile is produced in the liver, it is temporarily stored in the gall bladder.
When fatty food is present in the duodenum, the gall bladder contracts to release a large quantity of it into the duodenum.
Tip When the gall bladder is removed surgically, bile flows directly into the duodenum, small amounts of bile may not be sufficient for effective digestion of lipids. This may result in malabsorption and fatty faeces (steatorrhea).

Contents:

Sodium hydrogencarbonate
Pancreatic amylase: Catalyses the breakdown of starch in chyme into maltose
Lipase: Catalyses the breakdown of lipids into fatty acids and glycogen
Proteases: Catalyses the breakdown of proteins into peptides and amino acids

Contents:

Water, mucus, sodium hydrogencarbonate
Carbohydrase: Catalyses the breakdown of disaccharides into monosaccharides
Proteases: Catalyses the breakdown of peptides into amino acids
Secretion:


Present on the cell membrane of the epithelial cells of duodenum and the first part of the ileum.
Secreted by glands in the wall of the small intestine.


The small intestine is also responsible for most of the absorption process. It absorbs the most amount of water, monosaccharides, amino acids, fatty acids and glycerol.


The small intestine is very long.
This allows sufficient time for the complete digestion and absorption of food as it passed along the small intestine.
There are many projections on intestinal wall and surface of epithelial cells.
Finger-like projections called villi are present on intestinal walls. They are formed by the higher folded inner surface of the small intestine.
Numerous projections (microvilli) also exists on the surface of epithelial cells of the villi.
They increases the surface area for absorption.


Epithelium of each villus is one-cell thick.
This shortens the distance for transport of food molecules.
Epithelium cells of each villi contains many mitochondria.
This provides energy for the active transport of certain food molecules.
Each villus has a lymph vessel called lacteal, which is surrounded by a dense network of blood capillaries.
The lacteal carries away lipids, while blood capillaries carry away sugars and amino acids.
This maintains a steep concentration gradient for rapid absorption.
Villi are in constant motion due to peristalsis of the muscular wall.
This brings the digested food molecules into close contact with villi and reduces the distance for diffusion for rapid absorption.

Into the blood:

Small, water-soluble molecules (e.g. monosaccharides, amino acids, minerals and certain vitamins) are absorbed through the epithelium of villi into blood capillaries by diffusion and active transport.
Absorption of digested food into the blood decreases the water potential of the blood., resulting in 80% of the water from chyme being absorbed in the small intestine into the blood by osmosis.
Into the lymph: Diffusion

Fatty acids and glycerol first pass into the epithelial cells of villi.
They are then recombined inside the cells to form small oil droplets, and then passed out of the cell to enter the lacteal.
Oil droplets are then carried by the lymph in the lymphatic system and eventually enter the bloodstream.

item.title: Structures
item.description:
Cardiac sphincter is a circular sphincter muscle located at the entrance of the stomach to control the entry of food and prevent food from flowing back up the oesophagus.
Pyloric sphincter is a circular sphincter muscle located at the exit of the stomach to control the exit of food to the duodenum.

Features:

It is folded and elastic. The folds can spread out to increase the volume of the stomach when it fills with food.
Secretions:

Gastric glands in the inner wall secretes gastric juice.
Secretes mucus which covers its inner surface, forming a physical barrier to prevent the acid and digestive enzymes from damaging itself.
Composition of gastric juice:

Enzyme pepsin, a type of protease that catalyses the breakdown of proteins into peptides.
Hydrochloric acid.
Provides an acidic medium (pH ~2) for proteases to work optimally.
Denatures proteins in foods by unfolding the three-dimensional shapes of protein molecules, making it easier to digest.
Kills most of the bacteria taken in with food.

Churning are rhythmic contractions of the stomach wall stimulated by the arrival of the bolus.

The bolus is churned and mixed with gastric juice.
Results in a semi-liquid paste of partially digested food called chyme.
A small amount of chyme is released into the duodenum through the pyloric sphincter at a time.

item.title: Structure
item.description:
In humans, teeth are embedded in the upper jaw and lower jaw. They are responsible for mastication during ingestion.




Non-living part that forms the majority of the crown.
Made of mostly calcium salts, the hardest substance in the human body.
Protects the teeth from wear during biting and chewing.


A thin layer that replaces the enamel at the root of the teeth.
Fixes the teeth into the jawbone through the periodontal membrane.
Allows the teeth to move slightly and acts as a shock-absorber.


A bone-like, living layer slightly harder than the cementum, but not as hard as the enamel.
Contains numerous small canals with extensions of the cells in the pulp cavity.

The structure contains:

Living cells that produce dentine.
Blood vessels to supply oxygen and nutrients to the living tissues and remove waste products (e.g. carbon dioxide).
Nerve endings for sensing (hot and cold) to achieve protection.



Location: At the front of the jaw
Features:
Chisel-shaped
With flat sharp edges
With one root
Functions: Biting and cutting food


Location: Next to the incisors
Features:
Pointed
With one root
Functions: Tearing food (especially flesh)


Location: At the sides of each jaw, behind the canine
Features:
Broad top with two cusps
With one or two roots
Functions: Crushing and grinding food


Location: At the back of each jaw, behind the premolars
Features:
Larger than premolars
Broad top with four cusps
With two or three roots
Functions: Crushing and grinding food

Dentition describes the number and arrangement of different types of teeth in a mammal. It can be expressed as a dental formula showing the types and numbers of teeth on one side of the upper and lower jaws.

Example of a dental formula of a human adult:
(or )
Calculating number of teeth The total number of teeth is calculated by multiplying the sum of the denominator and numerator by 2. → (denominator + numerator) x 2 = total number of teeth


Milk teeth: Appear between the ages of 6 months and 2.5 years.
Gradually fall out and are replaced by permanent teeth between ages 6 and 12.
Permanent teeth: Function for most of our lifetime.
Cannot be replaced by new teeth if damaged or lost.


There are no premolars in milk teeth, and less molars.

Wisdom teeth are the third molars and the last teeth to erupt, between the ages 16 and 25. Humans have four wisdom teeth (two on each side of the upper and lower jaws). They may not erupt properly and become impacted, so they are commonly surgically removed.

item.title: Balanced diet
item.description:
Balanced diet provides us with enough energy and nutrients for maintaining metabolism (including growth), muscle contractions when performing physical activities, and generating heat to keep the body temperature constant.
The food pyramid is a guide containing a variety of food substances in the right amounts and proportions to help achieve a balanced diet.



Age and growth
Children and teenagers require a higher proportion of proteins, as they are in a stage of rapid development with higher metabolic rate.
They also lose heat faster, as they have a larger surface area to volume ratio than adults.
They have higher energy requirement per unit body mass, diet should include relative large amounts of energy-rich food.
Activity levels
Individuals who perform heavy physical activities require more energy for movement as muscles are contracting more and respiring faster.
They need a diet rich in carbohydrates and proteins.
Body status
Pregnancy: Extra carbohydrates, proteins, minerals (e.g. calcium) and vitamins are needed to support the growth and development of the fetus and the larger mass of the mother.
Breastfeeding: Extra energy and calcium is needed to produce high-quality breast milk.
Higher muscle mass: Larger body size and more muscle mass results in a higher metabolic rate in males than females and requires more energy and proteins.

See also: Body mass index

Undernutrition (starvation) is when the energy intake (from food) is lower than energy expenditure (over a long period). It may occur during fasting.
Effects:

The body first mobilise glycogen in liver and skeletal muscles as energy source.
Then, subcutaneous fat is broken down, which results in severe weight loss.
Eventually, muscle proteins are broken down, which can result in damage to the heart and immune system, increasing the risk of diseases.
Carbohydrates malnutrition A low carbohydrate diet reduces the glycogen store of the body, which forces the body to increase usage of fat and proteins for metabolism, while people may feel tired easily as fat and protein breakdown is a slow process.
Protein malnutrition Kwashiorkor is a disease caused by severe protein deficiency in the diet. This is common in children under two, and they are always underweight and often have a swollen abdomen.

Overnutrition is when the energy intake (from food) is higher than energy expenditure. Common causes are when people ear too much or lack sufficient physical activity.
Effects:

Extra energy is stored as fat, resulting in weight gain and obesity.
Obesity contributes to the development of diseases such as heart disease and diabetes.

Constipation is caused by the lack of dietary fibres in the diet.
Effects:

Food lacks bulk for muscles to push it through the alimentary canal, the person develops uncomfortable or infrequent bowel movements.
The chance for developing diseases like bowel cancer are increased.

item.title: Formula
Carbohydrates (nutrition)
item.description:
Pre-context: Carbohydrates
Carbohydrates can be used by the human body as a source of energy (). When it is in excess, they are stored as glycogen or lipids in the body.
Monosaccharides are readily absorbed in the small intestines, while disaccharides and polysaccharides must be broken down into monosaccharides before absorption as they are too large to be absorbed directly.

Naming of sugars and their functions For example, consider the word fructose & maltose: The morphemes of words (suffixes. prefixes) may reveal their sources.

Food sources:

Glucose & fructose: fruit and honey
Galactose: diary products
Functions:

Glucose acts as a respiratory substrate.

Food sources:

Maltose: germinating barley
Sucrose: sugar cane, sugar beet, table sugar
Lactose: milk, dairy products

Food sources:

Starch: cereals (e.g. rice, wheat, barley and oats), maize, potatoes, taros
Functions:

Glycogen is for energy storage in animals.
Cellulose from vegetables is a source of Dietary fibres.

item.title: DCPIP solution
item.description:
DCPIP solution can be used for testing vitamin C.
Procedure:

Add the sample drop by drop to blue DCPIP solution and observe the colour changes.
Observations (positive result):

DCPIP solution appears blue originally.
DCPIP solution is decolourized by vitamin C.

item.title: Deamination
item.description:
Deamination is the breakdown of excess amino acids occurring in the liver.

Excess amino acids cannot be stored in the body. Urea is excreted by the Urinary system.

item.title: Dietary fibres
item.description:
Dietary fibres, or roughage, are indigestible parts of plants, consisting mainly of cellulose from plant cell walls. It has no energy value, but stimulates peristalsis and makes faeces pass out of the body more easily.
Vegetable, fruits and wholemeal cereals are rich in dietary fibre. Insufficient intake of dietary fibres lead to constipation.

item.title: Food requirements of humans
item.description:
Humans are heterotrophs. We obtain nutrients by feeding on organic matter, which comes from other animals.



Carbohydrates
Lipids
Proteins
Vitamins
Minerals
Dietary fibres (or roughage)
Water


Balanced diet
Human digestive system

item.title: Lipids (nutrition)
item.description:
Pre-context: Lipids
Lipids can be used by the human body as a source of energy (). It must first be broken down into smaller molecules (glycerol and fatty acids) by enzymes to be absorbed in the digestive tract.
Warning Lipid stores energy than the same mass of proteins and carbohydrates, but this comparison may not stand at different masses.



Nature: Solid (in room conditions)
Food sources: Animal sources (e.g. butter, lard, cheese, fatty meat)


Nature: Oily (in room conditions)
Food sources: Plants and fish (e.g. corn oil, olive oil, salmon)


Subcutaneous fat act as an insulating layer to reduce heat loss when in excess.
Adipose tissues around internal organs act as a shock-absorber for protection when in excess.
As a component of cell membrane (e.g. phospholipid) and certain hormones (e.g. cholesterol)
Involved in transporting and storing fat-soluble vitamins (e.g. vitamin A, D, E)

item.title: Calcium ()
item.description:
Pre-context: Minerals

Food sources:
milk, cheese, yogurt, sardines, almonds, green vegetables
Functions:

Formation of bones and teeths
For blood clotting and muscle contraction
Deficiency symptoms / diseases:

Rickets (affects bone development in children)
Osteoporosis (weakens bones in adults)

Food souces:
liver, beef, eggs, green leafy vegetables
Functions:
For the formation of haemoglobin
Deficiency symptoms / diseases:

Anaemia (lack enough healthy red blood cells)

item.title: Proteins (nutrition)
item.description:
Pre-context: Proteins
Proteins are mainly used for growth and repair of body tissues in humans.

They are broken down into amino acids in the digestive tract for absorption.
When they are in excess, they are broken down in a process called deamination.

There are 20 types of amino acids, which are divided into two groups:

Non-essential amino acids (11/20)
Can be made using other compounds in humans
Essential amino acids (9/20)
Must be included in the diet in humans


Lean meat
Fish
Eggs, diary products
Grains (plant sources)
Nuts, peas, soya beans (plant sources)


Form enzymes, antibodies, some hormones, receptors, haemoglobin
As a source of energy when the body is short of carbohydrates and lipids (energy value: )

item.title: Vitamin A
item.description:
General roles of vitamins
Vitamin A: epithelial cells
Vitamin B: respiration
Vitamin C: connective tissues
Vitamin D: metabolism of calcium and phosphate ions
Vitamin E: free radicals
Vitamin K: blood clotting

Food sources:
liver, fish-liver oil, milk, cheese, eggs, green vegetables, carrots (carotene)
Functions:

Formation of visual purple (visual pigment) in the retina
Maintains healthy epithelial cells (for soft tissues and membranes)
Enhances immunity and reduces risk of infections
Important for growth and reproduction
Deficiency symptoms / diseases:

Night blindness
Thickening of the cornea
Dry skin
Increased risk of infections

Food sources:
cereals, soya beans
Functions:

Formation of red blood cells
Involved in respiration
Deficiency symptoms / diseases:

Fatigue
Anaemia
Beriberi

Food sources:
fruits, green vegetables
Functions:

Maintains healthy connective tissues
Helps heal wounds
Maintains healthy gums, teeth and skin
Deficiency symptoms / diseases:

Scurvy (leads to anaemia, exhaustion, spontaneous bleeding, limb pain, swelling)

Food sources:
liver, fish-liver oil, milk, cheese, egg yolk
Functions:
Helps the absorption of calcium and phosphate ions from the intestine.
↪️ For bone formation / development
Deficiency symptoms / diseases:

Rickets (affects bone development in children)
Osteoporosis (weakens bones in adults)

Food sources:
nuts, cereals
Functions:

Protects cells against damage by free radicals
Deficiency symptoms / diseases:

Anaemia due to excessive breakdown of red blood cells
Damage to nerve cells

Food sources:
green leafy vegetables
Functions:
Essential for blood clotting
Deficiency symptoms / diseases:

Bleeding in the gums
Poor blood clotting at wounds

item.title: Functions in the human body
item.description:
Pre-context: Water
Humans lose water water continuously through urination, sweating, breathing, egestion.


Act as a solvent and provides a medium for chemical reactions to take place.
As a reactant in certain metabolic reactions. (e.g. hydrolysis)
Helps transport substances around the body as a transport medium (blood).
Helps regulate body temperature (through sweating).

item.title: Composition of blood
item.description:
Blood is a lipid tissue consisting of blood cells suspended in plasma. A human adult has about five litres of blood.
Analysis of blood When blood is spun at high speed in a centrifuge, the blood cells go to the bottom part of the tube, and a pale yellow layer on top is plasma.
This process allows for separation of components in blood, allowing for further analysis.


Plasma is the liquid part of blood made up of mostly water (90%) with a variety of dissolved substances.

Plasma proteins (fibrinogen, antibodies) for blood clotting and body defence.
Inorganic ions for regulating blood pH and osmosis.
Nutrients act as energy sources or for the synthesis of other biomolecules.
Respiratory gases are transported within blood. Oxygen is used in respiration to release energy, while carbon dioxide is a waste product of respiration.
Urea is a waste product of protein Metabolism.
Hormones serve as chemical messengers that regulate metabolic processes.
Info Carbon dioxide is slightly soluble in water, it dissolves to form an acid .


Red blood cells
White blood cells
Blood platelets


Transport of substances
Oxygen (lungs → body cells) is carried by haemoglobin in red blood cells, while some are dissolved in plasma to be used in respiration.
Carbon dioxide (body cells → lungs) are mostly transported in plasma as hydrogencarbonate ions for removal in exhaled gases.
Nutrients are transported in plasma from the small intestine to the liver, and then to other parts of the body.
Urea (liver → kidneys) is the waste product formed from deamination, which is transported to the kidneys to be excreted in urine.
Hormones are secreted by endocrine glands into the bloodstream and transported in plasma to their target organs to regulate metabolic processes.
Antibodies are produced by lymphocytes and are transported in plasma for body defence.
Body defence
Blood clotting: Blood platelets play a role in blood clotting; the formation of blood clots at wounds prevents entry of pathogens and further loss of blood.
Phagocytosis: Phagocytes engulf and digest invading pathogens.
Production of antibodies: Lymphocytes produce antibodies which destroy pathogens or neutralize the toxins produced by pathogens.
Distribution of heat
Blood absorbs heat from metabolically active organs (e.g. liver and muscles), and distributes it throughout the body, which helps maintain a constant body temperature.

item.title: Blood platelets
item.description:
Structural features:

Very small cell fragments of irregular shape
Colourless
Have no nucleus
Size: 2 ~ 3 μm in diameter
Site of production: Bone marrow
No of cells per mm3: 150,000 - 500,000
Life span: A few days
Destruction: In liver and spleen
Function: Play a role in Blood clotting

item.title: Arteries
item.description:
Direction of blood flow: Away from the heart (heart → body tissues)
Blood pressure: High (pumping action of the heart)
Oxygenation of blood: Oxygenated
(except pulmonary artery and umbilical artery of an unborn baby)
Location: Most are located deep in the body
Wall: Thicker muscular wall with lots of elastic fibres
Lumen: Relatively small
Valves: Absent (except at the base of pulmonary artery and aorta)
Rate of blood flow: Faster


Arteries have very thick walls to withstand the high pressure of the blood.
The walls of the arteries contain large number of elastic fibres that stretches and recoils when the heart contracts and relaxes respectively. This helps maintain blood pressure and continuous blood flow.
The walls of arteries have a thick muscle layer, which regulate blood flow to certain organs or tissues by contracting or relaxing to change the diameter of the vessels to .




Direction of blood flow: Towards the heart
Blood pressure: Low
(blood has overcome resistance from the walls of blood vessels after travelling through many vessels over a long distance)
Oxygenation of blood: Deoxygenated
(except pulmonary vein and umbilical vein of an unborn baby)
Location: Most are located closer to the body surface (for heat dissipation)
Wall: Thinner wall with fewer elastic fibres
Lumen: Relatively large
Valves: Present
Rate of blood flow: Slower
Force to move the blood:

Contraction of skeletal muscles adjacent to the veins aids blood flow. When these skeletal muscles contract, the veins are squeezed and the blood inside is forced towards the heart.
Inhalation creates negative pressure in the thoracic cavity that facilitates the flow of blood in veins back to the heart.


Veins have a larger lumen than arteries, which reduces resistance so that blood can continue to flow in the veins at low pressure.
Valves are present to prevent the backflow of blood to ensure that blood flows in one direction only (towards the heart).




Direction of blood flow: Connect arteries and veins
Blood pressure: Falls when the blood travels from arterial end to venous end
Oxygenation of blood: Oxygenated at arterial end, deoxygenated at venous end
Location: In body tissues (for exchange of materials between blood and body cells, forms networks called capillary beds)
Wall: One-cell thick
Lumen: Very small
Valves: Absent
Rate of blood flow: Very slow


The capillaries are highly branched to reduce resistance so that blood can continue to flow in the veins at low pressure.
The capillaries are very close to tissue cells to prevent the backflow of blood, ensuring that blood flows in one direction only (towards the heart).
The capillary network has a very large cross-sectional area so that blood flows slowly, which allows more time for the exchange of materials.
The capillary wall is one-cell thick to provide a short diffusion distance for the exchange of materials.
The lumen size of capillaries is very small, which brings red blood cells in close contact with the capillary wall, which reduces the distance for oxygen to diffuse from red blood cells to the body tissues.
The capillary wall is differentially permeable, allowing small and soluble substances to be exchanged, while retaining large molecules (e.g. plasma protein) in the blood.

item.title: Double circulation
item.description:
In a double circulation system, blood flows through the heart twice. This is the most efficient way of circulation found in all mammals.

(Major blood vessels and organs)
Parts of circulation:

Pulmonary circulation: Connects the heart and the lungs
Systemic circulation: Connects the heart and all parts of the body
(except the lungs)
Advantages:

Separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood
The pulmonary circulation is separated from the systemic circulation so that only oxygenated blood is carried to the body tissues.
Blood pressures of each circulation can be kept different
(compared to single circulation)
Strong contractions of the left ventricle create high blood pressure to move blood quickly through the systemic circulation to all parts of the body.
Weaker contraction of the right ventricle protects the delicate capillaries in the lungs from damage by high pressure.

item.title: Heart
item.description:
The heart is an organ made up mainly of cardiac muscles lying in the thoracic cavity, protected by the rib cage.

It contracts and relaxes rhythmically without fatigue throughout life to pump blood around the body continuously to ensure a continuous blood flow.
It is surrounded by a tough protective sac called the pericardium.




Both atria receive blood from the veins, and have thinner walls than ventricles as they only need to pump blood into the ventricle through a small distance.

The left atrium receives deoxygenated blood from all parts of the body (except the lungs) through the superior vena cava and inferior vena cava.
The right atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs through the pulmonary veins.

Both ventricles receive blood from the atria, and have thicker and more muscular wall than atria as they need to create greater muscular contractions to produce high blood pressure for transporting blood through a long distance.

The left ventricle receives oxygenated blood from the left atrium and pumps the blood to all parts of the body (except the lungs) through the aorta.
The right ventricle receives deoxygenated blood from the right atrium and pumps the blood to the lungs through the pulmonary arteries.

The (atrial / ventricular) septum is a muscular wall that separates the right and left sides of the heart to prevent the mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.

Heart valves are present to prevent the backflow of blood and ensure blood flows through the heart in one direction only.
Bicuspid valve and tricuspid valve:
They separate atrium from ventricle, and are closed by the high pressure of blood in each ventricle when ventricles contract to prevent backflow of blood into the atria.


The bicuspid valve has two flaps, separates the left atrium and left ventricle.
The tricuspid valve has three flaps, separates the right atrium and right ventricle.
Semilunar valves:
Semilunar valves are pocket-shaped structures found at the base of the aorta and the pulmonary artery. They close to prevent backflow of blood into the ventricles.


Cardiac muscles are muscles that makes up the heart.

Located in the walls of the heart to give a driving force for maintaining blood flow.
Their cells contain many mitochondria which provide a lot of ATP for continuous contraction, and is highly resistant to fatigue.
Receives oxygen and nutrients from the coronary arteries branched off from the aorta. Carbon dioxide and other metabolic wastes are carried away through the coronary veins.

item.title: Major blood vessels and organs
item.description:
Tip
The liver is special in that it receives blood from two blood vessels: hepatic artery and hepatic portal vein.
item.guid: Biology/Anatomy/Transport of substances/Circulatory system/Major blood vessels and organs.md

item.title: Formation of tissue fluid
item.description:
Tissue fluid fills small spaces in between body cells, and maintains a relatively stable environment for the cells and serves as the medium across which exchange of materials between the blood and body cells takes place.

Process:

Tissue fluid is formed from blood in a capillary bed.
The hydrostatic pressure of the blood is higher than the tissue fluid at the arterial end of the capillary bed.
Some components of the plasma are forced out through the differentially permeable capillary walls to become tissue fluid.
Composition:

Tissue fluid contains water, mineral, glucose, amino acids, lipids and hormones.
Tissue fluid does not contain plasma proteins, red blood cells and blood platelets as they are too large to pass through the walls of capillaries.
Some types of white blood cells (e.g. phagocytes) can squeeze through the capillary walls and enter the tissue fluid to fight against invading pathogens. The tissue fluid also plays a role in humoral immunity.

Exchange of materials between the tissue fluid and body cells takes place by diffusion and only at capillary beds.
Body cells constantly take up oxygen and nutrients from the surrounding tissue fluid for respiration and metabolism, while producing carbon dioxide and other metabolic wastes.

At the venous end of the capillary bed, excessive loss of water and the presence of plasma proteins cause the blood to have low hydrostatic pressure and lower water potential than tissue fluid. Water is drawn into the capillaries by osmosis.
About 90% of the tissue fluid returns to the blood at the venous end. The remaining 10% drains into lymph capillaries, which are part of the lymphatic system.
item.guid: Biology/Anatomy/Transport of substances/Circulatory system/Material exchange between blood and body cells.md

item.title: Red blood cells
item.description:
Function: Contain haemoglobin to carry oxygen
Structural features:

Biconcave disc shape
Red in colour (due to the presence of haemoglobin)
Mature cells have no nucleus and organelles.
Size: About 8 μm in diameter and 2 μm in thickness
Site of production: Bone marrow
No. of cells per mm3: 4.2 - 6.2 million
Life span: About 120 days
Destruction:
Occurs in liver and spleen
Haemoglobin is broken down into iron (to produce new red blood cells) and bile pigment (excreted in bile)


Red blood cells are packed with haemoglobin.
Haemoglobin is an iron-containing protein that can bind with oxygen to serve as an oxygen carrier.
Red blood cells have a biconcave disc shape.
This provides a larger surface area to volume ratio to facilitate the diffusion of oxygen into and out of the cells; and shortens the diffusion distance for oxygen to reach and leave haemoglobin in the cells.
Mature red blood cells do not have a nucleus.
This enables them to hold more haemoglobin and thus carry more oxygen.


Sickle-cell anaemia
item.guid: Biology/Anatomy/Transport of substances/Circulatory system/Red blood cells.md

item.title: White blood cells
item.description:
Main article: Lymphocytes

Structural features:

Irregular shape
Colourless
Have a nucleus / lobed nucleus
Size and types:

Phagocytes: 10 ~ 20 μm in diameter
Lymphocytes: 6 ~ 10 μm in diameter
Site of production: Bone marrow
(Lymphocytes mature in the bone marrow or thymus gland)
No. of cells per mm3: 5,000 - 11,000
Life span: A few days
Destruction:

Some are killed by pathogens
Some are egested in the faeces
Function: Part of the immune system to defend the body against pathogens
item.guid: Biology/Anatomy/Transport of substances/Circulatory system/White blood cells.md

item.title: Structures
item.description:
The lymph is formed when tissue fluid flows into lymph capillaries.
Composition: (similar to tissue fluid and blood)

No red blood cells, blood platelets or plasma proteins (cannot enter tissue fluid)
Less oxygen and nutrients (as they have been absorbed by the body cells)
More carbon dioxide and wastes that have been released from the body cells
More lipids and fat-soluble vitamins that have been absorbed from the small intestine through lacteals


Lymph capillaries are tiny, blind-ended vessels found in many tissues of the body. Their walls are one-cell thick.
Tissue fluid can pass through the spaces between their cells and enter into the lymph capillaries by hydrostatic pressure.


Lymph vessels are large vessels joined by smaller lymph capillaries from different parts of the body, which then join two large veins at the base of the neck, returning lymph to the blood.
Flow of lymph in lymph vessels:

Contractions of skeletal muscles adjacent to lymph vessels
When the skeletal muscles contract, they press against lymph vessels, pushing the lymph along.
Valves are present in lymph vessels (similar to those in veins)
They prevent the backflow of lymph and ensure that the lymph flows only towards the heart.


Lymph nodes are small swellings at intervals along the lymph vessels.

They store white blood cells. When lymph flows through lymph nodes, the pathogens contained within will be destroyed by the white blood cells.
Lymph is effectively filtered by the lymph node before returning the the bloodstream. It helps in body defence.


It collects excess tissue fluid and returns the fluid to the blood.
It transports lipids and fat-soluble vitamins from the lacteals of intestinal villi to the blood.
Lymph nodes remove pathogens from the lymph, it is important for body defence.
