item.title: Plant cloning
item.description:
Cloning of organisms is the production of genetically identical individuals.

Tissue culture, or micropropagation, is a technique commonly used for plant cloning.
Process:

Tissue samples are taken from a surface sterilized parent plant.
The sample is placed in a sterilized culture medium to allow the formation of callus by mitotic cell division.
Small pieces of the callus are transferred to different sterile culture media to promote growth of shoots and roots.
The plantlets formed are planted into soil, which grows into a whole plant genetically identical to the parent plant.


Embryo spliting involves the isolation of individual cells from an embryo at an early stage and growing them independently, with each isolated cell developing into an embryo.
Eventually, the embryos are transferred into the uteri of surrogate mothers for further development.

Process:

A somatic cell (e.g. mammary gland cell) is obtained from an animal (nucleus donor).
An egg cell is obtained from another sheep (egg donor), and its nucleus is removed.
The somatic cell is fused with the egg cell (lacks a nucleus). The fused cell develops into an embryo.
The embryos are then transferred into the uteri of surrogate mother.
The surrogate mother gives birth to the cloned animal.

Cloning in general:

Desirable characteristics of the parent can be preserved, as clones are genetically identical to the parent.
Cloning is difficult or slow to breed quickly.
Endangered species and organisms with considerable economic importance can be propagated quickly.
GM plants or animals can be used to produce pharmaceutical products or other useful chemicals.
Plant cloning:

Cloned plants free of pathogens can be produced, as they are grown under sterile conditions.
Plant cloning requires relatively little space compared to growing plants in the field.
Animal cloning:

Cloned animals can serve as models for studying diseases and testing drugs.
Cloning early embryos provide stem cells for research or medical treatment.

Plant cloning:

The cost of tissue culture may be higher than conventional methods as it requires sterile conditions and is labour-intensive.
Cloned population may be less able to adapt to environmental changes due to lack of genetic variations.
Animal cloning:

Animal cloning with nuclear transfer has low success rate, but high costs.
Animal clones may age faster and have a shorter lifespan.

item.title: Gene therapy
item.description:
Gene therapy can be used to introduce genetic materials into cells to treat genetic diseases involving defective gene.

It involves the use of vectors such as inactivated viruses, which infects and transfers the normal gene into the target cell.
The normal gene is expressed and directs protein synthesis to produce the functional proteins.
Note This section focuses mainly on somatic cell gene therapy, where the genetic material of their germ cells (gametes) is not changed. The changes in gene is not inheritable.

Criteria:

Stem cells should be selected, as they are capable of producing cells continuously.
Only cells that can express the correct version of the gene to produce the correct products are selected.

Benefits:

Various genetic diseases can be treated.
Progressive diseases can be prevented.
Transformation can occur outside of patient's body, no immune response is triggered.
Only successfully transformed cells are returned to the patient's body, the results are highly effective.
Gene used comes from humans only, and does not break the normal species barrier nature has set.
The trait is not heritable and will not change the genetic composition permanently.
Does not upset the ecological balance (unlike transgenic animals).
Hazards:

It is possible to develop viral diseases, even if viral vectors are made harmless.
Viral vectors may trigger severe immune responses in some patients.
New genes may be wrongly delivered to non-target cells, or inappropriately expressed (e.g. making products in excessive amounts or at wrong times).
New genes are inserted at random locations in the genome and may affect the expression of an existing gene.
The transformed cells may die, and the body can no longer synthesize the gene products, allowing the disease to reappear.

item.title: Human Genome Project
item.description:
Human Genome Project was an international scientific research project started in 1990 by the US government to sequence the entire human genome.

A genome is the entire DNA in the somatic cells of an organism, including all of its genes.
Goals of HGP:

Determine the base sequence of human DNA (DNA sequencing).
Identify and locate all of the human genes (gene mapping).
Store this information in databases.
Improve tools for data analysis.
Transfer related technologies to the private sector.
Address the ethical, legal, and social issues that may arise.



Scientists can find out the functions of specific genes and how mutations occur.
Scientists can assess health damage and risks caused by exposure to mutagens and toxic agents.
Scientists have gained insights into the role of the non-coding regions of the genome.


Scientists can identify and locate the genes related to genetic diseases, and develop new diagnostic tests and treatments.

Main article: Evolution

Evolutionary relationships between humans and other organisms can be established by comparing the genomes.

item.title: Types of stem cells
item.description:
Stem cells are unspecialized cells. They can divide numerous times by mitotic cell division to form new stem cells or differentiate into various types of cells in the body.


Embryonic stem cells are obtained from the inner cell mass of a four to five days old embryo (before implantation in uterus) called blastocyst.
These cells have the potential to differentiate into any cell types of the body, and are described as pluripotent stem cells.
They are mainly obtained from left over embryos after IVF.

Adult stem cells are undifferentiated cells found in various tissues, such as the bone marrow, blood and skin.
↪️ Tissue-specific - Produce new cells to replace the dead or damaged cells in the tissues they are found.
These cells can only develop into a limited number of cell types, and are described as multipotent stem cells. They see limited usage.
They are isolated from various tissues in the bodies of adults and children.

Isolated stem cells can be grown in culture media and stimulated to differentiate and develop into different types of cells.

Research on cell development
Helps understanding on differentiation of cells into the wide range of specialized cells in order to find ways to cure or prevent some birth defects and cancers.
Drug testing
Helps reduce animal testing and controversies on its ethical issues.
Stem cell therapy
Stem cell therapy



Ethical issues (Bioethics)
Human embryos are destroyed when isolating embryonic stem cells.
Safety concerns
Cells in organ or tissue transplants can be recognized as foreign by recipient's immune system and rejected.
Transplanted stem cells may proliferate uncontrollably and becomes cancerous, or differentiate into undesired cells in the patient.
Difficulty of usage
Body tissues contain only a small number of adult stem cells, and they are difficult to isolate and culture.
Stem cells are difficult to grow and induce differentiation.
Advantages of using adult stem cells
Adult stem cells are derived from the patient itself, and does not harm the patient.
Transplanted will not be rejected by the patient's own immune system.

item.title: Production of human insulin
item.description:
See also: Production of pharmaceutical products > Human insulin


Recombinant plasmids are produced by inserting the human insulin gene into plasmids. (➊ ~ ➍)
Bacteria take up recombinant plasmids and undergo transformation. (➎)
Transformed bacteria are selected and cultured on a large scale in industrial fermenters (➏)
Numerous identical copies of gene of interest are produced by gene cloning. (➐)
The transformed bacteria is induced to synthesize the gene products in gene expression. (➐)

item.title: Production of pharmaceutical products
item.description:
Benefits of production with GMOs:

Higher product yield
GMOs typically have a higher growth rate, product yield from GMOs is much higher than animal sources, which takes a long time to rear.
More pure & lower risk of infection
The process of purification is much easier from GMOs than animal sources, whereas products extracted from animal sources are easily contaminated by pathogens.
Continuous production
Production occurs continuously from bacterial culture, whereas animals provide only a limited amount of products.
Less side effects
Products with amino acid sequences highly similar to human counterparts can be produced, so it would not be rejected by the body as immune responses would not be triggered that degrade its functions.
↪️ Overall effect: Lower cost of production
Example: HKDSE 2013 Paper 2 Q4(a)


Refer to this section for production process.
Background:

Diabetic (type I) patients were treated with insulin extracted from animals (e.g. pigs, cattle).
Problems:

Easily contaminated by pathogens (e.g. bacteria, viruses)
Has an amino acid sequence slightly different from human insulin, may trigger immune response and cause side effects.
Solution: Recombinant human insulin

Produced by genetically modified bacteria.
Has the same amino acid sequences as natural human insulin.
Does not trigger immune responses in the human body and has fewer side effects.

Background:

Caused by pituitary gland disorders, people affected has slow growth rate, with shorter height than other individuals.
Treated by injections of growth hormone extracted from dead bodies.
Problems:

Supply for extracted HGH is limited.
Extracts might have been contaminated with pathogens.
Solution: Recombinant HGH

Produced by genetically modified bacteria.
Produced in larger quantities and in a purer form.

Pre-context: Vaccination
Problems:

Vaccines for viruses may become pathogenic again.
Solution #1: Recombinant protein vaccines

Produced by GM microorganisms.
Free of whole pathogens and safer.
Can be produced in large quantities.
Solution #2: Transgenic plants

Antigens are produced in the edible parts of the plants, which will be absorbed into the blood through the alimentary canal.
Antigens will stimulate the body to produce a primary response to produce memory cells.

Monoclonal antibodies are produced by isolated and cloned B cells. They are highly specific, sensitive and effective.



The desired protein molecules will bind to the antibodies on the beads, while other molecules will flow through.


A pregnancy test strip contains monoclonal antibodies specific for HCG.
When the test strip is dipped into a urine sample of a pregnant women, the HCG present binds to the monoclonal antibodies, resulting in a colour change of the strip that indicates pregnancy.


Rapid antigen test: Monoclonal antibodies can recognize and specifically bind to antigens on pathogens or cancer cells for diagnostic tests.
Treatment of cancer: Monoclonal antibodies recognize and attach to cancer cells, 'making' them for the immune system to destroy them.


Plasmids extracted from bacteria are usually used as vectors for transferring a gene of interest into host cells.
Advantages:

Plasmids are small in size. They are readily taken up by bacteria cells and transferred naturally between bacteria.
Plasmids can serve as marker to allow the selection of transformed bacteria, as they usually carry antibiotic resistance genes.
Plasmids replicate independently of the bacterial chromosome, and multiple copies of the gene of interest can exist in a single bacterial cell.

Bacteria are commonly used as host cells in Recombinant DNA technology.
Advantages:

Bacteria are easy to manipulate.
They are well studied and can easily be genetically modified.
They are easier to transfer target genes to bacteria.
Bacteria have a high growth rate.
Bacteria have high reproduction rate, and many have a short generation time.
Large quantities of products can be produced within a short period of time.
Bacteria are easy to culture.
They can be grown in a small space under ideal conditions.
They can produce desirable products continuously by adding culture medium and removing waste products from a fermenter.
It is easy to extract and purify products.
Products often contain fewer impurities than products from other sources.
The cost of purification of products from a bacterial culture is lower than from animal sources.

item.title: Potential uses in medicine
item.description:
Stem cell therapy involves the use of transplantation of selected and cultured stem cells into patients to replace existing abnormal cells.
Stem cells could be obtained from the bone marrow, blood or cord blood (blood that remains in the placenta and umbilical cord after childbirth).


Treating blood diseases (e.g. cancers)
Replacing damaged skin (e.g. skin burns)
Treating broken nose with grown cartilage
Growing organs for transplants
Treating spinal cord injury by replacing or regenerating damaged nerve cells in spinal cords
Replacing insulin-producing cells in the pancreas of a diabetic (type I)
Treating brain damage, Parkinson's disease or Alzheimer's disease with stem cells induced to form brain cells

item.title: Usage in scientific research
item.description:
Transgenic organisms are genetically modified organisms used in scientific research, agriculture and the food industry.


Studying the functions of genes
Genes can be introduced or inactivated for comparing the characteristics or metabolism of transgenic and non-transgenic organisms.
Studying diseases
Transgenic organisms can be used as models to study mechanisms of diseases and test possible treatments.
Example: Oncogenes can be introduced into genomes of mice to develop cancer.
Safety testing
Transgenic organisms are made more sensitive to certain chemicals and exposed to new products (e.g. cosmetics) to evaluate the safety of the products by examining their physiological responses.

Transgenic crops are genetically modified to improve yield, shelf life and nutritional value, so as to provide more affordable food to more people.


Herbicide resistance
Farmers can use herbicide to kill weeds competing with crops (water, nutrients, sunlight, space), while not killing the crops themselves.
Pest resistance
Crops are engineered to synthesize Bt toxins (a toxic protein that kills the larvae of certain insects) in all cells to reduce the amount of chemical pesticides required.
Disease resistance
Example: Tobacco mosaic virus; causes pale mottling on leaves of infected plants
Cold, drought and salt tolerance
Crops can be grown in places with relatively cool climates, or poor soil quality (e.g. high salt concentration or waterlogging).


Enhanced nutritional value
Example: Omega-3 fatty acids; helps prevent cardiovascular diseases
Example: -carotene (Golden Rice); precursor of vitamin A
Longer shelf life
Ripening of fruits can be controlled, reducing loss of fruits and food wastage from early ripening and softening before reaching consumers.
They can be stored for a longer time under controlled conditions, and can be transported to more distant markets.



Faster growth
Example: Transgenic salmon
Increased productivity; grows twice as fast as non-transgenic ones
Lowers unit costs
Reduces overfishing of wild salmon
Tolerance to cold climate
Warm water species are genetically engineered to produce antifreeze proteins, which keep them active even in freezing environments, so they can be farmed in cold waters.
Disease resistance
Diary cows have a gene coding for an antibacterial protein inserted to kill the bacteria that cause mastitis (decreases volume and quality of milk produced).


Transgenic cows are genetically modified to produce milk that contains some proteins found in human breast milk, providing a better alternative for mothers who cannot breastfeed their babies.
Some transgenic cows are genetically produced milk with higher level of casein, which shortens the time required for coagulation of curds in cheese making.
Transgenic cows and pigs have been developed with a gene that increases the content of omega-3 fatty acids.

Transgenic pigs are made to be able to digest and absorb phosphate more efficiently to significantly reduce the phosphate content in their manure.
If their manure washed into a river, it would not contaminate the water and cause excessive growth of algae (algal bloom).

item.title: Benefits
item.description:
Providing scientists with new tools to study organisms at the molecule level. (e.g. particular gene can be knocked out to study its effect on organisms)
Speeding up research in medical science and bringing advances in medicine. (e.g. genetic diseases)
Opening up new possibilities for solving food shortages and providing ways to improve food quality. (e.g. GM crop plants)
Enabling development of new tools for cleaning up contaminated environment. (e.g. break down hydrocarbons in oil spills)


The use of antibiotic resistance genes as selection markers raises concerns in creating multi-antibiotic-resistant bacteria (‘superbugs’).
GM foods and recombinant drugs may cause allergic reactions and their long-term effects on our health are still unknown.
GMOs (leaked outside laboratories or test fields) may breed with wild types and transfer their modified genes to the offspring. GMOs may out-compete wild types and upset the ecological balance.
item.guid: Biology/Biotechnology/Techniques/Benefits and risks of genetic engineering.md

item.title: Principles
item.description:
DNA fingerprinting, also DNA profiling, is a technique used for identifying individuals using their DNA profiles.


Variable number tandem repeats (VNTRs) are located at non-coding regions of chromosomes with has large amounts of mutations.
The phenomenon of length polymorphism can be exploited as:

Each VNTR contains a variable number of short repetitive sequences of nucleotides, which varies greatly among individuals. This results in different lengths of VNTRs when cut with restriction enzymes.
Each individual receive two allele from each parent, with low chance of two persons having the same set of VNTRs (except for identical twins) due to independent assortment, crossing over or random fertilization.

Note The VNTR segments with varying lengths can be extracted with restriction enzymes.
These segments can be separated by gel electrophoresis.
The method of generating a DNA fingerprint is called restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis (RFLP analysis).

Gel electrophoresis is a method for separating DNA fragments based on their size.

Design:

Negatively charged DNA are placed at the negative end (cathode) of the gel, they will migrate towards the positive end (anode).
Smaller fragments (with shorter lengths) move (through the pores of the gel) faster and further than larger ones in a given time.
Separate bands are formed on the gel.
The DNA is stained with a dye or labeled with a radioactive marker as it is colourless.

RFLP (Restriction fragment length polymorphism) is a technique that can pinpoint the locations of genes.
Process:

Extract DNA sample (e.g. hair, blood, saliva, semen) from the individuals.
Suitability of samples
The sample needs to contain nucleated cells (e.g. hair follicle stem cells, white blood cells, cheek cells).
For semen, although one sperm cell only contains one set of chromosomes, there are many sperm cells in semen, each receiving chromosomes randomly in meiosis from diploid daughter cells. When lyzed, its lysate would contain both sets of chromosomes in diploid daughter cells.

Use restriction enzymes to cut (digest) the DNA sample into segments.
A large amount of DNA fragments is produced, some containing VNTRs.
Separate DNA fragments using gel electrophoresis.
The DNA fragments are separated according to their molecular size.
The gel is immersed in an alkaline solution so that DNA fragments are denatured and becomes single-stranded. They are transferred from the gel to a nylon membrane.
The nylon membrane is incubated with radioactive DNA probes (single-stranded DNA fragments). The DNA probes bind to complementary bases of the VNTRs.
Unbound DNA probes are washed off. An X-ray film is placed against the nylon membrane in the dark. Radioactive probes on the DNA fragments expose the film and give a pattern of dark bands, making up the DNA fingerprint.
Match the DNA fingerprint patterns between individuals.
Positive matching can be used as evidence against the suspect / proof for biological relationships as the DNA of an individual is unique.
Warning When a sample involves two alleles, the total number of bands formed may need to be multiplied by two.
Shortcomings:

Time-consuming, require several weeks to complete
Require relatively large amounts of DNA
Alternatives to RFLP analysis Short tandem repeats (STR) are shorter (in length) repetitive sequences of nucleotides. Specific loci are chosen for analysis, less time is required for analysis.


Criminal investigation
Hair, saliva, blood or semen sample in the crime scene is collected to create DNA fingerprints for matching with those of victims and suspects.
Percentage testing
Each child inherits half of the genetic material from each parent, so some bands of the DNA fingerprint of the child will resemble some bands of the mother and father respectively. Individuals can be tested for any biological relationship.
Note DNA fingerprints of a pair of identical twins show the same band patterns, so it can be used to determine whether both twins are identical or fraternal.
↪️ See also: Development of embryo and fetus > Formation of twins

Victim identification
DNA fingerprinting can be used to identify the remains of victims in natural disasters, especially when the body is badly decomposed or if only parts of the body is found. DNA samples recovered from personal items are used for comparison.
Medical diagnosis of diseases
DNA fingerprinting can be used to check whether an individual carries a mutant allele for a genetic disease in order to diagnose genetic diseases in fetuses and newborn babies.
Authentication of food products and herbal medicines
DNA fingerprinting is more accurate method of determining the authenticity (genuine vs substitutes) of an uncooked food sample, and replaces the traditional morphological comparison.
Examples: GM foods, caviar, Korean ginseng
Ecological studies and conservation
DNA fingerprint of an unknown species is compared with known species to identify it.
Genetic variations of a particular species can be monitored.
Goods can be identified to check whether they are made from body parts of protected species.
Evolutionary studies
DNA fingerprinting helps establish evolutionary relationships among different groups of organisms.

item.title: Genetically modified microorganisms
item.description:
Genetically modified organisms (GMOs) are organisms whose genetic composition have been changed using genetic engineering techniques.

Method: Recombinant DNA technology
A gene of interest is introduced to a bacterium by using plasmids or bacteriophages.


Soil bacterium Agrobacterium can be utilized to transfer a target gene into plant cells (most dicotyledonous plants) to integrate it with the plant genome, as the bacterium contains (tumour inducing) plasmid.
Limitations:

Insertion is a random process, it may affect expression of the gene in host cells.
The target gene may not be expressed in infected plant cells.
Only a small proportion of host cells can be infected.
Not all plants can be infected by the bacterium.
Info Plants do not have an adaptive immune system like animals, so the bacterium will not induce immune responses.

A gene gun can be used to transfer target genes into plant cells.
Process:

DNA fragments containing the gene of interest are coated onto the surface of gold or tungsten nano-sized beads.
It is then physically forced into the plant cells (shooting out).
Advantage:

Can deliver the gene to any cells without limitation.
Limitations:

The gene may not be expressed.
The process can cause mechanical damage to the cell.


Microinjection can be used to create genetically modified animals where all of their cells contain the gene of interest.

The gene is introduced into the zygote, the very first cell of the animal.
Process:

Egg cells from the animal are fertilized by sperms in virto.
Foreign DNA containing target gene is injected into fertilized eggs using a very fine needle-like pipette viewed with a microscope.
Fertilized eggs are allowed to grow and develop into embryos.
The embryos are implanted into the uterus of the female animal (surrogate mother).
The surrogate mother gives birth to offspring containing the target gene.
Advantage:

Precise delivery of gene to the target cell.
Limitations:

Injection can damage cells.
Only one cell is targeted per injection.

Viruses or liposomes can be used as vectors for transferring target genes into animal cells.
Details:

Genome of the virus is modified to remove disease-causing genes to insert the gene of interest.
Liposomes are small artificially prepared vesicles made of a lipid bilayer with the target gene enclosed in vesicles, which delivers the gene by fusing with the cell membrane.
Advantage:

Ensure delivery of gene to specific host cell (with specific antigens).
Limitations:

The desired gene is inserted randomly into the genome. It could be inserted (incorrectly) into the DNA sequence of another gene and affect the expression of that gene.
May induce immune response, and prevent insertion of target gene.

item.title: Components
item.description:
Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a technique for replicating specific DNA sequences outside cells.
A small amount of DNA sample (DNA template) can be amplified to many copies quickly and accurately in order to enhance detection, which can be used for further analysis (applications).


Primers are short sequences of synthetic single-stranded DNA complementary to one end of the target sequence.
Choosing appropriate primers:

Primers of suitable length (about 18 - 24 bases) should be used.
Shorter primers have fewer combinations of base sequences and less variations, there is a higher chance for it to anneal to wrong positions of the DNA strand and produce inaccurate, non-specific DNA amplification product.
Longer primers result in slower annealing rate.
The nucleotide sequence of primers should point in the direction (3' or 5') which DNA extension occurs.
Two different primers (pointing toward one another) are needed, as a DNA template consists of two strands.
Length of primers
Shorter primers are used to amplify a small, simple fragment of DNA.
Longer primers are used to amplify an eukaryotic genomic DNA sample.
Warning
Primers are DNA molecules, so it should not contain the base uracil (U).
Functions:

They bind to one end of the target sequence to mark the point where the synthesis of a new DNA strand starts.
The target sequence to be amplified is 'bracketed'.

Deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates (dNTPs) are free nucleotides and building blocks of new DNA strands.

DNA polymerase are enzymes that joins adjacent free complementary nucleotides.

The enzyme needs to be able to withstand the high temperature (heat stable) during PCR with high enzymatic activity.



Denaturation
Heat the reaction mixture (to about 95°C) to denature the DNA molecules so that the double helix unwind and separate into two single strands.
Primer annealing
Cool the reaction mixture (to between 50°C and 65°C) to allow primers with complementary bases to anneal to each end of the single-stranded DNA molecules. 5'-GATCTGACTGATGCGTATGCTAGT-3' (primer 2) ATCA GATC (primer 1) 3'-CTAGACTGACTACGCATACGATCA-5'
Extension
Complementary free nucleotides (dNTPs) join to the primer to extend the DNA molecule. Temperature is raised (to about 70°C) for DNA polymerase to catalyse the synthesis of new DNA strands. 5'-GATCTGACTGATGCGTATGCTAGT-3' ...ATACGATCA GATCTGACT... 3'-CTAGACTGACTACGCATACGATCA-5'
At the end of each cycle of PCR, the number of DNA strands is doubled.
Cycling of PCR Cycling of PCR can be performed automatically in a thermal cycler by setting programmes to alter the number of PCR cycles performed, and the temperature and duration for the different stages of a cycle. The amplified DNA fragments have to be purified before they are used for other purposes.

item.title: Principles
item.description:
Recombinant DNA technology are techniques for cutting and joining DNA fragments to create recombinant DNA. A gene of interest (gene coding for particular proteins from donor cells) can be transferred from a donor organism to a host organism.
Comparison with PCR Recombinant DNA technology involves a host cell, biological systems can be used for synthesizing protein molecules. PCR is a technique strictly for replicating specific DNA sequences outside cells, proteins are not produced.


Vectors (e.g. bacterial plasmids, viruses) are DNA molecules used for transferring into a host cell (commonly bacteria).
Characteristics of plasmids:

Circular double-stranded DNA that replicate independently (extrachromosomal) of the bacteria chromosome.
Naturally transferred between bacterial cells. (*)
Contain selective markers (e.g. antibiotic resistance genes) that may offer survival advantages to the bacteria, and can be used for screening.

Producing recombinant DNA:

Isolation of gene of interest and vectors
DNA fragments containing the gene of interest are isolated from donor cells.
Vectors (plasmids) are isolated from bacteria.
Restriction (cutting of DNA fragments and plasmids)
Restriction enzymes recognize and cut at specific base sequences (restriction sites) on a piece of DNA.
The same restriction enzyme is used to cut open the plasmids, so the same sticky ends are produced to allow them to be ligated together.
Different types of ends of a DNA fragment are produced.
Note Restriction enzymes are produced by bacteria as a defense mechanism against bacteriophages by cutting up viral DNA before it can be integrated into the bacteria chromosome and replicates.

Ligation (joining of DNA fragments and plasmids)
Gene of interest is inserted into an open plasmid, and joined together with the help of DNA ligase.
Resulting DNA molecule is called a recombinant plasmid.
Transforming bacteria:

Introduce recombinant plasmids into bacterial cells
Select the transformed bacteria by culturing the bacteria on nutrient agar containing a specific antibiotic.
Some bacteria may not become transformed when they do not take up recombinant plasmids.
The insertion of target gene into a plasmid is a random process, some plasmids (with smaller size) may re-join without taking up the target gene.
Only the transformed bacteria are resistant to the antibiotic, so they survive and reproduce to form colonies.
Production of proteins:

Induce the expression of the gene to encode the protein product.
Extract and purify the proteins produced.
↪️ Example: Production of human insulin

Medicine:

Production of pharmaceutical products
Proteins molecules are produced using genetically modified organisms, useful for patients with diseases.
Gene therapy (main article)
Transfers a normal gene into patient's abnormal cells (target cells) in order to treat genetic diseases.
Medical research
Genetically modified organisms (e.g. GM mice) are produced as models for studying human diseases.
Agriculture and food production: (Transgenic organisms)

Produces GM crops and animals with increased productivity, resistance to pests or diseases, and nutritional values.
Less time-consuming than selective breeding.
Industrial applications:

Produces GM bacteria that can produce enzymes for use in industrial processes.
Advantages in industries
Large amounts of enzymes can be made in a relatively short time because of the high growth rate of bacteria.
Enzymes with high purity can be made, saving the cost of purifying them.
Enzymes can be modified to be more effective at desired temperatures, pH or other conditions in manufacturing processes. Refer to: Production of pharmaceutical products
Bioremediation:

Produces GM bacteria to clean up oil spills, heavy metals, and radioactive wastes by converting them into non-toxic compounds.

item.title: Blunt ends
item.description:
Restriction enzymes can produce different DNA ends when they cut across DNA. They are described as "sticky" or "blunt" based on the shape of the complementary strands at the terminus.

Blunt ends are produced when restriction enzymes make a straight cut across the DNA.
Example:
5'-GATCTGACTGAT GCGTATGCTAGT-3' 3'-CTAGACTGACTA CGCATACGATCA-5'

Sticky ends (single-stranded with unpaired bases) can pair up with another sticky end with a complementary base sequence.
Example:
5'-ATCTGACT GATGCGTATGCT-3' 3'-TAGACTGACTACG CATACGA-5'

item.title: Determining factors
item.description:
Bioethics focuses on ethical issues and other concerns cased by advanced in biological sciences and medicine.

Areas of concern:

Ethical issues: Moral values, human rights, animal rights, religious beliefs
Health issues: Potential hazards to human health
Legal issues: Government's policy making, law making and enforcement
Social issues: Effects on society, equality and fairness
Economic issues: Costs of research and development, application of biotechnology
Environmental issues: Effects of biotechnology on environment, biodiversity, ecological balance
Factors for consideration:

Risks associated with the technology
Unintended consequences
Benefits of the technology
Ways to actively minimize risks
Whether the new technology should be used

See also: Genetically modified organisms
Ethical issues:

Creating GMOs may violate the laws of nature, and some religions are against GMOs as they believe humans should not play the role of God.
Some people are concerned about sources of foreign genes in GM foods.
Example: Vegetarians may not accept vegetables containing animal genes.
GM animals may suffer poor health and reduced lifespan, raising concerns about animal welfare.
Health issues:

GM foods may cause unknown long-term health effects (e.g. allergic reactions)
Antibiotic resistance genes in GM foods may transfer to bacteria in human intestines, producing antibiotic-resistant 'superbugs' and causing incurable diseases. (low chance)
Social and economic issues:

GM crops have higher yields with lower production costs than non-GM crops. This reduces the competitiveness of farmers who grow non-GM crops and affects their livelihood.
Poorer farmers may not be able to afford expensive GM seeds (due to patents) while wealthier ones can. This may widen the wealth gap between developing and developed countries.
GM crops may be genetically modified to grow for only one season and afterwards produce sterile seeds that do not germinate. Farmers would be forced to buy new seeds from the manufacturer every year, so farmers may benefit little from growing GM crops.
Environmental issues:

GMOs may out-compete wild types and replace them, leading to a decrease in biodiversity and may upset the ecological balance.
When GMOs are grown in open areas, pollen grains from the GM crops may pollinate non-GM crops, causing genetic pollution.
There is a risk of gene transfer from GM crops to weeds, resulting in 'superweeds' which may spread uncontrollably.
Toxins produced by pest-resistant crops may accumulate along the food chain and cause poisoning in consumers at higher trophic levels.
Mass farming of pest-resistant crops may speed up the evolution of pesticide resistance in insect populations.

Main article: Animal and plant cloning
Ethical issues:

Some people are against cloning as they believe humans should not play the role of God and manipulate the natural reproductive process of organisms.
Animal cloning (using nuclear transfer) has a low success rate. The clones may develop abnormally, and may cause suffering to the animal clones.
Ethical issues (humans):

Human cloning will involve selection of better fitted individuals to be cloned, and promoting elitism and discrimination against the less fit.
It is difficult to define the identity of the clone.
Human cloning may cause confusion in family structures and relationships.
Clones may be treated as inferior class of human beings, labors or commercial products to be traded, lowering the value of human lives.
Using organs from human clones for transplantation is morally unacceptable because this kills the clones who are also human beings.
Economic issues:

Cost of cloning animals is high, it should be spent on more pressing and less controversial studies.
Example: If cloning is used on endangered species due to loss of habitat, the funds should be spent on conserving habitats instead.
Environmental issues:

Extensive cloning reduces genetic variations. The population of clones may be more susceptible to diseases or changes in the environment.
Biodiversity is reduced. Genetic variations required for evolution will be reduced.

Main article: Human Genome Project
Ethical issues:

Genetic testing may cause unnecessary psychological burdens.
People may live in distress after they had been diagnosed for carrying disease-related genes.
There will be a debate on the types of diseases applicable for using genetic screening (life-threatening diseases or milder diseases).
Legal issues:

Disputes may arise about the ownership of genetic information. People are concerned about the privacy of genetic information.
Social issues:

Knowing a person’s genetic information may cause discrimination and social inequality (e.g. unequal opportunities for education and jobs).

Main article: Gene therapy
Ethical issues:

Undesirable genes may not be eliminated from the gene pool by natural selection and be passed on to further generations.
Gene therapy might be misused to enhance appearance or improve athletic performance.
Gene therapy may be misused to modify gametes so that parents can choose desirable characteristics for their offspring.
Health issues:

The use of viral vectors may cause severe immune reactions in patients, as it may become regain the ability to cause diseases / pathogenic again.
The new genes may be wrongly delivered to non-target cells or inappropriately expressed. New genes inserted into the genome may affect the expression of existing genes and cause cancers.
Somatic cell gene therapy does not offer a permanent cure, the cells containing the therapeutic genes may die, or the genes may degenerate, and the diseases may reappear again as a result.
Legal issues:

Laws may be needed to prevent abuse / misuse of gene therapy.
Laws may be needed to ensure consent to gene therapy may be given only by a patient who is fully informed and capable of making decisions.
Social issues:

Cost of gene therapy is high, most people cannot afford treatment. Social inequality will become worse.
Economic issue:

Huge amount of money is spend on research.

Main article: Stem cell therapy
Ethical issues:

Obtaining stem cells from early embryos results in the destruction of the embryos. It is controversial as it may be equivalent to killing human life, raising issues about whether or not embryos have human rights, and whether the sacrifice is justified.
Health issues:

Stem cells may divide uncontrollably and become cancerous in patients.
The cells grown from embryonic stem cells may cause an immune response and rejection in patients.
Legal issues:

Laws are needed to prevent usage in unauthorized procedures (e.g. human reproductive cloning).
Some people believe that embryos should not be created for the sole purpose of medical research.
Social issues:

Social inequality will worsen if only wealthy people can afford stem cell therapy.
Some people are concerned that the misuse of stem cells may lead to trading of embryos or the tissues or organs developed from stem cells.

item.title: Sections
item.description:
Biotechnology refers to any technological applications involving organisms, biological systems or processes to produce goods or provide services.
Genetic engineering is a common technique in biotechnology, which involves the direct manipulation of genetic material in organisms.


Techniques
Recombinant DNA technology
Sticky and blunt ends
Production of human insulin
Polymerase chain reaction
DNA fingerprinting
Genetically modified organisms
Animal and plant cloning
Benefits and risks
Applications
Production of pharmaceutical products
Gene therapy
Stem cell therapy
Nature of stem cells
Transgenic organisms
Human Genome Project

item.title: Groups of elements
item.description:
Major elements (macronutrients): Used to make organic compounds

Nitrogen (), Phosphorus (), Sulphur ()
Magnesium (), Potassium (), Calcium ()
Trace elements (micronutrients): Used for regulating metabolism

Iron (), Zinc (), Copper (), Manganese ()



Absorbed ions: Nitrate () / Ammonium ()
Main functions: Synthesis of amino acids, nucleic acids, chlorophyll
Deficiency diseases:
Poor growth
Chlorosis (Yellow leaves)


Absorbed ions: Phosphate ()
Main functions: Component of nucleic acids, ATP, cell membranes
Deficiency diseases:
Poor growth of roots
Purple patches on leaves

Deficiency diseases:

Deficiency diseases:

Curled leaves with brown edges

item.title: Nutrition in plants
item.description:
Plants are autotrophs. They make their own food from simple inorganic substances by photosynthesis. Oxygen is released as a by-product in the process.

Plants require some minerals are needed for metabolism in plants.
Tip Plants are a primary food source and act as producers in ecosystems. Other organisms depend either directly or indirectly upon plants for food.

item.title: Effects of light intensity on gas exchange
item.description:
During photosynthesis, the size of stomata becomes larger, more carbon dioxide can be absorbed and more oxygen can be released. On the contrary, stomata close in darkness.
Stages:

A: Low light intensity; photosynthesis < respiration
Net uptake of oxygen and net release of carbon dioxide.
Only respiration is carried out in darkness.
B: At compensation point; photosynthesis = respiration
No net exchange of gases.
C: High light intensity; photosynthesis > respiration
Net uptake of carbon dioxide and net release of oxygen.
D: Maximum photosynthesis; photosynthesis > respiration
Factors other than light intensity (e.g. concentration) is in short supply and limits the rate of photosynthesis.
item.guid: Biology/Botany/Processes/Gas exchange/Effects of light intensity on gas exchange.md

item.title: In leaves
item.description:
Gas exchange in plants rely on passive ventilation (diffusion only).



Gases in the surroundings diffuse down their concentration gradients into the air spaces through the stomata.
Gases first dissolve in the water film on the surface of spongy mesophyll cells and then diffuse into the cells.
Gases diffuse into the neighbouring cells.


Gases diffuse from cell to cell down their concentration gradients toward the air spaces.
Gases diffuse from water film on the surface of spongy mesophyll cells into the air spaces.
Gases diffuse out of the leaf through the stomata.



Due to the absence of cuticle, gas exchange occurs all over the root surface.
Root hairs provide a large surface area for diffusion of gases.
Oxygen in soil air diffuses into the root hairs and epidermal cells.
Carbon dioxide produced by respiration diffuses out of the cells into soil air.

item.title: Bubble potometer
item.description:
Aim: To measure the rate of transpiration
Limitations:

A potometer can only measure the rate of water uptake.
Assumptions:

The rate of water uptake is the same as the rate of transpiration.
Tip Some water is retained in the shoot for photosynthesis, growth and other metabolic activities.
Precautions:

A leafy shoot should be cut under water to prevent air bubbles from entering the xylem vessels and blocking water uptake.
All connections should be smeared with vaseline to prevent leakage of water.
Calculation:

The rate of water uptake is found by calculating the rate of movement of the air bubble (unit: ), which is an indirect measurement of the rate of transpiration.

item.title: Turgidity
item.description:
Turgidity is a means of support for herbaceous stems and non-woody parts of plants (e.g. leaves). They rely mainly on the turgidity of thin-walled cells (e.g. pith, cortex) for support.
Sufficient water supply:

Thin-walled cells gain water from xylem vessels by osmosis and becomes turgid.
The stem stands upright.
Insufficient water supply: (during hot & dry days)

Transpiration rate becomes higher than water absorption rate.
Thin-walled cells lose water and becomes flaccid.
The stem is no longer supported, and bends.
The plant wilts.

Rigidity is a means of mechanical support in woody plants. They rely mainly on the rigidity of thick-walled cells of xylem vessels.
Properties of xylem vessels for support:

Cell walls of xylem vessels are thick and lignified, making them hard and rigid.
Supports plants even without sufficient water supply, as they consists of dead cells.
Wood Wood contributes to the strength of woody stems. It is formed when older xylem vessels are pushed towards the centre during growth, and develops into wood as they are further hardened with lignin, forming annual rings.

item.title: Transpiration
item.description:
Transpiration is the process where a plant loses water in the form of water vapour by evaporation.
Most plants absorb water from soil continuously. Most of the water absorbed by a plant is lost through transpiration, only a very small amount is used by the plants in photosynthesis and other cellular activities.
Loss of water:

Most of the water is lost through the stomata.
Small portions of water are lost through the cuticle present on surfaces of leaves and herbaceous stems, and lenticels of woody stems.




Setting up transpiration pull
Transpiration pull is the main force which transports water and dissolved minerals up the xylem vessels from the roots to the leaves.
Absorption of water and dissolved minerals
Water is lost in order to absorb water by transpiration pull, a form of 'necessary evil'.
Prevents over-heating in hot weather
Water takes away heat from the plant surfaces when it evaporates, reducing the temperature of the plant.


Bubble potometer
Weight potometer



Effects: Rate of transpiration decreases with increasing relative humidity.
(higher concentration of water vapour in atmosphere)
Explanation:

A higher relative humidity decreases the concentration gradient of water vapour between air spaces in leaves and surrounding air.
Water vapour diffuses out of the air spaces more slowly.


Effects: Rate of transpiration increases with increasing relative humidity.
Explanation:

A higher temperature increases the rate of water evaporation from surfaces of mesophyll cells.
Air can hold more water vapour at higher temperature (relative humidity of surrounding air is lowered), so concentration gradient of water vapour between air spaces and atmosphere is increased.


In still air: Lower transpiration rate

Water vapour accumulates around the stomata after diffusing out of the leaves.
Concentration gradient of water vapour between air spaces and atmosphere is reduced, water vapour diffuses out of the leaves more slowly.
In windy conditions: Higher transpiration rate

Air current carries water vapour away from the leaf surfaces.
Concentration gradient of water vapour between air spaces and atmosphere is increased, water vapour diffuses out of the leaves more quickly.


Effects: Rate of transpiration increases with light intensity.
Explanation:

As light intensity increases, the stomata opens wider, more water vapour in the air spaces diffuses out of the leaves.
Leaf temperature increases at higher light intensities, as light intensity is usually correlated with illumination by sunlight.


Adequate soil water allow plants to transpire at higher rates as the soil can provide enough water to replenish the loss.
Dry soil will make the plant undergo water stress, as water loss is not replenished, the stomata closes, decreasing the rate of transpiration.


Density and distribution of stomata on leaves
In terrestrial dicotyledonous plants, there are fewer stomata on the upper epidermis of the leaves. This reduces water loss when the leaves are directly exposed to sunlight.
Leaf area
The greater the total area of a plant, the more cuticle and stomata will be present, the greater is the rate of transpiration.

See also: Leaves

Waxy cuticle covers the epidermis
The epidermis is covered by a layer of waxy cuticle that is impermeable to water, reducing evaporation of water from the inner tissues of the leaves.
Guard cells control the size of the stomata
When light is not available for photosynthesis or the plant becomes dehydrated, the stomata close and water loss from the leaves is reduced.
Distribution of stomata
The upper epidermis usually has fewer stomata than the lower epidermis to reduce the transpiration rate of the leaves, as the upper surfaces of leaves are directly lit by sunlight and its temperature will be higher.


Transport of substances
Support in plants

item.title: Xylem
item.description:
The xylem transports water and minerals by transpiration pull (physical process).
Structural features:

Long and hollow
Formed by thick and lignified cells
Vessel cells are dead and elongated with no cell content (organelles)
Has no end walls between adjacent cells
Adaptations of xylem
The xylem vessels form a hollow tube with little resistance.
Thick and lignified vessels provide mechanical support to keep the vessels open, even with negative pressure created during transpiration pull.

The phloem transports organic nutrients (e.g. sucrose and amino acids) within the plant.
Structural features & adaptations:

Sieve tubes have cytoplasm but no nucleus. This allows organic nutrients to flow with little resistance.
Sieve plates have many small pores. This allows organic nutrients to move from cell to cell.
Companion cells have cytoplasm, a nucleus, and large numbers of mitochondria to provide energy for metabolic activities (active transport of organic nutrients) of the sieve tube.


In leaves: xylem is above phloem

In stems: xylem (inner), phloem (outer)

In roots: xylem (star), phloem (‘planets’)



Transpiration lowers the water potential of mesophyll cells. Water moves from xylem vessels into the mesophyll cells by osmosis.
Loss of water from xylem vessels of leaves creates transpiration pull to draw water up the xylem vessels from roots to leaves.
Transpiration pull draws water from xylem vessels of roots, creating a water potential gradient from xylem vessels to the root epidermis.
Water potential of root hair cells becomes lower than soil water. Water moves into root hair cells by osmosis.


Takes place through the phloem.
Carbohydrates synthesized in the leaves are first converted into sucrose, which is then transported from leaves to other parts of the plant for use or storage.
Usage of organic nutrients:

Growing regions (e.g. buds and root tips)
Storage tissues (e.g. in the fruits and roots)

TODO: This part is currently in consideration for addition for the following reason:
The experiment could be used to demonstrate the position of the vascular tissues.


Nutrition in plants
Support in plants

item.title: Weight potometer
item.description:
Aim: To measure the amount of water absorbed and lost
Limitations:

A potometer can only measure the rate of water uptake.
Assumptions:

Any loss of mass is due to transpiration.
Precautions:

A leafy shoot should be cut under water to prevent air bubbles from entering the xylem vessels and blocking water uptake.
All connections should be smeared with vaseline to prevent leakage of water.
An oil layer is added to prevent the evaporation of water, which can cause overestimation of water loss.
Calculation:

Volume of water absorbed is equal to the drop in water level in the burette, while the volume of water loss by transpiration is the decrease in the weight of the whole set-up.
The amount of water absorbed is slightly greater than the amount of water lost by the leafy shoot. This indicates that some water is retained in the shoot for photosynthesis, growth and other metabolic activities.

item.title: Structure & adaptations
item.description:
See also: Gas exchange in plants / Photosynthesis


Broad: Provide a large surface area for gas exchange, and absorbing light for photosynthesis.
Flat and thin: Shorten the diffusion distance for gases to reach the mesophyll cells (between internal and external environment), as well as allowing light to reach photosynthetic cells easily.


Closely-packed cells: Protect the inner tissues of the leaf from mechanical damage and infections.
Covered by a thin waxy cuticle: Impermeable to water and reduces the loss of water by evaporation.
Transparent cuticle & epidermis: Most epidermal cells do not contain chloroplasts, which allows light to penetrate and reach the photosynthetic mesophyll beneath them.

Palisade mesophyll:

Tightly-packed columnar cells: Higher density of chloroplasts for carrying out photosynthesis.
Located on upper layer of leaves: Cells are under direct illumination by sunlight and helps maximize the amount of light absorbed for photosynthesis.
Spongy mesophyll:

Loosely-packed cells: Lower density of chloroplasts than palisade mesophyll.
Lots of large air spaces: Provides a large surface area and allows gases to diffuse freely inside the leaf for gas exchange to facilitate photosynthesis.
Presence of moist water film: Water film covering the surfaces of these cells allows gases to first dissolve in it and diffuse into cells readily.
Experiment on presence of air spaces When a leaf is put into a hot water bath, the air in the air spaces expands and bubbles appear on the surface of the leaf.


Stomata:

Allow gases to pass into or out of the leaf rapidly for gas exchange.
In bright sunlight, the size of the stoma will become larger, more carbon dioxide in air could diffuse through stomatal pores into the air spaces, photosynthesis occurs at a higher rate.
Lower epidermis of leaves contains more stomata than the upper epidermis. This can reduce water loss as the temperature of the upper epidermis is higher under direct sunlight.
They are also present on stems of herbaceous plants for gas exchange.
Info The difference in density of stomata can be observed by peeling off the upper and lower epidermis, and observing them under the microscope separately.
Guard cells:

Surrounds the stomata to allow regulation of the size of stomata and rate of gas exchange.
The inner wall is thicker than the outer wall. This allows the outer wall to stretch more than the inner wall for the cell to bend when it is turgid, opening the stomata for gas exchange.
Aquatic plants have no guard cells as gas exchange occurs all over the plant surfaces.

See also: Transport of substances
Vascular bundles in the midrib and veins consists of two types of vascular tissues — xylem (transports water and minerals) and phloem (transports food).

See also: Gas exchange in plants
Terrestrial plants: (e.g. moss leaf)

Has no stomata, no cuticle and their leaves are one-cell thick.
Survives only in moist and shady environments as they have large surface area to volume ratio with a higher rate of water loss.
Atmospheric gases and carbon dioxide dissolves in the water film on the leaf and then diffuses in and out through the entire surface of the leaf.
Submerged leaves of aquatic plants:

Surrounded by bodies of water, and has no stomata and cuticle on the leaf surface, as there is no danger of desiccation.
Leaf surface is permeable, so dissolved gases can diffuse directly into the leaves all over their surfaces.
Floating leaves: (e.g. water lily)

Has stomata and cuticle only on the upper epidermis.
Dissolved gases can directly diffuse into the leaves through the lower epidermis.
Woody plants:

Have stems surrounded by cork (an outer layer of protective tissues) that is impermeable to gases.
With lenticels (small openings) where cork cells are loosely packed to allow gas exchange.

item.title: Roots
item.description:
Roots anchor the plant in the soil and absorb water and minerals.

Structures:

Epidermis: Protects the inner tissues from injuries and infections.
Root cap: Protects the root tip, where its cells have to be continually replaced as they are rubbed off when the root grows through soil.
Cortex: Made up of layers of thin-walled cells to store food, and allow water and minerals to move across the root.
Vascular bundle: Consists of xylem (transports water and minerals) and phloem (transports food), located in the center of the root.
Adaptations (absorption of water & minerals):

The epidermis is not covered by cuticle, so water and minerals can enter the root easily, and allow gas exchange to occurs freely.
The epidermis consists of one layer of closely-packed thin-walled cells, while root hair cells have thin cell walls. This provides a short diffusion distance for water and minerals.
Roots are highly branched and root hairs are numerous. This increases the surface area for absorption of water and minerals.
Roots have long and fine root hairs (outgrowths). This allows the roots to reach into spaces between soil particles to absorb water and minerals more efficiently.
Root hair cells contain many mitochondria to provide energy for the absorption of minerals by active transport.
Absorption (water in roots):

Water is absorbed into the root hair cells by osmosis.
The cytoplasm and cell sap of root hair cells contain dissolved substances, the water potential of root hair cells is usually lower than that of soil water.
Water moves from the root hair cells into the neighbouring cells.
Water moves inwards from cell to cell by osmosis down a water potential gradient (water potential of root hair cells > neighbouring cells in cortex; due to water absorption) across the cortex.
Some of the water moves between the cell walls of adjacent cells without entering the cytoplasm or the vacuole of the cells.
Water is drawn up by transpiration pull created by the evaporation of water from the leaves.
Absorption (minerals in roots):

Normal conditions: Concentration of mineral ions in root hair cells is higher than surrounding soil water. Mineral ions are taken up into the root by active transport against a concentration gradient requiring energy from respiration.
Abnormal conditions: Concentration of mineral ions in root hair cells is lower than surrounding soil water. Minerals enter the root hair cells by diffusion down the concentration gradient.
