item.title: Skeletal muscles
item.description:
Skeletal muscles, also striated muscles, are made up of bundles of muscle fibres surrounded by connective tissues. Each muscle fibre is a singe, elongated muscle cell that contains a number of nuclei. They are attached to bones by tough and inelastic tendons made up of collagen fibres.
Skeletal muscles appear to have striations of light bands and dark bands when viewed with a microscope. This is why they are also called striated muscles.


Skeletal muscles are voluntary muscles because their contractions can be consciously controlled by the cerebrum.
Skeletal muscles contract quickly but also fatigue quickly.
Contractions of skeletal muscles produce heat, helping to maintain a stable body temperature.
Tip Skeletal muscles can also contract involuntarily through reflex actions.


Skeletal muscles are attached to bones by tendons, with one end that does not move, and another end that moves when the muscles contract.

Tendons are tough and inelastic. They can effectively transmit the pulling force from muscles to bones.

Skeletal muscles usually work in pairs as opposing muscles to move bones in opposite directions.
One muscle contracts to pull a bone into one position, while another muscle contracts to return the bone to its original position. Pairs of muscles working in this manner are called opposing muscles or antagonistic muscles.

A flexor bends a limb at a joint when it contracts.
An extensor straightens the same limb at a joint when it contracts.


In the above example, the biceps is a flexor, while the triceps is an extensor.
Naming of muscles:

When a flexor contracts, the opposing extensor is relaxed to allow the limb to bend.
When a extensor contracts, the opposing flexor is relaxed to allow the limb to straighten.


Neuromuscular junctions are special synapses formed between the branches of axon of a motor neurone and muscle fibres of a skeletal muscle. They are responsible for carrying nerve impulses to initiate muscle contractions.


At a neuromuscular junction, the membrane of the muscle fibre becomes highly folded to form a motor end plate. This provides a large surface area for the neurotransmitters to bind to its receptor sites.
Since motor neurones form neuromuscular junctions with a number of muscle fibres, many muscle fibres can contract at the same time, generating a great pulling force.

item.title: Protective structures
item.description:
See also: Coordination


Bones: Bony structures provides mechanical protection to the CNS.

Cranium: The brain is enclosed in the cranium of the skull.
Vertebral column: The spinal cord is enclosed in the vertebral column.
Membranes:
The meninges are protective membranes that cover the brain and the spinal cord.
Cerebrospinal fluid:

It is formed in cavities in the brain and fills the space between the inner and middle meninges, as well as the internal cavities of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord.
It acts as a shock absorber and offers mechanical support to the brain and the spinal cord, and supplies oxygen and nutrients to the neurones and removes wastes from them.



The cerebrum is the site of consciousness, controlling voluntary actions (e.g. speaking and walking) and associated with intelligence, reasoning, memory, emotions and personality.

Cerebral hemispheres:

Each hemisphere is responsible for the opposite side of the body.
The two hemispheres are connected by nerve fibres for communication.
Distribution of grey matter and white matter:

Grey matter: Thin (< 5 mm) outer layer of each hemisphere. (cerebral cortex)
It contains mainly cell bodies of neurones which appear grey.
It is also highly folded to increase surface area so that more neurones can be packed into it.
White matter: Inner layer beneath the cerebral cortex.
It appears white due to the myelin sheaths on the myelinated nerve fibres.
Functional areas:


Sensory areas
Receive and interpret nerve impulses from sensory receptors to produce sensations. (e.g. vision, hearing, taste, smell, touch, pain)
Association areas
Integrate information from different sensory areas and make decisions in relation to the stored information (i.e. memory) from the past.
Nerve impulses are generated there and sent to different motor areas to initiate responses.
Motor areas
Generate and send nerve impulses to effectors (e.g. skeletal muscles) to produce voluntary responses.

The cerebellum coordinates contractions of skeletal muscles for smooth movements and maintains body posture and balance.

As the cerebellum is responsible for precision and fine control of voluntary movements, damaging this region of the brain may result in jerky and uncoordinated movements.
Distribution of grey matter and white matter:

Grey matter: Highly folded and makes up the outer layer.
White matter: Makes up the inner layer.

The medulla oblongata controls involuntary actions not under conscious control (e.g. vital processes — heart rate, breathing), and also serves as the reflex centre coordinating many reflex actions in the head (e.g. sneezing, coughing, saliva secretion, swallowing)
Distribution of grey matter and white matter:

Grey matter: Makes upgreen the inner layer.
White matter: Makes up the relatively smooth outer layer.


The spinal cord is a long cylindrical structure running from medulla oblongata down through vertebral column. It transmits nerve impulses between the brain and other parts of the body, and serves as the reflex centre for reflex actions involving the trunk and the limbs.
Distribution of grey matter and white matter:

Grey matter: Makes up the inner H-shaped region containing cell bodies of neurones.
It has a central canal filled with cerebrospinal fluid running through the entire length of the spinal cord. It is continuous with the cavities in the brain.
White matter: Makes up the outer region which consists of nerve fibres.



Dorsal root: Contains sensory neurones whose cell bodies are located in the dorsal root ganglion, transmitting nerve impulses from receptors to the spinal cord.
Ventral root: Contains motor neurones whose cell bodies are located in the grey matter of the spinal cord, transmitting nerve impulses from the spinal cord to effectors.

item.title: Comparing reflex actions and voluntary actions
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Coordination/Nervous system/Comparing reflex actions and voluntary actions.md

item.title: Neurones
item.description:
Components:

Cell body: Contains the nucleus and a variety of organelles.
Nerve fibres: Cytoplasmic processes (extensions) extending from the cell body.
Dendons transmit nerve impulses towards the cell body.
They can form branches called dendrites to receive information from a number of neurones.
Axons transmit nerve impulses away from the cell body.


A neurone has long nerve fibres.
This is to transmit nerve impulses over a long distance.
A dendron has many branches (dendrites).
This is to receive information from other neurones so that each neurone can communicate with many others.
Most nerve fibres are surrounded by a lipid covering called the myelin sheath.
This is to protect and insulate the nerve fibres, so that the loss of nerve impulses to the surroundings can be prevented. It can also speed up the transmission of nerve impulses.
Tip Nerve fibres surrounded by the myelin sheath is referred to as myelinated.



Sensory neurones
They transmit nerve impulses from receptors to the CNS.
They have an oval-shaped cell body lying outside the CNS, with a long dendron and a short axon.
Motor neurones
They transmit nerve impulses from the CNS to effectors (e.g. muscles and glands).
They have an irregularly shaped cell body lying outside the CNS, with a number of very short dendrons and long axons.
Interneurones
They transmit nerve impulses within the CNS.
They have an irregularly shaped cell body lying inside the CNS, with short dendrons and short axons.




A nerve is made up of bundles of nerve fibres wrapped in tough connective tissue.
Some nerves consists of nerve fibres of either sensory or motor neurones only.
(e.g. optic nerve is a cranial nerve consisting of nerve fibres of sensory neurones only)
However, spinal nerves consist of nerve fibres of both sensory and motor neurones.

A synapse is the junction between two neurones. Transmission of nerve impulses from one neurone to another is done by means of neurotransmitters.


Synaptic knob: Swollen structure located at the end of an axon, with numerous mitochondria for energy production and contains synaptic vesicles to store neurotransmitters.
Synaptic cleft: Tiny gap that separates the neurones. There are also enzymes present in the synaptic cleft to break down neurotransmitters.
Note
There is no physical contact between neurones, nerve impulses cannot travel directly to the next neurone.
The enzymes in the synaptic cleft is specific in action to prevent repeated nerve impulses from being generated when the dendron is continuously stimulated.


Unidirectional transmission of nerve impulses
Description: Synapses ensure that nerve impulses are transmitted in one direction only (from axon of one neurone to dendron of the next neurone).
Explanation: Only synaptic knobs can secrete neurotransmitters and only dendrons have receptor sites for binding with neurotransmitters.
Formation of neural networks
Synapses allow one neurone to communicate with many other neurones to form neural networks. This allows complex coordination between receptors and effectors.

item.title: Reflex actions
item.description:
Reflex actions are rapid automatic responses to a stimulus, allowing the body to respond quickly and protect us from danger.
Characteristics:

Stereotyped: Same stimulus always lead to the same response.
Involuntary: They are not under the control of the cerebrum.
Inborn & No prior learning is required.

In humans, both the medulla oblongata and spinal cord serve as reflex centres.

Medulla: Sneezing, coughing, saliva secretion, swallowing, etc.
Spinal cord: Spinal reflexes, withdrawal reflex, knee jerk reflex
A reflex action involves a reflex arc, the nervous pathway along which nerve impulses travel for the reflex action to take place.
Components:

A receptor
A sensory neurone
An interneurone (may be absent)
A motor neurone
An effector


The withdrawal reflex is an automatic response to withdraw a limb from a painful stimulus, protecting us from being injured (when touching a hot or sharp object accidentally with a hand).

Note The receptor is linked to the effector by only three neurones: sensory neurone, interneurone and motor neurone. Nerve impulses can travel through the reflex arc very quickly (in < 0.1 s).

Sensation of pain
The cerebrum receives information from the sensory neurone through another interneurone not part of the reflex arc. Sensation of pain is felt after the hand has been withdrawn as the nerve impulse takes longer to travel to the cerebrum.
Overcoming reflex action
The reflex action can be overcome voluntarily via another interneurone of another nervous pathway that forms a synapse with the motor neurone, which allows the cerebrum to transmit nerve impulses from the cerebrum to initiate voluntary movement of the arm.

When the tendon just below the knee cap is tapped, a hanging leg will give a little kick automatically. This helps maintain body posture and balance during walking.

Note The receptor is linked to the effector by only two neurones: a sensory neurone and a motor neurone.

Sensation of tapping
An interneurone of another nervous pathway forms a synapse with the sensory neurone in the reflex arc, nerve impulses are transmitted to the cerebrum.

item.title: Voluntary actions
item.description:
Voluntary actions are conscious actions that are under conscious control of the cerebrum.
Characteristics:

Do not take place automatically and are not stereotyped
Can take place without stimulation of receptors, but caused by nerve impulses generated in the cerebrum



Receptors detect a stimulus and generate nerve impulses.
The nerve impulses are transmitted along the sensory neurones to the sensory areas of the cerebrum.
The association areas of the cerebrum integrate nerve impulses from different receptors or sensory areas and relate them to past experiences. When a decision is made, nerve impulses are generated and transmitted to the motor areas.
The motor areas of the cerebrum generate and send nerve impulses along motor neurones to effectors.
The effectors produce responses.

item.title: Comparing nervous coordination and hormonal coordination
Nervous system
item.description:
Nervous system is responsible for nervous coordination.
Parts of the nervous system:

Central nervous system (CNS)
Consists of the brain and spinal cord, and receives sensory signals in the form of nerve impulses from receptors in different parts of the body, then interprets the nerve impulses and initiating responses.
Peripheral nervous system (PNS)
Consists of nerves outside the CNS, and named from where they arise:
Cranial nerves: (e.g. optic nerves and auditory nerves)
Arise from the brain, linking the brain with receptors and effectors in the head and the neck.
Spinal nerves:
Arise from the spinal cord, linking the spinal cord with receptors and effectors in the rest of the body.


Neurones
Central nervous system (CNS)
Voluntary actions
Movement in humans
Reflex actions
Comparing reflex actions and voluntary actions

Endocrine system is responsible for hormonal coordination, consisting of a number of endocrine glands secreting hormones to coordinate many physiological processes in the body.

Endocrine glands



Growth hormone (GH): Stimulates growth of skeletal muscles and bones.
Anti-diuretic hormone (ADH): Regulates the water content of the blood.
Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH): Stimulates ovum development and oestrogen secretion in females.
Luteinising hormone (LH): Stimulates ovulation in females.


Thyroxin: Regulates metabolic rate.


Insulin: Lowers blood glucose
Glucagon: Raises blood glucose


Adrenaline: Prepares the body for physical activity or emergency.


Oestrogen: Stimulates the development of the female reproductive system and female secondary sexual characteristics.
Progesterone: Regulates the menstrual cycle.


Testosterone: Stimulates the development of the male reproductive system and male secondary sexual characteristics.

Hormones are chemical messengers that travel throughout the body in the bloodstream. They have the following properties:

They are very specific and will only act on target organs with cells that have specific receptor sites.
The hormone binds to the receptor sites of the target cells to produce specific responses.
Cells that lack receptor sites do not respond to the hormone.
They are effective in very low concentrations, but can have widespread and long-lasting effects.
The hormone may affect multiple organs situated far away from the gland that produce it.


Homeostasis
Hormonal control of menstrual cycle


Comparing nervous coordination and hormonal coordination

item.title: Insulin
item.description:
Blood glucose levels are regulated by a negative feedback mechanism through the actions of protein hormones insulin and glucagon, secreted by the pancreas.
The pancreas detect changes in blood glucose levels and control the secretion of these hormones. Glucose level is regulated at a set point of around of blood.

Insulin is a protein hormone that has the following functions:

Stimulates liver cells to convert more glucose to glycogen
Stimulates body cells and liver cells to take up more glucose from the blood
Increases respiration in cells to consume glucose
Inhibits the secretion of glucagon
Overall, insulin causes blood glucose level to decrease.

Glucagon is a protein hormone that stimulates liver cells to convert more glycogen to glucose.
Overall, glucagon causes blood glucose level to increase.




Diabetes mellitus – failure in blood glucose regulation

item.title: Homeostasis
item.description:
Homeostasis is a self-regulating process by which body systems in an organism maintains a stable internal environment.
Warning Homeostasis does not maintain a constant environment.
Changes in the internal environment are influenced by the external environment (e.g. air temperature) and body activities (e.g. feeding).
In humans, the internal environment refers to the immediate environment of cells (blood & tissue fluid). As cells are sensitive to changes in the environment surrounding them, homeostasis ensures that the cells may function properly.


Negative feedback mechanism
Parameters of the internal environment
Blood glucose levels and regulation

item.title: Interactions of components
item.description:
In a negative feedback mechanism, any changes in a parameter triggers a corrective response that has the opposed effect to bring the the parameter back to normal (set point).


Receptors: Detect changes in the internal environment.
Control centre: Receive information from the receptors and coordinates a response with reference to a set point. (nervous system / endocrine system)
Effectors: Produce a response to reverse any changes in the internal environment.


Blood glucose levels and regulation
Osmoregulation (ADH)
Control of heartbeat > Rate and depth of breathing
Body temperature regulation

item.title: Body temperature
item.description:
See also: Effects of temperature on enzymatic reactions / Body temperature regulation

Importance in keeping the parameter stable:

To maintain a stable optimal temperature for enzymes to work in metabolic reactions.
Effects of extreme conditions:

Enzymes become inactive at low temperatures, while they are denatured at high temperatures. Body metabolism is affected, which may lead to death.
Organ(s) involved in homeostatic control:

Skin — Helps regulate the body temperature at around 37°C

See also: Urinary system

Importance in keeping the parameter stable:

Maintains a stable water potential for blood and tissue fluid so that cells can function properly.
Effects of extreme conditions:

Differences in water potential of blood or tissue fluid surrounding the cells determines the net movement of water into and out of the cell by osmosis.
Organ(s) involved in homeostatic control:

Kidneys — Filters the blood and removes excess water and salts from the body

See also: Breathing system
Importance in keeping the parameter stable:

Ensures that a sufficient supply of oxygen for cells to carry out respiration in order to obtain energy.
Maintains a stable content of carbonic acid (carbon dioxide) in blood and tissue fluid for a stable pH.
Effects of extreme conditions:

Insufficient oxygen supply affects respiration and can damage nerve cells and the heart over time.
A build-up of carbon dioxide would lower the pH (increase the acidity) of blood and tissue fluid, affecting enzyme activity in cells.
Organ(s) involved in homeostatic control:

Lungs — Helps take in oxygen and remove carbon dioxide
Heart — Ensures adequate blood flow carrying oxygenated blood to all parts of the body
Note They receive signals from the brain to change the breathing rate and heart rate when necessary.

Main article: Blood glucose levels and regulation
Importance in keeping the parameter stable:

Ensures a sufficient supply of glucose for cells to carry out respiration in order to obtain energy.
Maintains a stable water potential of blood and tissue fluid.
Effects of extreme conditions:

Glucose is the main respiratory substrate, inadequate supply affects respiration of cells, resulting in dizziness or even death when the brain does not have enough glucose supply.
Glucose is soluble in water and affects the water potential of the blood. Differences in water potential of blood or tissue fluid surrounding the cells determine the net movement of water into and out of the cells by osmosis.
Note Starch is insoluble in water, so it does not affect the water potential of a solution.
Organ(s) involved in homeostatic control:

Pancreas
Liver

item.title: Control of breathing
item.description:
Pre-context: Breathing system
Breathing is under both voluntary and involuntary control.
Control of breathing by the nervous system:

Voluntarily controlled by the cerebrum.
Involuntarily controlled by the medulla oblongata.
Sets the basic rhythm of breathing.
Adjusts the rate and depth of breathing.
↪️ Example: during sleeping

Pre-context: Mechanism of ventilation
Ventilation rate is the volume of air breathed in and out per minute.

↪️ See also: HKDSE 2020 Paper 2 Q1(b)
Tidal volume and breathing rate
Tidal volume is the volume of air that moved through the lungs in each inhalation and exhalation during resting.
Only the cycles where there are no major fluctuations should be measured in the breathing rate.
A spirometer is used to determine the vital capacity of a person.
Calculation by graph
From the graph:
Breathing rate = = 25 breaths / min
Tidal volume =

Basic rhythm is controlled by the respiratory centre of the medulla oblongata.
Cycle of inhalation and exhalation: See diagram

Initiation of inhalation
Respiratory centre sends nerve impulses to the intercostal muscles and diaphragm muscle to stimulate them to contract, and the lung inflate and inhalation occurs.
Stimulation of stretch receptors
Stretch receptors send nerve impulses to inhibit the respiratory centre, so it stops sending nerve impulses to the respiratory muscles. The muscles would relax, and the lung to deflate and exhalation occurs.

The rate and depth of breathing is affected by the concentration of carbon dioxide in blood. Chemoreceptors detect changes in pH of the blood and send nerve impulses to the respiratory centre. It is controlled by a negative feedback mechanism.
Detection by chemoreceptors Respiration consumes and produces simultaneously, so the rate of consumption of is directly proportional to the rate of production of . Moreover, carbon dioxide can dissolve in blood and undergo the following reaction:
↪️ See also: Transport of respiratory gases > Carbon dioxide Therefore, the conc. of can be deduced from the change in pH caused by production of bicarbonate ions.
Location of chemoreceptors:


Respiratory centre in medulla oblongata
Carotid bodies in the walls of the carotid arteries in the neck
Aortic bodies in the wall of the aorta (aortic arch)
Process of regulation: See diagram

A rise / fall in blood concentration results in a fall in blood pH.
Chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies detect a fall / rise in blood pH, and send nerve impulses to the respiratory centre.
Chemoreceptors in the respiratory centre detects a fall / rise in blood pH.
The respiratory centre sends more / fewer nerve impulses (via a sympathetic nerve) to the intercostal muscles and diaphragm muscle, causing them to contract more / less frequently and forcefully.
The rate and depth of breathing increase / decrease. is removed from the body at a faster / slower rate. Blood pH level is increased / lowered to the normal level.
Note Chemoreceptors can also detect the pH level (i.e. concentration) of the cerebrospinal fluid.
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Physiology/Blood gas content regulation/Control of breathing.md

item.title: Initiation of heartbeat
item.description:
Pre-context: Heart
The heartbeat is under involuntary control.


Control of the basic heartbeat is myogenic, which means the heart will beat without any external stimulus (but it is lmitated within the muscle itself).
Components:

The heart is composed mainly of cardiac muscles. They can contract upon stimulation by electrical impulses generated by the cardiac muscles themselves.
The sinoatrial (SA) node (group of specialized cardiac muscle cells) is a "pacemaker" that provides the initial stimulus for a heartbeat.
Process:

Electrical impulse generation by SA node & Contraction of atria
Electrical impulse is generated by the SA node, which spreads rapidly through the walls of both atria, causing both atria to contract at the same time.
Electrical impulse relay at AV node
The electrical impulse pass to the AV node (a relay point) between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
AV node relays the electrical impulses along the septum to the base of the ventricles through the bundle of His (specialized muscle fibres).
The electrical impulses are delayed for ~0.1 second to allow time for the ventricles to fill with blood.
Contraction of ventricles
As the electrical impulses spread upwards through the wall of the ventricles, the ventricles contract from the bottom up to squeeze blood upwards into the aorta and pulmonary arteries.
Note The inner walls of the ventricles contain specialized conducting fibres which spread the electrical impulses.

A cardiac cycle is a sequence of events starting from one contraction of the atria to the next.
Note The human heart beats 72 times per minute on average, with each cardiac cycle lasting ~0.8 seconds.

Atrial systole (contraction of the atria)
()
SA node generates electrical impulses.
Atria contract and ventricles relax.
Blood pressure in atria becomes higher than that in the ventricles.
Bicuspid and tricuspid valves open. Blood is forced from the atria into the ventricles through bicuspid and tricuspid valves.
Ventricular systole (contraction of the ventricles)
()
AV node relays electrical impulses.
Ventricles contract and atria relax.
Blood pressure in ventricles becomes higher than that in the atria.
Bicuspid and tricuspid valves are forced to close. This prevents the backflow of blood into the atria.
Semilunar valves open. Blood is forced into the aorta and the pulmonary artery through the semilunar valves.
Note The closure of bicuspid and tricuspid valves produces the first heart sound ('lub').

Diastole (relaxation)
()
Both the ventricles and atria relax.
Blood pressure in ventricles and atria fall. The blood pressure in atria is higher than that in ventricles.
Bicuspid and tricuspid valves open. Blood from the vena cava and pulmonary vein is allowed to flow into the atria. (as the pressure in the atria is lower)
Semilunar valves close. This prevents the backflow of blood from the two blood vessels into the ventricles.
Note The closure of semilunar valves process produces the second heart sound ('dub').

Cardiac output is the total volume of blood pumped by each ventricle per minute.


Heart rate: Numbers of heartbeats per minute
Stroke volume: Volume of blood pumped by each ventricle in one heartbeat
Factors affecting stroke volume:

Venous return (volume of blood returning to the heart from the vena cava)
It limits the volume of blood available in the left ventricle.
Strength of ventricular contraction
It determines the maximum volume of blood pumped out of the heart in each heartbeat.
↪️ See also: HKDSE 2014 Paper 2 Q1(b)(ii)

Factors influencing control of cardiac output:

Blood pH (concentration of in blood)
Changes in blood (/ cerebrospinal fluid) pH are detected by chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies which send nerve impulses to the cardiovascular centre.
Blood pressure
Stretch receptors in the walls of vena cava, carotid arteries and the aorta are sensitive to stretching of blood vessels caused by increased blood flow.
Movement of limbs
This stimulates stretch receptors in muscles and tendons.
Mechanism of control:

Receptors send nerve impulses to the cardiovascular centre in the medulla oblongata.
Cardiovascular centre processes the information and send nerve impulses to SA node via a sympathetic nerve and the vagus nerve (parasympathetic nerve) to regulate cardiac output.
These nerves are antagonistic in action: sympathetic nerve stimulates the SA node, increasing cardiac output; vagus nerve inhibits SA node, decreasing cardiac output.
When resting, vagus nerve is more active than the sympathetic nerve.
During exercise or in stressful situations, sympathetic nerve will be more active.
Control by cardiovascular centre:

When more nerve impulses is sent via the sympathetic nerve to stimulate the SA node and the cardiac muscle:
The cardiac muscle contracts more frequently and forcefully.
The heart rate and stroke volume is increased.
Cardiac output is increased.
When less nerve impulses is sent via the sympathetic nerve to stimulate the SA node and the cardiac muscle:
The cardiac muscle contracts less frequently and forcefully.
The heart rate and stroke volume is decreased.
Cardiac output is decreased.
Note When more nerve impulses are sent through the vagus nerve, fewer nerve impulses (but not none) are sent through the sympathetic nerve.

During exercise or in stressful situations, the cardiovascular centre sends nerve impulses via the sympathetic nerve to the adrenal glands, causing them to secrete more adrenaline into the blood.
Action of adrenaline:

Stimulates SA node and cardiac muscles;
Causes cardiac muscles to contract more frequently and forcefully;
The heart rate and stroke volume is increased;
Cardiac output is increased.
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Physiology/Blood gas content regulation/Control of heartbeat.md

item.title: Rate and depth of breathing
item.description:
Pre-context: Control of breathing
Effects of exercise:

Skeletal muscles contract more vigorously.
Energy demand is increased.
More oxygen is needed to carry out aerobic respiration at a faster rate.
Carbon dioxide is produced at a faster rate.

Response to exercise:

Respiratory centre (in the medulla) is stimulated to send more nerve impulses through the sympathetic nerve to the respiratory muscles to increase ventilation rate.
More oxygen can be breathed in per unit time, oxygen concentration in air sacs increases. A steep concentration gradient of oxygen between the air inside the air sacs and the blood in the capillaries can be maintained so oxygen diffuses into the blood more rapidly.
Carbon dioxide can also be breathed out more quickly, thus a steep concentration gradient of carbon dioxide between the blood and air sacs is maintained for the rapid removal of carbon dioxide by diffusion.
Response to strenuous exercises:

As the intensity of physical activity increases, the energy demand of muscle cells increases greatly. The rate of Aerobic respiration is limited by the availability of oxygen and may not be fast enough to provide sufficient energy to satisfy the energy demand.
Skeletal muscles cells would also undergo Anaerobic respiration to produce extra energy to supply the immediate energy need. Lactic acid is produced as a by-product, accumulation of the acid in skeletal muscles gradually prevents the muscles from contracting normally and they begin to work inefficiently (muscle fatigue).


Ventilation rate remains high for some time after exercise ends, gas exchange occurs at a faster rate.
This provides more oxygen for the metabolism of lactic acid in the liver (to pay the oxygen debt) so that the blood pH can be increased to a normal level.
Oxygen debt Lactic acid lowers the blood pH to an extent, the chemoreceptors will be stimulated in order to increase the blood pH.

Pre-context: Control of heartbeat
Reason for increased cardiac output:

Supply oxygen and glucose to skeletal muscle cells more rapidly.
This allows the cells to carry out aerobic respiration at a faster rate release more energy for muscle contractions.
Remove carbon dioxide and lactic acid from skeletal muscle cells more rapidly.
This prevents the accumulation of carbon dioxide and lactic acid in the muscles, which lowers the pH of the blood and affects enzymatic reactions.
Remove heat from skeletal muscles and cardiac muscle.
This prevents muscles from overheating.
Actions to increase cardiac output:

Cardiovascular centre is stimulated and sends more nerve impulses to the SA node and the cardiac muscles via the sympathetic nerve.
The cardiac muscles contract more frequently and forcefully.
Adrenal glands secrete more adrenaline into the blood and increases cardiac output.
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Physiology/Blood gas content regulation/Effects of exercise.md

item.title: Importance of blood gas content regulation
item.description:
Importance of regulating gas content in blood:

Cells take up oxygen from blood continuously for Respiration to release energy.
Carbon dioxide is produced as a waste product of Respiration, and it dissolved in blood plasma to form weak acids, which lowers the pH of blood.
Enzyme activity and thus the metabolic rate is affected by change in pH.
Determination of gas content in blood:

Respiration rate — intensity of physical activity
Ventilation rate — rate and depth of breathing
Circulation of blood — rate and strength of heartbeat
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Physiology/Blood gas content regulation/Importance of blood gas content regulation.md

item.title: Body temperature regulation
item.description:
Note This article focuses on the mechanism occurring in humans only.
See also: Parameters of the internal environment
Regulation of body temperature provides an optimum temperature range for enzymes to work efficiently in metabolic reactions, maintaining a steady metabolic rate.
Thermoregulation involves balancing heat gain and heat loss.

The body gains most heat internally from metabolic reactions, especially from cellular respiration in the liver and skeletal muscles.
The body also gains heat from or loses heat to the environment by conduction, convection and radiation.
The body also loses heat by the evaporation of sweat.


Structure of skin
Mechanism of regulation

item.title: Components
item.description:
Pre-context: Homeostasis
Thermoregulation is an example of homeostasis in humans, and occurs through the negative feedback mechanism.


There are thermoreceptors in the hypothalamus and in the skin.

In the hypothalamus: Detect the temperature of the blood
In the skin: Detect the temperature of the skin

The control centre is the thermoregulatory centre in the hypothalamus of the brain.

Monitors and controls the core body temperature.
Receives nerve impulses from receptors about temperature changes.
Tip Core body temperature refers to the temperature of the brain and organs in the thorax and abdomen.
Division by functionality:

Heat gain centre: Stimulated when temperature is lower than normal and coordinates effectors to initiate responses that increase heat gain and reduce heat loss.
Heat loss centre: Stimulated when temperature is higher than normal and coordinates effectors to initiate responses that reduce heat gain and increase heat loss.


Arterioles near the skin surface (for vasoconstriction)
Sweat glands (for sweating)
Erector muscles (for reducing heat loss by contraction)
Skeletal muscles (for shivering to generate heat)
Thyroid gland (controls metabolic rate)

Initiation of response:

Body temperature becomes lower / higher than normal as it loses heat more quickly to the surroundings.
The heat gain / loss centre in the hypothalamus is stimulated to send nerve impulses to initiate responses in the skin that reduce / increase heat loss.
Responses to reduce heat loss:

Vasoconstriction of arterioles reduces blood flow to capillaries near the skin surface. More blood flows through the shunt vessel (which is deeper in the skin). Less heat is loss from the skin to surroundings by conduction, convection and radiation.
Sweat glands secrete less sweat, and heat loss by evaporation is reduced.
Erector muscles contract and hairs become erect.
In the long term, the layer of subcutaneous fat becomes thicker in cold conditions. Fat is a good insulator of heat, less heat is lost from the body by conduction and convection.
Responses to increase heat loss:

Vasodilation of arterioles increases blood flow to capillaries near the skin surface. More heat is loss from the skin to surroundings by conduction, convection and radiation.
Sweat glands secrete more sweat, heat loss by evaporation is increased.
Erector muscles relax and hairs lie flat.
In the long term, the layer of subcutaneous fat becomes thinner in hot conditions. This reduces the insulating effect.
Note
Like transpiration, wind speed and relative humidity affects the rate of evaporation of sweat.
A layer of still air is trapped close to the skin surface for mammals with thick furs. Since air is a good insulator of heat, so heat loss from the skin by conduction and convection is prevented.

Shivering is brought about by involuntary muscles contractions.

A fall in temperature stimulates the heat gain centre in the hypothalamus to send more frequent nerve impulses to skeletal muscles, causing them to contract in short bursts.
Contraction (metabolism) of skeletal muscles generates extra heat from increased cellular respiration.

Thyroxine is a hormone that increases the metabolic rate of body cells so that more heat is generated in the body. It is secreted by the thyroid gland as a long-term response to cold conditions.
//TODO import image of the gland
Secretion of thyroxine: Secreted by the pituitary gland under the control of the hypothalamus and involves a negative feedback mechanism.

A lowered body temperature is detected by thermoreceptors in the hypothalamus.
The hypothalamus signals the pituitary gland to secrete a hormome.
The hormone stimulates the thyroid gland to secrete more thyroxine.
Thyroxine increases the metabolic rate of body cells. More heat is generated.

When feeling cold:

Put on more clothes to reduce heat loss.
Consume hot food and hot drinks, or switch on a heater to increase heat gain.
Do exercise to increase heat production by Metabolism.
When feeling hot:

Wear fewer and thinner clothes to reduce insulation.
Seek shade from strong sunlight to reduce heat gain by radiation.
Switch on a fan or an air-conditioner to generate wind, so heat loss by convection and evaporation of sweat can be increased.
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Physiology/Body temperature regulation/Mechanism of body temperature regulation.md

item.title: Skin
item.description:
The skin is mainly responsible for thermoregulation in humans.
Functions:

Regulate body temperature
For body defence (acts as a physical barrier)
For sensation
For excretion (through sweating)



Innermost layer (Malpighian layer):

Contains actively dividing cells by mitotic cell division to produce new cells.
Contains cells producing the pigment (melanin) which gives the skin its colour.
Melanin absorbs ultraviolet (UV) light to protect the tissues from damage.
Produces vitamin D in sunlight.
Middle layer:

Contains living cells produced by the Malpighian layer.
Contents of its cells are gradually replaced by the fibrous protein keratin as they are pushed towards the skin surface. Their nuclei then disappears and they die.
Outermost layer (cornified layer):

Contains flattened, dead cells that are constantly shed and replaced by cells from inner layers.
Serves as a barrier preventing the invasion of pathogens and protects the body from minor mechanical injuries.
Cells are waterproof and help minimize water loss from the skin surface.


Hair follicles are sac-like structures that extend from the epidermis to the dermis.

Hair root is where a hair develops, it is at the base of the hair follicle.
An erector muscle is attached to each hair follicle.
Action of erector muscle:

Contraction of erector muscle causes the hair to become erect.
Relaxation of erector muscle causes the hair to lie flat.
Note The contraction of this muscle is an involuntary action.

Sebaceous glands open into the hair follicles and produce sebum (oily secretion).
Sebum keeps the skin soft and makes it waterproof. Moreover, it is an antiseptic that can inhibit the growth of bacteria and fungi on the skin.

Sweat glands are glands that secrete sweat.
Sweat consist of water, minerals and metabolic wastes (e.g. urea).

By sweating, sweat from each sweat gland passes along a sweat duct to the skin surface through a sweat pore.
Evaporation of sweat helps cool the skin.
Sweating helps excrete metabolic wastes.

Sensory receptors are present in the dermis to detect stimuli (e.g. temperature, touch, pain).
Sensory neurones carry nerve impulses from the receptors to the CNS. Motor neurones carry nerve impulses from the CNS to the muscles and glands in the dermis.

General function:

Supply living cells in the skin with oxygen and nutrients, and remove carbon dioxide and metabolic wastes.
Shunt vessels:

Connect arterioles and venules, allowing blood to bypass certain capillaries.
Controlling the amount of blood flowing through the capillaries near the skin surface can control the heat loss from the skin.

A layer of subcutaneous fat lies underneath the dermis.

Thickness of the layer varies among different regions of the body and individuals.
Serves as an insulating layer to reduce heat loss.
Serves as a source of energy reserve.

item.title: Design
item.description:
Dialysis machines are used in patients with kidney failures to perform haemodialysis, which can remove wastes and excess salts from the blood.



Dialysis tubing is differentially permeable.
It has small pores that allow small molecules to pass through, but blood cells and plasma proteins cannot.
Composition of the dialysis fluid is similar to that of blood plasma.
It has the same concentration of glucose, amino acids and salts as normal blood, so there is no net flow of essential substances from the blood to the dialysis fluid in order to prevent the loss of essential substances.
The water potential is the same as blood to prevent water loss.
The dialysis fluid is kept at the same temperature as blood (37°C) to prevent heat loss.
However, it does not contain urea to allow urea to diffuse into the dialysis fluid down the concentration gradient.
Dialysis tubing is highly branched. (similar to a capillary network)
This increases the surface area for rapid diffusion of urea out of the blood.
Dialysis fluid and blood flow in opposite directions.
This ensures there will be a difference in concentration in the whole length of the dialysis tubing, this maintains a steep concentration gradient for rapid diffusion, and ensures more urea is removed.


The amount of blood that can be drawn into the dialysis machine per unit time is limited, each treatment may take 4-6 hours to remove most urea from blood.
The treatment has to be repeated 2-3 times a week as urea is continuously produced by the liver.


Eat foods with less proteins / less protein-rich foods
Control of diet

item.title: Excretion
item.description:
Excretion is the removal of metabolic wastes from the body.
The kidneys are major excretory organs for urea, which is produced in the liver through deamination of excess amino acids. It is forced out from the glomerulus into the Bowman's capsule by ultrafiltration.

item.title: Osmoregulation
item.description:
Osmoregulation is the regulation of water content in the body.
Goals of osmoregulation:

Keeping the water potential of the blood and tissue fluid constant (water balance)
Maintaining a stable environment for cells to function properly
↪️ Achieved by actively retaining or releasing water in urine

Osmoregulation is controlled by a negative feedback mechanism. This involves urine production, which is brought about by antidiuretic hormone (ADH).
Details of antidiuretic hormone (ADH):

Production: Produced by the hypothalamus of the brain continuously.
Release: Stored and released by the pituitary gland. Amount of ADH released depends on the changes in water potential of blood detected by osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus.
Effects: Increases the permeability of the walls of the collecting duct so that a proportion of water is reabsorbed.
Goal: Conserve water / Remove excess water


Osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus detect a fall in water potential in blood, and signals the pituitary gland to release more ADH.
The level of ADH in blood increases.
The walls of the collecting ducts become more permeable to water.
A larger proportion of water is reabsorbed into the blood by osmosis.
A smaller volume of concentrated urine is formed.
The hypothalamus stimulates the 'thirst centre' in the brain, so the person feel thirsty and drink water.
The water potential of blood rises and returns to normal.


Osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus detect a rise in water potential in blood, and signals the pituitary gland to release less ADH.
The level of ADH in blood decreases.
The walls of the collecting ducts become less permeable to water.
A smaller proportion of water is reabsorbed into the blood by Osmosis.
A larger volume of dilute urine is formed.
The water potential of blood falls and returns to normal.

Processes for water gain and loss
Water gain: drinks, food, metabolism (e.g. respiration)
Water loss: exhaled air, sweat, urine, faeces

Factors:

Direct gain/loss of water
Production of metabolic wastes (e.g. urea) during respiration
Glucose level (e.g. absorption, diabetes mellitus)
Intake of minerals
Note As part of osmoregulation, small and soluble substances in blood are also filtered and end up in the urine produced. This helps to achieve the salt and water balance of the body.
Effects:

Regulation by ADH
Secretion of ADH is increased/decreased in order to retain/release a larger amount of water in blood.
Increased blood volume
When the water potential of the cells is higher than that of blood, there will be a net movement of water from body cells to blood by osmosis.

Consider two types of drinks: distilled water, mineralized water

All drinks increases the volume of blood.
Distilled water increases the water potential of blood, this decreases the secretion of ADH to release water.
A larger volume of dilute urine is produced when taking in distilled water, and therefore it is less effective in replenishing water loss / maintaining higher fluid content.
Mineralized water decreases the water potential of blood, this increases the secretion of ADH to retain water, while removing excess salts.
A smaller volume of concentrated urine is produced when taking in mineralized water, and therefore it is more effective in replenishing water loss / maintaining higher fluid content.

item.title: Reabsorption
item.description:
Reabsorption takes place at the kidney tubule. Useful substances are actively absorbed into the blood via capillaries, while water and urea are absorbed passively into blood.


Glucose, amino acids and some salts in the glomerular filtrate are reabsorbed into the blood by both diffusion and active transport.
The reabsorption of glucose, amino acids and salts causes the glomerular filtrate to become more dilute and its water potential increases. Water in the filtrate moves into blood by osmosis down a water potential gradient.
Amount of water reabsorbed is directly proportional to the amount of solutes reabsorbed. Therefore, the concentration of the filtrate that arrives at the end of the first coiled tubule remains unchanged.
Reabsorption of water from the glomerular filtrate raises the concentration of urea (to become higher than in blood) along the tubule, resulting in passive reabsorption of urea into blood by diffusion.
Note
Glucose and amino acids are soluble in water, as they can form extensive hydrogen bonds with water molecules.
Glucose and amino acids are completely (and only) reabsorbed in the first coiled tubule. Water, urea, and some salts are reabsorbed even in the collecting duct.
For sodium ions, they are always actively reabsorbed. Their presence in blood can affect the water potential of blood.


The first coiled tubule is long and highly coiled, increasing surface area and allowing more time for reabsorption.
The inner wall of first coiled tubule is lined with microvilli, increasing surface area for reabsorption.
The wall of first coiled tubule is only one-cell thick, and the tubules are close in contact with blood capillaries, shortening the distance for reabsorption.
The cells in the walls of first coiled tubule contain numerous mitochondria, providing a lot of energy for active transport of useful substances against a concentration gradient.
Each kidney tubule is richly supplied with blood capillaries, a steep concentration gradient can be maintained for rapid absorption of substances.
Tip The kidneys contain over a million nephrons, this makes the kidneys highly effective in filtering blood and reabsorption.

item.title: Adaptations
item.description:
Ultrafiltration takes place in the glomerulus.

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue ⤴️


Blood inside the glomerulus is under high blood pressure due to the pumping action of the heart, which results in high hydrostatic pressure in the glomerulus.
Capillary wall of the glomerulus and the wall of the Bowman's capsule are thin and differentially permeable. They serve as the filter to allow ultrafiltration.
The glomerulus has a high surface area for diffusion due to its capillary network. This allows efficient filtration of blood by maintainining a steep concentration gradient of substances.
Note An increase in the blood volume would increase the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerulus.


Water and other small molecules in the blood are forced out.
Due to the high hydrostatic pressure inside the glomerulus, they are forced out through the walls of the glomerulus and the Bowman's capsule into the capsular space to form the glomerular filtrate.
Blood cells and plasma proteins are absent in the glomerular filtrate.
They are too large to pass through the walls of the glomerulus and the Bowman's capsule.
Note
Composition of glomerular filtrate is similar to tissue fluid as they are both formed similarly.
About 20% of blood in the glomerulus is filtered and becomes the glomerular filtrate.
Diseases
Proteinuria — Urine contains excess proteins, usually caused by damaged glomerular capillaries or Bowman's capsule (which acts as filters). As useful proteins are lost, it may cause edema (build-up of fluid in the body's tissue, causing swelling).

item.title: Urinary system
item.description:
The urinary system is responsible for osmoregulation.
Kidneys:

Receives blood from the aorta through the renal arteries and return blood to the vena cava through the renal veins.
Filters the blood to form urine and leads to osmoregulation and excretion.
Ureter:

Connects the kidneys to the urinary bladder.
Urinary bladder:

Muscular sac responsible for temporary storage of urine.
Urethra:

Two sphincter muscles are present to prevent urine from leaking out.
Urination is the process that releases urine to the outside of the body.




Nephrons are responsible for filtering of blood and formation of urine.
Blood vessels:

Afferent arteriole pump blood into the glomerulus (a network of capillaries).
Glomerulus join to form an efferent arteriole leaving the Bowman's capsule.
Efferent arteriole leads to another network of capillaries that wraps around the kidney tubule.
Flow of fluid along the kidney tubule:
Bowman's capsule → proximal convoluted tubule → loop of Henle → distal convoluted tubule → collecting duct
Info
All Bowman's capsules are found in the cortex of the kidney.
Collecting ducts drain their contents into the pelvis and then to the ureter.


Ultrafiltration
Reabsorption


Osmoregulation
Excretion

Main article: Dialysis machines
Kidney failure occurs when the half of the kidney function is lost. It can be treated through haemodialysis.

item.title: Colour vision
item.description:
Main article: Human eye

The colour we see depend on relative stimulation of the three types of cone cells.
The three types of cone cells are sensitive to either red, green or blue. Below shows the colour produced when these types of cone cells are stimulated:
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Stimuli, receptors and responses/Human eye/Colour vision.md

item.title: In bright light
item.description:
Main article: Human eye
The pupil is the hole in the centre of the iris, circular muscles and radial muscles of the iris, which its muscles contract or relax to change its size and regulate the amount of light entering the eye. It is a reflex action.



Circular muscles of the iris: Contract
Radial muscles of the iris: Relax
Pupil: Constricts (becomes smaller)
Light entering the eye: Less
Importance: Prevents excessive light from entering the eye so that the photoreceptors will not be damaged.



Circular muscles of the iris: Relax
Radial muscles of the iris: Contraxt
Pupil: Dilates (becomes larger)
Light entering the eye: More
Importance: Increases stimulation of the photoreceptors to allow us to see in dim light.
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Stimuli, receptors and responses/Human eye/Controlling the amount of light that enters the eye.md

item.title: Eye accommodation
item.description:
Main article: Human eye
Eye accommodation refers to the changing of the curvature (shape) of the lens in order to allow light rays from objects at different distances to be focused on the retina. This works because of the elastic nature of the lens of the eye.
Note
Light rays from nearby objects are more divergent (spread out) and require more refraction.
Light rays from distant objects are nearly parallel and require less refraction.



Circular ciliary muscles around the lens: Contract
Suspensory ligaments: Become slack (tension reduced)
Lens: Becomes thicker (more convex) due to its elasticity and refracts light more



Circular ciliary muscles around the lens: Relax
Suspensory ligaments: Becomes tighter (tension increased)
Lens: Becomes thinner (less convex) due to its elasticity and refracts light less
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Stimuli, receptors and responses/Human eye/Eye accommodation.md

item.title: External structures of the eye
item.description:
The human eye is a photoreceptor for detecting light. The brain receives the nerve impulses from the eyes and interpret them to produce vision.


The eye is a spherical organ situated in an orbit, a bony socket in the skull, which encloses and protects all but the front of the eye.
There are three pairs of eye muscles that attach the eyeball to the wall of the orbit. They contract and relax to allow the eyeball to rotate.


Eyebrows prevent sweat from entering the eye.
Eyelashes trap dirt before it can enter the eye.
Eyelids can close to protect the eye from foreign objects and strong light.
Tear glands is located above the eyeball and secretes tears.
When we blink, the eyelids spread tears over the eye surface, keeping it moist and clean.
Tears contain an enzyme called lysozyme to kill bacteria.



The sclera is the white of the eye.

It is a white, opaque, fibrous coat of the eye, which is very tough so that it gives shape to the eyeball and protects the structures inside.
It is the surface where the eye muscles attach to the eyeball.
The cornea is located in the front part of the eye and is continuous with the sclera.

It is transparent so that light can enter the eye.
It has a curved surface that refracts (bends) light.

The choroid contains many blood vessels to supply cells of the retina with nutrients and oxygen, and removes carbon dioxide and metabolic wastes produced.

It is dark in colour because it contains a black pigment to absorb light. This is to prevent reflection of light in the eye and contributes to sharp vision.
The ciliary body is a forward continuation of the choroid.

Ciliary muscles: Ring of circular muscular tissues that surrounds the edge of the lens.
Suspensory ligaments: Connects the ciliary body with the lens and holds it in place.
The lens is a transparent, elastic and biconvex structure that helps refract and focus light onto the retina.

It consists of living cells with no nuclei. This makes them transparent and allows light to pass through without obstruction.
Its elasticity allow the shape of the lens to be changed when looking at objects from different distances.
Note Ciliary muscles in the ciliary body contract or relax to change the tension of suspensory ligaments, and hence the shape of the lens (thickness, curvature) in order to focus light from objects at different distances onto the retina. See also: Eye accommodation
The iris lies in front of the lens and is connected to the ciliary body.

It contains the pigment which gives the eye its colour.
It consists of circular muscles and radial muscles with a central hole called the pupil.
The pair of muscles change the size of the pupil, controlling the amount of light that enters the eye.


The retina contains two types of photoreceptors (light-sensitive cells), which generate nerve impulses when stimulated by light.

Rod cells are rod-shaped cells that contain the photosensitive pigment visual purple, which is very sensitive to light and stimulated by lower light intensities, allowing it to work well in dim light.

However, it cannot detect colours, they are responsible for black-and-white vision.
They are evenly distributed across the retina, except for their absence from the yellow spot and the blind spot.
Cone cells are cone-shaped cells that are stimulated by higher light intensities and are used mainly in bright light for colour vision.

They are less numerous than rod cells — most are concentrated at the yellow spot, but few are found in the periphery of the retina. This is why objects appear most clearly when their image fall on the yellow spot.
The yellow spot is located at the central region of the retina and contains cone cells only. Vision in the centre mainly relies on the detection of light falling on the yellow spot.
The blind spot contains no photoreceptors. It is where the optic nerve leaves the eye.
The optic nerve is a bundle of nerve fibres with neurones that are connected with photoreceptors on the retina.

When the photoreceptos are stimulated by light, nerve impulses are generated to stimulate the visual centre of the brain. They are transmitted via the optic nerve.
The region where the optic nerve leave the brain is called the blind spot.

Note Each type of cone cells (red, green and blue cone cells) have a dedicated neurone connected to it.



The eyeball is divided into two chambers by the lens internally.

Anterior chamber
Space between the cornea and the lens, filled with aqueous humour, a clear and watery solution secreted by the ciliary body.
Supplies nutrients and oxygen to the cornea and the lens, which have no blood vessels.
Posterior chamber
Space between the lens and the retina, filled with vitreous humour, a clear and jelly-like fluid secreted by the ciliary body.
↪️ These chambers help keep the shape of the eyeball by maintaining the intraocular pressure and inflates the globe of the eye, and refract and focus light onto the retina.


Light rays from the object enter one's eyes through the cornea and are refracted by the cornea, aqueous humour, lens and vitreous humour to be focused on the retina to form a real, vertically and laterally inverted image that is smaller than the object.
When photoreceptors on the retina are stimulated by light falling on them, they generate and send nerve impulses along the optic nerve to the visual centre of the brain, which interprets the nerve impulses to produce vision, allowing us to see an upright image of the object.
Image formed on the blind spot is not visible because it has no photoreceptors to detect light, no nerve impulses are generated to send to the brain.



Short sight is a defect that causes a person see near objects more clearly than distant objects. It occurs when either the eyeball is too long or that the lens is too thick, or a combination of both.
Info People with severe short sight have a higher risk for retinal detachment. This happens as the eyeball continues to lengthen, pulling the retina away from the choroid. Since retina contains light sensitive cells and obtains nutrients / oxygen from choroid, light sensitive cells will die and light falling on retina cannot be detected, no nerve impulse can be produced. Therefore, vision is impaired.
Effects:

Light rays from nearby objects focus correctly.

Light rays from distant objects are focused in front of the retina, resulting in a blurred image on the retina.

Correction method:

By wearing glasses containing concave (diverging) lenses.
Light rays from distant objects are diverged before entering the eyes, allowing the image to be bright back into focus on the retina.



Long sight is a defect that causes a person see distant objects more clearly than near objects. It occurs when either the eyeball is too short or that the lens is too thin, or a combination of both.
Effects:

Light rays from near objects are focused behind the retina, resulting in a blurred image on the retina.

Light rays from distant objects focus correctly.

Correction method:

By wearing glasses containing convex (converging) lenses.
Light rays from near objects are converged before entering the eyes, a sharp image is formed on the retina.



Colour blindness is an inability to distinguish some or all colours. It is caused by the poor functioning or a deficiency of one or more types of cone cells. Colour blindness is an inherited eye defect. In rare cases, it can be caused by damage to the retina or the brain.
Red-green colour blindness is the most common type of colour blindness in humans, the person would not be able to distinguish red and green because of poor functioning or deficiency of red or green cone cells. Total colour blindness is rare in humans.
There is currently no cure for colour blindness, but colour-blind people generally live a normal life. Mild forms of colour blindness are often not recognized by the person concerned.
Test cards for colour blindness:

Aids to improve vision:

Wear glasses with special filter lenses to help one see more accurately.
Mobile phone applications that help colour-blind people see colours using the camera of their smartphones.
item.guid: Biology/Neuroscience/Stimuli, receptors and responses/Human eye/Human eye.md

item.title: Structures
item.description:
The human ear is a mechanoreceptor for detecting sound (pressure waves). The brain receives the nerve impulses from the ears and interpret them to produce hearing.


Outer ear:

Pinna: Flap of funnel shaped elastic cartilage covered with skin to facilitate the collection of sound waves into the auditory canal.
Auditory canal: Passageway for sound from the pinna to the eardrum.
Middle ear:

Eardrum: Thin and elastic membrane that vibrates when sound waves reach it and converts sound waves to mechanical vibrations.
Ear bones: Amplifies the vibrations from the eardrum and transmits them to the oval window.
Eustachian tube: Helps maintain equal pressure on either side of the eardrum by allowing air to enter or leave the middle ear.

Inner ear:

Oval window: Flexible membrane that transmits the vibrations to the cochlea in the inner ear.
Round window: Flexible membrane that allows the pressure built up in the cochlea to be released into the middle ear.
Cochlea: Divided lengthwise by membranes into three liquid filled canals.
Upper canal: In contact with the oval window.
Lower canal: In contact with the round window.
Central canal: Contains sensory hair cells connected to the auditory nerve.
Movements of the endolymph cause hairs of the sensory hair cells to bend, stimulating the sensory hair cells to generate nerve impulses.
The nerve impulses are sent along the auditory nerve to the auditory centre of the brain for interpretation.
Semicircular canals: Detect head movements and help us have a sense of balance.

item.title: Stimuli and receptors
item.description:
Irritability is the ability of organisms to detect stimuli and produce appropriate responses accordingly. It is important to survival as it enables organisms to escape from danger, and look for food and mates.

Stimuli are changes in our internal and external environment. They are detected by sensory cells called receptors.
Different types of receptors detect different stimuli, some are grouped with other tissues to form a sense organ. Below lists a few main types of receptors:

Receptors convert stimuli into nerve impulses that travel along a nerve to the control centre (usually the brain), where they are interpreted as a sensation. The control centre can send nerve impulses to effectors (e.g. muscles or glands) to produce responses.



Nervous coordination: The nervous system coordinates the receptors and effectors, with the brain serving as the control centre.
Hormonal coordination: Coordination is brought about by the endocrine system.


Human eye
Human ear
Phototropic response
Coordination

item.title: Growth responses
item.description:
See also: Growth and development / Photosynthesis
Phototropism is the directional growth movement of a plant part in response to unilateral light. It is controlled by auxins.

Shoots: positive phototropism (towards light)

Leaves are brought to face the light source.
Maximum amount of light can be absorbed for photosynthesis.
Roots: negative phototropism (away from light)

Roots can grow downward into the soil for anchorage.

Auxins are a group of plant hormones produced in the apical meristem at the tip of shoots and roots. They are transported to the regions of elongation, stimulating the cells to elongate and hence promote growth.
Illumination from all directions:

Auxins distribute evenly from all directions in the regions of elongation of the shoot and the root.
The shoot and the root shows growth without bending.
Illumination with unilateral light:

Auxins migrate from the illuminated side to the shaded side of the shoot and root.
High concentration of auxins stimulates shoot growth on the illuminated side, the shoot shows bending growth towards the light.
High concentration of auxins inhibits root growth on the shaded side, the root shows bending growth away from the light.
Warning Light does not destroy auxins in the illuminated side of the plant.



Auxin concentrations from 10-6 to 10-4 ppm promote root growth, but are insufficient to promote shoot growth.
Auxin concentrations from 10-4 to 102 ppm promote both shoot and root growth.
Auxin concentrations from 10-2 to 102 ppm promote shoot growth, but inhibit root growth.
Auxin concentrations above 102 ppm inhibit both shoot and root growth.


Coleoptiles are protective sheaths that cover the first leaf of a monocotyledonous seedling as the young shoot emerges from the soil. It was used to investigate phototropism.
Suitability for experiments:

They are fast-growing.
They are easy to handle.
They have a simple structure for easy observation.



Observations:

If the tip is removed / blocked from light, no bending growth movement occurs.
Bending growth occurs even if the lower part of the coleoptile is covered.
Conclusions:

The tip is responsible for detecting the unilateral light.
Bending growth (response) did not occur in the tip itself but in the region below the tip.
Hypothesis:
A signal is transmitted from the tip to a lower part of the coleoptile to exert the effects of growth.


Observations:

Bending growth occurred even when an agar block is inserted.
Growth does not occur when a mica plate is inserted.
Conclusions:

A signal is transmitted from the tip by diffusing through the agar block to reach the lower part of the coleoptile and exert the effects of growth.
The signal transmitted from the tip to the lower part of the coleoptile is chemical in nature, as the mica plate is impermeable to chemicals and blocked the transmission of signal.


Conclusions:
The chemical produced by the tip passes down the shaded side of the coleoptile.


Conclusions:

The agar block contained the chemical produced by the tip of the coleoptile.
This chemical stimulated growth as it passed down the decapitated coleoptile.
The decapitated coleoptile bent to one side because of a higher concentration of the growth-promoting chemical on the other side.


Conclusions:
Unilateral light had caused an uneven distribution of the chemical and the shaded side had a higher concentration of the chemical.

item.title: Cell wall
item.description:
The cell wall is a thick, rigid layer made up of cellulose covering the cell membranes of plant cells.
Functions:

Protects and gives a more regular shape to plant cells
Fully permeable to water and dissolved substances
Composition of cell wall The cell wall in some organisms is not made up of cellulose, but peptidoglycan, chitin or other compounds.
↪️ See also: Eubacteria / Archaebacteria / Fungi

item.title: Cytoplasm
item.description:
Contents:

Jelly-like substance made up of water, proteins and other simple molecules (e.g. sugars, fatty acids, nucleotides, etc.)
Holds all organelles in a cell and serve as a medium of biochemical reactions to take place.

item.title: Endoplasmic reticulum
item.description:
The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is an extensive network of interconnected membrane-bound sacs that extends from the outer nuclear envelope to the periphery of the cell (i.e. cell membrane).
Specialised types of ER:

Rough endoplasmic reticulum
A series of convoluted, flattened membranes.
Attached with ribosomes on the surface.
Transports proteins produced at the ribosomes.
Large quantities are present in protein-secreting cells.
(e.g. cells that secrete insulin in the pancreas)
Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
A network of folded / stacked membranes that provides a large surface area for various enzymes to align for carrying out metabolic processes.
Involved in the synthesis and transport of lipids within the cytoplasm.
Large quantities are present in lipid-secreting cells.
(e.g. cells that secrete male sex hormones in the testes / Leydig cells)

item.title: Light microscope
item.description:
Light source: Transmitted light passes through the specimen
Sample / Specimen: Living or dead cells
View of image: Two-dimensional, colour images
Resolution / Magnification: Lowest, sub-cellular structures cannot be observed
Preparation of samples:
Sample do not need to be fixed and processed.
Ultra-thin sections are not needed.
Total magnification of a compound microscope:
Magnification of eyepiece x Magnification of objective
Image formed is inverted upside down and reversed laterally. b → p



Light source: Electron beams passes through the specimen
Sample / Specimen: Dead cells
View of image: Two-dimensional, black and white images
Resolution / Magnification: Highest, sub-cellular structures can be observed
Preparation of samples:
Samples have to be fixed and sectioned in order to preserve and stabilise cell structures.
Ultra-thin sections must be used.


Light source: Electrons bounce off the specimen
Sample / Specimen: Dead cells
View of image: Three-dimensional, black and white images
Resolution / Magnification: Moderate, only surface features can be observed
Preparation of samples:
Samples have to be fixed and coated with a thin layer of heavy metal in order to preserve and stabilise cell structure.
Ultra-thin sections are not needed.

item.title: Nucleus
item.description:
Darkly stained spherical structure under the light microscope.
Surrounded by the nuclear membrane (a double membrane).
Nuclear pores: Allow exchange between nucleus and cytoplasm.
Nucleolus (organelle in nucleus): Plays a key role in the large-scale production of rDNAs and assembly of ribosomal subunits.
Contains DNA which controls protein synthesis and thus all activities of a cell (e.g. growth and repair).
