item.title: Sex determination
item.description:
Sex chromosomes are chromosomes that control the inheritance of sex and certain characteristics of the body.

Females have two X chromosomes (), while males have one X chromosomes and one Y chromosomes ().
Certain genes present in sex chromosomes (usually the X chromosome, as it is much larger than the Y chromosome, and thus carries more genes) can cause the inheritance of sex-linked traits.

Note The other 22 pairs of chromosomes are referred to as autosomes.
In meiosis, all ova receive an X chromosome. However, half of the sperms receive an X chromosome and the other half receive a Y chromosome.
Since the two types of sperms are produced in equal proportions and fertilization is a random process, there is an equal chance ( or ) of having a boy or a girl at each birth.


Generally, sex-linked inheritances are X-linked and recessive in nature.


Red-green color blindness
X-linked genetic disorder caused by a recessive allele on the X chromosome. Certain cone cells in the retina are absent or defective.
Haemophilia
Many possible causes. One of which is the deficiency of blood platelets, where people are unable to form blood clots normally (blood coagulation / blood clotting).

Key:
: dominant allele for normal color vision
: recessive allele for red-green color blindness


Males have only one X chromosome, and if their X chromosome carries the recessive allele, they will suffer from the disorder.
↪️ X-linked recessive inheritance is more common in males than females.



This is an example of multiple alleles / co-dominance.


and are co-dominant (equally dominant) alleles, while is a recessive allele.


If blood with incompatible blood groups were transfused into the patient, the antibodies will attach to the antigens of the red blood cell's surface, causing agglutination / clumping of red blood cells.



People with blood group AB is a universal recipient, as they do not have antibodies against antigens A or B.
People with blood group O is a universal donor, as they do not have antigen A or B on their red blood cells.

item.title: Types of inheritance
item.description:
Pre-context: Genes


Monohybrid inheritance: The inheritance of single characteristics that are controlled by a single gene. These characters are contrasting (e.g. red or white flower).
Dihybrid inheritance: The simultaneous inheritance of two characteristics. The two characteristics are controlled by two different genes.


Law of Dominance (First law of inheritance)
Heterozygote (hybrid) will only express the dominant trait in the phenotype.
↪️ See also: Genes > Common terms for genetics
Law of Segregation (Third law of inheritance)
During the production of gametes, two copies of each hereditary factor segregate so that offspring acquire one factor from each parent when the gametes re-unite randomly during fertilization.
↪️ See also: Meiotic cell division > Significance of meiotic cell division
Law of Independent Assortment (Second law of inheritance)
A pair of traits segregates independently of another pair during gamete formation.
↪️ See also: Independent assortment

Mendel's laws of inheritance was proposed by Gregor Mendel in the 1860s after conducting breeding experiments on pea plants.
Pea plants were chosen because:

They had easily observable characteristics.
They grew fast.
They were easy to handle.



Mendel took two pea plants of opposite traits (one short and one tall - homozygous) and crossed them. He found the generation offspring were tall (homozygous dominant).
Then, he crossed the filial generation and obtained both tall and short plants in the ratio (monohybrid ratio) in the generation.



Mendel crossed wrinkled-green seed and round-yellow seeds and observed that all the generation were round-yellow (heterozygous). This meant that dominant traits were the round shape and yellow colour.
He then self-pollinated the generation and obtained 4 different traits: round-yellow, round-green, wrinkled-yellow, and wrinkled-green seeds in the ratio (dihybrid ratio) in the generation.

Consider the colour of pea flowers, where represents the dominant allele for red colour, represents the recessive allele for white colour.
To deduce the dominant allele, find a pair of parents with the same phenotype but their offspring has different phenotypes.

Principles for deduction:

The genotype of the the offspring results in the phenotype expressed.
All genes are inherited from the offsprings' parents.
Deduction:

Offspring D is white in colour, so it posses white colour allele.
As the white colour allele is inherited from one of its parents, A or B, either A or B should posses a white colour allele.
However, A and B are all red in colour, that means they all also posses red colour allele.
So either A or B should be heterozygous, and since red colour allele express in this condition, red colour allele is dominant.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Basic Genetics/Mendel's laws of inheritance.md

item.title: Test cross
item.description:
Test cross is used to find out an organism's genotype (homozygous or heterozygous).
Method:
Cross an organism with another organism with homozygous recessive phenotype.

If all the offspring produced express dominant phenotype, then the organism crossed is homozygous.
If the offsprings are half dominant and half recessive (phenotypic ratio ), the organism is heterozygous.
Diagram:

item.title: Types of variations
item.description:
Variations are differences in characteristic among individuals of the same species.


Discontinuous variations is a type of variation that has a few distinct phenotypes and no intermediate forms.

These characteristics are usually controlled by one gene and are relatively unaffected by environmental factors.
Surveys for variation are presented in bar charts.
Examples: Blood groups, tongue-rolling ability


Continuous variations is a type of variation that shows a continuous range of intermediate forms.

These characteristics are easily affected by environmental factors.
Surveys for variation are presented in histograms. Large sample sizes often result in bell-shaped charts with a normal distribution.
Examples: Height, weight, IQ



Sexual reproduction
↪️ Produces offspring with a mix of genetic materials from parents.
Independent assortment
↪️ Results in different combinations of chromosomes.
Crossing over
↪️ Results in new combinations of alleles in chromosomes.
Random fusion of gametes at fertilization
↪️ Results in zygote with different combinations of genetic materials.
Mutations
↪️ Results in new alleles.

item.title: Major stages
item.description:
The cell cycle refers to the sequence of events in a cell from the time it is formed until the time it divides.


Interphase
Nuclear division
Cytokinesis


Mitotic cell division
Meiotic cell division

item.title: Crossing over
item.description:
Crossing over is a process when two non-sister chromatids of a homologous pair cross each other at certain points, exchanging corresponding segments. This may happen when homologous chromosomes pair up during prophase I.
This process brings about new genetic combinations in gametes.

item.title: In animal cells
item.description:
Cytokinesis is the process by which the cytoplasm divides into two equal halves to form two daughter cells.


The cell membrane around the middle of the dividing cells move inwards, constricting to form a cleavage furrow, which deepens until the parent cell separates to form two daughter cells.


A cell plate is formed midway between the two daughter nuclei, growing inwards and dividing the cytoplasm into two halves to form two daughter cells.

item.title: Independent assortment
item.description:
Independent assortment, or random segregation, describes the independent separation of genes during the development of gametes in meiosis I. The gametes produced vary in their combinations of chromosomes. ()
Process:

The paired homologous chromosomes line up along the equatorial plane.
The arrangement of chromosomes in each homologous pair at the equatorial plane is random.
The two members of each pair of homologous chromosomes are separated independently.

item.title: Interphase
item.description:
Interphase is a period of active growth between two successive cell division, where cells carry out intense metabolic activities to prepare for the next cell division.
Metabolic activities:

Synthesis of proteins
Synthesis of new organelles
Replication of DNA (duplication of chromosomes)
By the end of interphase, the cell has doubled (2x) its amount of DNA, and is large enough to divide.


During this stage when the cell is not dividing, the chromosomes cannot be seen with a light microscope because they appear as long and fine threads of chromatin.

item.title: Stages of meiosis
item.description:
Meiotic cell division involves meiosis (division of the nucleus) and cytokinesis (division of the cytoplasm) to form four genetically different, haploid daughter cells. This occurs in gamete-producing cells in reproductive organs.





Replicated DNA coils tightly into chromosomes.
Each chromosome is visible as two sister chromatids.
Homologous chromosome pair up.
The chromatids of the homologous pair may exchange segments with each other by crossing over.
The nuclear membrane breaks down.
Spindle fibres start to form.



Homologous pairs line up along the equatorial plane.
The spindle fibres attach to the chromosomes at the centromeres.



The spindle fibres shorten and pull the two chromosomes of each homologous pair apart to opposite poles of the cell.



The spindle fibres break down.
A nuclear membrane forms around each group of chromosomes. This is followed by cytokinesis, forming two haploid daughter cells.
In some organisms, the nuclear membrane re-forms and the chromosomes decondense, although in others, this step is skipped since cells will soon go through another round of division in meiosis II.




The nuclear membrane break down again.
Spindle fibres start to form.



The chromosomes line up along the equatorial plane.
The spindle fibres attach to the chromosome at the centromeres.



The spindle fibres shorten and pull the sister chromatids of each chromosome apart, moving them towards opposite poles of the cell.
The separated chromatids are now called daughter chromosomes.



The spindle fibres break down.
A nuclear membrane forms around each group of daughter chromosomes. This is followed by cytokinesis, four haploid daughter cells are formed.
Each cell contains one member of each homologous pair and only half the chromosomes of the parent cell and are genetically different.
The chromosomes loosen to become chromatin again.




Chromosome number (Meiosis I) ⤴

Chromosome number (Meiosis II) ⤴


Sexual reproduction
Meiotic cell division forms haploid gametes for sexual reproduction.
When a male gamete and female gamete fuse at fertilisation to form a zygote, the diploid number (2n) of chromosome is restored. This keeps the chromosome number of a species constant from generation to generation.
Genetic variation (speciation)
Meiotic cell division creates very large numbers of genetic variation among the gametes. Some offspring may have characteristics that enable them to survive environmental changes better. This increases the chance of survival of the species. Below are a few possible explanations:
Independent assortment (or random segregation)
Crossing over
Random fusion of gametes at fertilisation
↪️ See also: Mendel's laws of inheritance > Mendal's laws




Half of the gametes have both members of the homologous pair.
Half of the gametes have no members of the homologous pair.



Half of the gametes have haploid numbers of chromosomes. (normal)
Half of the gametes have both members of the homologous pair.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Cell cycle & division/Meiotic cell division.md

item.title: Stages of mitosis
item.description:
Mitotic cell division involves mitosis (division of the nucleus) and cytokinesis (division of the cytoplasm) to form two daughter cells. Each daughter cells are genetically identical to each other and to the parent cell, as they receive a copy of every chromosome of the parent cell.




Replicated DNA coils up tightly into chromosomes.
Each chromosome is visible as two sister chromatids attached at the centromere.
The nuclear membrane breaks down.
Spindle fibres start to form.



The chromosomes line up along the equatorial plane.
The spindle fibres attach the chromosomes at the centromeres.



The spindle fibres shorten and pull the sister chromatids of each chromosome apart, moving them towards opposite poles of the cell.
The separated chromatids are now called daughter chromosomes.



The spindle fibres break down.
The chromosomes loosen (decondense) to become chromatin again.
A nuclear membrane forms around each group of daughter chromosomes. This is followed by cytokinesis, forming two diploid daughter cells.




Chromosome number ⤴

The two daughter cells formed by mitotic cell division are genetically identical to the parent cell and have the same function. The following is a list of significant reasons for this:

Growth
Significance: Provides new cells for growth in multicellular organisms.
Occurrence: May occur over the entire body (in animals), or be limited to certain regions (meristems in plants).
Repair
Significance: Provides new cells to replace dead or damaged cells in multicellular organisms.
Occurrence: Happens more frequently in some body parts (e.g. in the skin and the lining of the intestines) for tissue repair.
Asexual reproduction
Description: Involves no fusion of gametes
Significance: Offspring produced are genetically identical to their parents and to each other.
Occurrence: In specific organisms (e.g. Amoeba & some plants)

It depends on the type of cell, some examples are listed below:

Brain cells and cardiac muscle cells do not divide.
Bone marrow cells divide continuously.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Cell cycle & division/Mitotic cell division.md

item.title: Nuclear division
item.description:
Nuclear division is the division of the nucleus, consisting of either one round of mitosis, or two rounds of meiosis.
List article!

This article is a list of related items, and may constitute a stub article. You can help the Knowledge Handbook by expanding it.

item.title: Chromosomes
item.description:
Series: DNA, chromosomes & genes
DNA - Chromosomes - Genes

A chromosome is made up of DNA wrapped around protein molecules histone.

When a cell is going to divide, chromatin condenses to form a chromosome.
Chromosomes are normally visible under a light microscope only during the metaphase of cell division.


In interphase, each chromosome is duplicated (DNA is replicated).
When the cell is about to divide at the beginning of nuclear division (prophase), the chromatin coils tightly into a chromosome.

Each chromosome is visible as a X-shaped structure made up of two chromatids joined together at the centromere.
The joined copies are now referred to as sister chromatids (as they are identical copies of each other).
During cell division, genetic information is carried by DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) to be passed from a parent cell to the daughter cells.

The number of chromosomes in a single cell varies from species to species. However, all somatic cells from a particular species have a fixed number of chromosomes.

Diploid (): Cell or organism with two sets of chromosomes.
e.g. human somatic cells
Haploid (): Cell with only one set of chromosomes.
e.g. sex cells, gametes

Homologous chromosomes are a pair of chromosomes with the same size and shape. They have the same organisation of genes.
It is formed when one maternal and one paternal chromosome pair up with each other inside a cell during fertilization.


Parental chromosomes: The set of chromosomes from male parent.
Maternal chromosomes: The set of chromosomes from female parent.

item.title: DNA
item.description:
Series: DNA, chromosomes & genes
(Nucleic acids) - DNA - Chromosomes - Genes

Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is the chemical that stores genetic information in a cell. It is usually found in the nucleus.

A DNA molecule consists of two polynucleotide chains (i.e. two DNA strands) that run in opposite directions and are twisted together to form a double helix. (anti-parallel relationship)
The backbone of the DNA molecule is made up of the sugar (deoxyribose) and phosphate groups of nucleotides.
Attached to the sugar of each nucleotide is one of four nitrogenous bases: adenine (A), thymine (T), guanine (G) and cytosine (C). They can do complementary base pairing.
Genetic information is stored in the sequence of the nucleotide bases in DNA.
Complementary base paring: Bases on one strand pair up with those on the other strand through hydrogen bonds. A always pair up with T, and G always pairs with C.

A-T: 2 hydrogen bonds
G-C: 3 hydrogen bonds


DNA is a large molecule made up of a huge number of nucleotides, it can store a very large amount of genetic information.
DNA molecule is stable. The sugar-phosphate backbone is joined together by strong covalent bonds, and there are hydrogen bonds between the bases of the two stands of DNA to hold the two strands together, stabilizing the helical structure.
Complementary base pairing enables DNA to replicate (make an exact copy of itself) every time a cell divides, so that genetic information is passed on to new cells.


DNA replication
Extraction of DNA from onion cells

item.title: Genes
item.description:
Series: DNA, chromosomes & genes
DNA - Chromosomes - Genes
A gene is a short length of DNA in a chromosome.

The sequence of bases in the DNA of a gene provides the genetic code that determines the sequence of amino acids in a particular polypeptide, making up proteins for building body parts, enzymes and hormones.
Genes are the basic unit of heredity and determines traits (body characteristics) of an organism by controlling how proteins are made. Traits may be controlled by one or more genes.

Tip The alleles of a gene may differ from each other by only one or a few bases.

Locus is the position of a particular gene on a chromosome.
Allele is a pair of genes that is located on a locus of two homologous chromosomes. The pair controls one characteristic / trait of an organism.

Homozygous refers to having two identical alleles (e.g. , ).
Heterozygous refers to having two different alleles (e.g. ).
Note Allele is the alternative form of the gene. However, it only applies to homologous chromosomes.


Genotype is the genetic composition (combination of alleles) of a characteristic (e.g. , , ). It can also be described with nouns.
Phenotype is the observable feature of a characteristic of an organism.
Dominant allele is an allele that can express its effect whether in a homozygous or heteroeygous condition.
Recessive allele is an allele that can express its effect only in a homozygous condition.

item.title: Comparative anatomy
item.description:
Comparative anatomy studies similarities and differences in physical structures of different organisms.
Based on the theory of evolution, it is expected that different species that evolved from a common ancestor share certain structures similar to the common ancestor.
Homologous structures are anatomically similar structures with similar body position that evolved from a common ancestor.

An example is the pentadactyl limb (five-fingered limb) in mammals.

As the organisms evolve, the homologous structure have adapted to suit their ways of life.

item.title: Comparative embryology
item.description:
Comparative embryology studies similarities and differences in embryos of different species.
Embryos of closely related groups of organisms show common features and resemble each other at early stages of development.

Example: Embryos of all vertebrates have gill pouches, but only fish retain the gill pouches in later stages of development.

item.title: Comparing base sequences of DNA
item.description:
Comparative molecular biology studies similarities and differences between organisms in their DNA, proteins and other biomolecules.

Organisms that share more
similarities in the base sequences of DNA have a closer evolutionary / phylogenetic relationship.
Note
Base sequences of DNA determines the characteristics of organisms.
Mutations affect the amino sequence of protein produced and may result in changes in characteristics.
↪️ See also: Mutations

Certain essential proteins are commonly found in many different organisms, but may be slightly different as a result of mutations.
An organism with fewer numbers of amino acid differences of a protein compared to another organism shows that they are more closely related.
Example: Amino acid sequence of haemoglobin molecule
↪️ See also: Evolutionary tree
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Evolution/Evidence of evolution/Comparative molecular biology.md

item.title: Evolutionary tree
Fossil records
item.description:
Fossils are preserved remains of organisms. They provide information about the morphology of organisms living in the past.
Formation of fossils:

Burial of dead organisms in sediments
Preservation of dead organisms by freezing (in permafrost)
Organisms trapped in resin
↪️ See also: Hydrocarbons

For fossils found in sedimentary rocks:

Comparing layer 1 and 3, layer 1 consists of fossils of organisms that:

Appeared later on Earth
More complex in structure
Uses for determining evolutionary relationships:

By comparing anatomy of organisms
By comparing morphology of organisms
Determining chronological order of existence of organisms
Dating of fossil layers:

Radioisotope dating (carbon-14 dating) can be used to arrange fossils in a chronological sequence.


Fossils show similarities to living species.
This indicate existing life forms arose from pre-existing ones.
Fossils in younger rocks show a greater diversity of fossils.
This indicate that different types of organisms have evolved from a common ancestor.
Fossils in younger rocks are more complex than those in older rocks.
This indicate that organisms evolved from simple to complex forms as simple organisms adapted to become more complex.


There are missing links within the fossil records.
There is a lack of a continuous fossil record of all the intermediate forms between ancient species and modern species.
Fossils can be damaged and incomplete.
Natural processes (e.g. erosion, movement of Earth's crust) may damage fossils, leaving only incomplete fragments.
Some organisms may not be fossilized.
Organisms with soft bodies cannot be fossilized, while some other organisms die in conditions not favourable for fossil formation (e.g. dead bodies in rainforests decay rapidly).
Some fossils are trapped in inaccessible areas.
Fossils can be trapped deep under the sea due to the movement of Earth's crust, making them unavailable for studying.

item.title: Gene flow
item.description:
Gene pool is the total of all alleles in all individuals in a population. In evolution disruptions, the gene pool of a population is changed.

Gene flow is the movement of alleles into or out of a population.

Gene flow introduces new alleles into a gene pool or change allele frequencies, creating less differences between populations.

Genetic drift is the change in allele frequencies as a result of chance. It usually occurs due to natural disasters.

Genetic drift impact small populations greatly, as there is a greater chance that a rare allele will be lost.

See also: Mutations
Mutations can produce totally new alleles for a trait.

Mutations can be neutral, harmful or beneficial. If the new trait is beneficial (helps organisms to survive), they will have a selective advantage and becomes more frequent in the population.

See also: Theory of natural selection
By natural selection, the allele frequency of the favoured form increases within the gene pool.

Better adapted individuals to their environment can survive and reproduce, passing on beneficial genes to the offspring and increases the frequency of beneficial alleles in the population.

Individuals have a choice in who they mate with, the process is not random.

item.title: Theory of natural selection
item.description:
Charles Darwin proposed the theory of natural selection and survival of the fittest.

Individuals compete for limited resources (e.g. food, water and shelter).
Most organisms tend to produce more offspring than needed to replace themselves. However, the number of individuals in a population remains relatively constant.
There are genetic variations among individuals of the same species. (*)
Individuals with variations favourable to their environment have a greater chance to survive and reproduce. ("survival of the fittest")
↪️ See also: Sources of genetic variations
Some genetic variations are inheritable and can be passed on to offspring. (*)
The variations accumulate through many generations. Individuals with favourable characteristics become more frequent in the population. The organism has evolved and become different from its ancestor.
Environmental changes give stresses to organisms.
Selection pressure (the changes in condition) favours a particular form of the species. They have a selective advantage to survive and reproduce more successfully.
↪️ The proportion of the favoured form increases in subsequent generations, while proportion of the less-well-adapted form decreases.
Examples:

Beetles / Peppered moths

Antibiotic-resistant bacteria Note Bacteria have a short generation time and reproduce very quickly. The amount of time required for developing antibiotic resistance is shorter, as each cell division may create mutations from DNA replication or damage by mutagens.
Sickle-cell anaemia > Resistance to malaria
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Evolution/Mechanism of evolution/Theory of natural selection.md

item.title: Theory of evolution
item.description:
Existing life forms arose from pre-existing life forms.
Organisms can be traced back to a common ancestor.
Organisms evolved from simple to complex forms.


Fossil records
Comparative anatomy
Comparative embryology
Comparative molecular biology
↪️ Representing evidences: Evolutionary tree


Theory of natural selection
Evolution disruptions
Speciation

item.title: Types of isolation
item.description:
Speciation depends on two factors: isolation and genetic variation.

Isolation of populations of species
Gene flow is stopped between the isolated groups as they cannot reach or breed with each other.
Mutations and genetic variations
Genetic variations may exist between isolated populations of species. Moreover, the isolated groups may each face different selection pressure (different environmental conditions), different favourable alleles are passed on to offspring in each isolated group.
Accumulation of variations
Variations accumulate in each isolated group over many generations. When the population evolve enough genetic change that it can no longer interbreed to produce fertile offspring, it is considered as a new species.



Geographical isolation
Separation of populations by physical barriers prevent mating.
Behavioural isolation
Organism has a behaviour that is considered unfavourable and chooses not to mate.
Temporal isolation
The mating times of the organisms do not match up.

item.title: Structure of seeds
item.description:
Note
Dicots (e.g. mung bean) have two cotyledons in their seeds.
Monocots (e.g. maize) have only one cotyledon.



It softens the seed coat for the radicle to push out of the seed.
It causes the cotyledons to swell and ruptures the seed coat.
It activates enzymes in the cotyledons to hydrolyse the stored food (e.g. starch) into simpler forms by hydrolysis, which can then be used in respiration to provide energy for growth.
It provides a medium for transporting the soluble food to the radicle and plumule for growth and development.


Higher temperatures enable the enzymes to work more efficiently as germination involves enzyme activity.


Necessary for the cells in the seed to carry out aerobic respiration in order to release energy for growth.




Water enters the seed through the micropyle.
The seed coat is ruptured by the swelling of cotyledons.
Enzymes are activated to break down (hydrolyse) the food reserves into soluble food substances for growth and development.
Food substances involved:
starch → glucose; protein → amino acids; lipids → fatty acids + glycerol
Food substances are then transported by water to the growing points of the radicle and plumule for forming new cells.
The radicle pushes out of the seed, emerging and growing downward to form the root.



The radical grows and develops into the root.
Root hairs develop on the radicle to increase the surface area for absorption of water and minerals.



The plumule grows upwards rapidly to form the shoot.
The hypocotyl (hooked plumble; curved shoot) lifts the cotyledons up above the soil by its rapid growth.
The cotyledons protect the plumule tip on their way out.



The curved shoot beneath the cotyledons straightens once above the soil.
The cotyledons turn green and carry out photosynthesis for a few days.



Green leaves are formed to carry out photosynthesis to make food.
The cotyledons gradually shrink and fall off.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Growth and development/Germination of seeds.md

item.title: Growth and development
item.description:
Growth is the permanent and irreversible increase in the dry mass and size of an organism. In multi cellular organisms, growth involves the following processes:

Cells carry out mitotic cell division, resulting in an increase in cell number.
Cells use food substances to synthesize organic matter or biomass, resulting in an increase in cell size.
Development is the irreversible increase in complexity (form) of an organism. This involves differentiation, where cells specialize into different types for performing different functions, achieving a division of labour among cells. These specialized cells may also group together to form tissues, organs or systems.


Growth parameters
Sigmoid growth curves
Germination of seeds
Growth and development in flowering plants
Growth and development in humans
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Growth and development/Growth and development.md

item.title: Growth pattern of annual plants
item.description:
Dry mass decreases in the early stages of germination. Some of the stored food is used in respiration to provide energy for growth.
Dry mass increases. Green leaves have developed and started to carry out photosynthesis. When the rate of photosynthesis is higher than the rate of respiration, the production of food is faster than the consumption of food. This results in a net gain of organic matter.
The dry mass decreases because the plant disperses seeds and fruits.

Growth is restricted to regions with meristems present, which is a group of undifferentiated cells (meristematic cells) that can undergo mitotic cell division continuously to form new cells.
Main types of meristems:

Apical meristems
They are located at root tips and shoot tips, the cells produced elongate, leading to an increase in the length of the root. Growth as a result of these cells are called primary growth.
Lateral meristems
Located at the periphery of roots and stems, the cells produced increases its girth (thickness). Growth as a result of these cells are called secondary growth



Region of cell division:

Meristematic cells divide actively by mitotic cell division, producing many small, thin-walled cells.
Most newly formed cells are then pushed to the region or elongation for growth.
Region of elongation:

Most of the growth in the root tip occurs here.
The cells from the region of cell division absorb water by osmosis, forming many small vacuoles in the cytoplasm which stretches the thin, elastic cell walls, and the cells elongate.
Region of differentiation:

Cell walls elongate as the cells elongate, becoming rigid when the cells cannot elongate further.
Small vacuoles fuse together to form one large vacuole.
The cells then differentiate into specialized cells to perform different functions.



Cells of the vascular cambium (a type of lateral meristem) divide and differentiate to form secondary phloem and secondary xylem, increasing the thickness of the stems and roots.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Growth and development/Growth and development in flowering plants.md

item.title: Growth patterns in humans
item.description:
Infancy: Rapid growth over the first three years.
Childhood: Growth rate slows down considerably over the next 8 to 10 years.
Adolescence: Another period of active growth at puberty.
Adulthood: No net growth occurs, person reaches maximum size, but cell division still continues to replace damaged or dead cells.
Old age: Growth becomes negative (decrease in weight/height).




Growth rate: Grow rapidly during infancy and early childhood. Slowing down and reaching adult size by the age of eight.
Relative size: Decrease with age (∵ other body parts grow faster than this)


Growth rate: Grow rapidly in the early years of life and during adolescence.
Relative size: Increase with age


Growth rate: Grows at a rate proportional to the whole body.
Relative size: Remains almost constant


Growth rate: Start to grow rapidly at puberty, allowing the body to mature before having children.


Patterns of growth in boys and girls are similar until the age of 10.
From 10 to 13, the growth rate is faster in girls than in boys because puberty begins earlier in girls.
After the age of 13, the growth rate becomes faster in boys than in girls. Increased rate of growth is greater than in girls.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Growth and development/Growth and development in humans.md

item.title: Dry mass
item.description:
Tip Most important details of the parameters are included, namely:
Advantages
Disadvantages
Reason for selection
Info Growth parameters can be represented using sigmoid growth curves.

Dry mass is the mass of an organism after all the water has been removed from its body. It is usually obtained by heating the organisms in an oven slightly above 100°C, until a constant mass is obtained upon repeated weighing.
Advantages:

It provides an accurate measurement of growth, showing the actual amount of organic matter (biomass) in an organism.
Disadvantages:

It is impossible to make a continuous measurement on the same organism as they are killed. A large number of the same type of organisms are needed in order to measure growth over a period of time.
It is time-consuming.
It is impractical to measure the dry mass of large organisms, such as a large tree.

Fresh mass is the total mass of an organism, including its water content.
Advantages:

Measuring fresh mass is fast and convenient.
Repeated measurements can be made on the same organism over a (longer) period of time as it causes no harm to the organisms.
Disadvantages:

Measurement is less accurate and cannot show the actual biomass of the organism as it is easily affected by factors unrelated to growth.
Tip Water content varies with environmental factors (e.g. temperature & water supply) and behaviours of the organism (e.g. drinking, feeding and urination).

Size measures the change in size of the whole organism or of a body structure over a period of time.
Advantages:

Measuring size is fast and convenient.
Repeated measurements can be made on the same organism or structure over a period of time as it causes no harm to the organism or its body structure.
Disadvantages:

Growth in other dimensions may be neglected as the size of an organism or body structure is often measured in one dimension only.

item.title: Sigmoid growth curves
item.description: Sigmoid growth curves are obtained by plotting any growth parameters of an organism against time. It is able to show the growth pattern of the organism.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Growth and development/Sigmoid growth curves.md

item.title: DNA replication
item.description:
A segment of DNA before replication has hydrogen bonds between the bases, holding the two DNA strands together.
The hydrogen bonds between the bases break. The two DNA strands separate. Each DNA strand acts as a template.
Free nucleotides bind to the DNA templates by base pairing. Nucleotides are joined together with the help of enzyme DNA polymerase.
Two identical DNA molecules are formed, each of which consists of one original strand and one newly synthesized strand.

item.title: Stages of protein synthesis
item.description:
Messenger RNA (mRNA) carries the genetic code to the cytoplasm to direct protein synthesis. The synthesis of proteins occurs in two stages.


Transcription - synthesis of mRNA in the nucleus.
Translation - synthesis of polypeptide (protein) in the cytoplasm.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Molecular Genetics/Gene expression and protein synthesis.md

item.title: Genetic code
item.description:
Genetic code is a set of rules that determines the sequence of amino acids in a protein. It is stored in the sequence of nucleotide bases in the DNA of a gene.
It has the following features:

Triplet code
A sequence of three consecutive bases (triplet / codon) on a DNA strand codes for one amino acid.
Degenerate code
There are four types of bases in DNA, different combinations produce 64 triplet codes to specify 20 types of amino acids used to make proteins.
The excessive number of triplet codes means that certain triplet codes code for the same amino acids.
Some triplet codes serve as 'start signals' or 'stop signals' for protein synthesis.
The code is read in a continuous manner. There is no break between codes.
The code is non-overlapping. The adjacent triplet do not share a base.
The code is universal. The same triplet code codes for the same amino acid in all species.

item.title: Sections
item.description:
List article!

This article is a list of related items, and may constitute a stub article. You can help the Knowledge Handbook by expanding it.


Genetic code
Gene expression and protein synthesis
Transcription
Translation
Mutations

item.title: Gene mutations
item.description:
A mutation is a sudden and permanent change in the DNA / gene / chromosome of an organism. Mutations can be classified into two types.

A gene mutation is a change in the base sequence of DNA in a gene.
Types of gene mutations:

Insertion: One or more bases are added to the sequence.
Deletion: One or more bases are lost from the sequence.
Substitution: One or more bases are replaced by others.
Inversion: A sequence of bases is reversed.
Insertion or deletion of bases by a number other than a multiple of three will shift the reading frame. Every codon after the point of mutation will be affected. The protein produced have a different sequence of amino acids and usually cannot function.
↪️ See also: Genetic code (Triplet code)
Substitution or inversion of bases does not cause a reading frame shift, but changes one codon for another. It may cause several effects on the amino acid sequence:

Codon codes for the same amino acid (silent mutation)
Amino acid sequence remains the same.
↪️ See also: Genetic code (Degenerate code)
Codon codes for a different amino acid
Amino acid sequence is changed, the polypeptide may fold into a protein with a different conformation, the protein may not function properly.
Codon changes the amino acid to a stop codon
Translation comes to a stop prematurely. The polypeptide produced will be shorter than normal and probably cannot function.
Tip
Change in a nucleotide in the base sequence may lead to a change in the triplet code. This may change the amino acid sequence of the protein produced.
As a result, the protein produced may fold into a different shape and lose its function.


Sickle-cell anaemia

A chromosome mutation is a change in the structure of chromosomes. It affects large segments of DNA containing many genes.


Deletion: A segment of a chromosome is lost.
Duplication: A segment of a chromosome is inserted to the homologous chromosome.
Inversion: A segment of a chromosome breaks off and rotates through 180° before rejoining.
Translocation: A segment of a chromosome breaks off and becomes attached to a non-homologous chromosome.
↪️ These changes often arise from errors during the crossing over of chromosomes in meiosis.

Non-disjunction is when the members of a pair of homologous chromosomes fail to separate during meiosis I, and they end up in the same gamete. Alternatively, sister chromatids may fail to separate during meiosis II.
The above results in gametes with an abnormal number of chromosomes (e.g. extra or missing chromosome).
Note
Mitosis passes on the mutation to all the cells derived from the zygote.
Zygotes lacking an entire chromosome rarely survive. Zygotes with an extra chromosome may survive and develop, but usually develops a syndrome of disorders.


Down syndrome


Spontaneous mutations: Occur naturally and randomly with no outside causes.
Induced mutations: Exposure to mutagens (agents that can increase the rate of mutations).

Examples of mutagens ⤴️
Explanations for mutations:

Some mutagens affect DNA by changing the structure of the bases and causes them to pair with the wrong base.
Some mutagens have structures that resemble nucleotides, so they can be incorporated into the DNA molecule and cause errors in DNA replication.
Ultraviolet (UV) radiation changes the structure of DNA and interfere with DNA replication. Ionizing radiation (e.g. X-rays and gamma rays) can damage DNA molecules directly, or they can ionize other molecules (e.g. water) to form free radicals. Free radicals are highly reactive, and can cause DNA damage and give rise to mutations.


Occurring in somatic cells:

Not passed on to the offspring.
Only daughter cells derived from the mutated cells are affected.
Occurring in gametes or gamete-producing cells:

Passed on to the offspring.
Mutated DNA occurs in every cell of the offspring.


Gene mutation can result in a change in the conformation and function of the protein. Many genetic disorders are caused by improper function of proteins.
Mutations that result in a significant loss of genetic material (e.g. deletion of a segment of a chromosome) are most likely lethal.

The gene mutation may cause no change in the phenotype:

If the mutation occurs in a non-coding region of the DNA (it does not code for proteins).
If the mutation is a silent mutation, the triplet codes still code for the same amino acids, the sequence of amino acids is unchanged.
If the change of amino acids do not change the shape of the protein sufficiently, it can still function properly.
If the mutated allele is recessive to the normal allele and is not expressed in the heterozygous solution.
Note
The majority of mutations are neutral.
If a mutation does cause a change in the phenotype, but the change gives no particular advantage or disadvantage to the organisms, then the effect is also regarded as neutral.

Mutations provide a source of genetic variations, and may give rise to new characteristics that help organisms become better adapted to a particular environment.
Well-adapted organisms have a better chance to survive and reproduce, they pass on their genes to the next generation. This is natural selection and the mechanism of evolution.

item.title: Transcription
item.description:
Transcription is the synthesis of mRNA using part of the nucleus DNA as a template.


Template strand: The DNA strand to be transcribed.
Coding strand: The DNA strand that is not transcribed, it is identical to the mRNA.


Unwinding of the double helix of DNA
The RNA polymerase binds to a region of the DNA near the beginning of the gene.
The hydrogen bonds between the nitrogenous bases of the two DNA strands of the double helix breaks.
A section of the DNA double helix unwinds.
Pairing of free and complementary RNA nucleotides
The RNA polymerase makes use of one DNA strand as a template (the template strand).
Exposed nitrogenous bases of the DNA attract and form hydrogen bonds with their complementary and free RNA nucleotides in the presence of RNA polymerase. (see complementary base pairing)
The RNA polymerase moves along the template strand. The process is repeated until it reaches the end of the gene. A long messenger RNA is formed.
Note The base sequence of mRNA is identical to the coding strand and complementary to the template strand, except it has the base uracil (U) instead of thymine (T).

Rewinding of DNA strands
The RNA polymerase separates from the DNA and releases the mRNA.
The mRNA produced then leaves the nucleus through nuclear pores and enters the cytoplasm. It then rests on a ribosome (free or ER-bounded) for translation.
The DNA rewinds to re-form a double helix.

item.title: Role of transfer RNA
item.description:
Translation leads to the synthesis of a polypeptide (protein), with the amino acid sequence determined by the series of codons on the mRNA. This process occurs at ribosomes in the cytoplasm.
Note Production of proteins occurs in the cytoplasm.

Transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules are carriers of amino acids, bringing specific amino acids to the ribosomes. There are different tRNA molecules in the cytoplasm.

At one end of the tRNA molecule is a binding site for a specific amino acid.
At the other end of the tRNA molecule is a sequence of three unpaired bases (anticodon - complementary to codons of mRNA). It can pair with complementary mRNA codon.
Note tRNA is a single-stranded molecule twisted into the shape of a clover leaf. It is made in the nucleus through transcription and then moves out to the cytoplasm.
//TODO images

Pre-context: Genetic code
↪️ Some triplet codes serve as 'start signal' or 'stop signals' for protein synthesis.
(Start: AUG; End: UAA / UAG / UGA)

First, molecule of mRNA binds to a ribosome. tRNA in the cytoplasm complementary to the codons binds to the start codon on the mRNA, carrying amino acid.
Then, another tRNA carrying another amino acid binds to the next codon with its complementary anticodon. The amino acids are joined together by peptide bonds.
The process repeats, the ribosome moving one codon further along the mRNA. The proceeding tRNAs will be released to pick up another amino acid.
The ribosome continue to move until it reaches a stop codon on the mRNA. The mRNA and the polypeptide will be released, translation is complete.
Note
Ribosomes provides two sites (codons) for amino acids. Therefore, a tRNA will separate from the mRNA when another codon is to be translated and there are not enough sites for binding tRNA.
There is no corresponding tRNA for the stop codon.
//TODO images

The polypeptide produced by translation then coils and folds to form a protein.

Some proteins consists of more than one polypeptide.
The amino acid sequence of each polypeptide determines the three-dimensional structure (conformation) of the protein molecule.
Different fates of proteins:

Proteins made on free ribosomes in the cytoplasm stay in the cell and will be used within it (e.g. enzymes).
Proteins made on ribosomes attach to the rough ER are either embedded in the cell membrane (e.g. channel proteins, carrier proteins and receptor proteins) or exported out of the cell (e.g. digestive enzymes, hormones and antibodies).

item.title: Condoms
item.description:
Condoms trap semen in the end of the condom to prevent sperms from entering the vagina. Some condoms are coated with spermicide, which is a chemical that kills sperms. They have a failure rate of about 15%, as they may break and leak if not used correctly.
There exists male condoms that is rolled over the erect penis before intercourse, and female condoms that are put into the vagina before intercourse to catch semen.
Condoms can also protect against sexually transmitted diseases (e.g. gonorrhoea and AIDS) and urinary tract infections, as the use of condoms can reduce the contact of body fluids (e.g. semen and vaginal secretions) from infected persons.


Diaphragms are dome-shaped cap with an elastic rim that is inserted into the vagina before intercourse. It fits over the cervix so that the sperms cannot enter the uterus, and has a failure rate of about 10%.
After intercourse, it must be left in place for six to eight hours. It is usually used together with spermicide.

item.title: Contraceptive methods
item.description:
Birth control is achieved by contraception, i.e. the prevention of pregnancy.


Preventing ovulation (maturation of follicle)
Preventing sperms from reaching an ovum
Preventing the implantation of an embryo


Contraceptive pills


Rhythm method
Barrier methods
Surgical methods (sterilization)


Intrauterine devices (IUD)

item.title: Contraceptive pills
item.description:
Contraceptive pills are taken to prevent ovulation as a contraceptive method. It has a failure rate of around 5%.

Composition: Synthetic female sex hormones
To maintain a high level of hormones in blood, which will prevent follicles from developing in the ovaries and no ovulation occurs.
Usage: Taking one pill every say for the first 21 days of the menstrual cycle, then stop taking the pills or take hormone-free pills for seven days.
Hormone-free period allows the uterine lining to be shed and menstruation occurs.
Side effects: nausea, weight gain, headache and high blood pressure

item.title: Intrauterine devices
item.description:
Intrauterine devices (IUD) are small T-shaped structure made of plastic and copper in order to prevent the implantation of an embryo as a contraceptive method. It is placed in the uterus by a doctor to prevent embryos from implanting in the uterine lining. It can usually be used for five to ten years and can be removed by a doctor.

The device works by causing slight inflammation to prevent implantation of the embryo. However, the device may irritate the uterine lining, causing heavy menstruation and painful cramps.

item.title: Rhythm method
item.description:
Rhythm method is a contraceptive method that prevents sperms from reaching an ovum. It has a failure rate of around 25%.
The method is carried out by avoiding sexual intercourse five days before and two days after ovulation during the fertile period. This ensures that sperms and ovum will have no chance of meeting each other.
Note An ovum can survive for 12 to 24 hours after being release, while some sperms can survive for five days.
However, the rhythm method has a high failure rate, as menstrual cycles are not always regular and it is difficult to predict the time of ovulation.


Keeping record of the time of menstruation
Ovulation usually occurs 14 days before the next menstruation.
Measuring body temperature every morning
Ovulation causes a sudden rise in body temperature.

Observing vaginal secretions every day
Mucus secretions from the cervix become more watery around the time of ovulation.

item.title: Vasectomy (male sterilization)
item.description:
Note
Surgical operations for the purposes of sterilization is often irreversible.
Secondary characteristics are not affected as sex hormones are transported by blood to target organs, where they carry out their functions.



Both sperm ducts are tied and cut.
Testes can still make sperms and male sex hormones, and the man can still ejaculate.
However, there are no sperms in his semen as sperms cannot pass through the sperm ducts.



Both oviducts are tied and cut.
Oviducts are blocked so that the ova cannot pass through and meet the sperms.
Menstruation still occur after the surgery as the ovaries can still produce female sex hormones.

item.title: Hormones
item.description:
Pre-context: Menstrual cycle





Tip The first day of menstruation is counted as day 1 in the menstrual cycle.

Menstruation occurs, a process which discharges the shed uterine lining together with blood through the vagina. This lasts about five days.
Pituitary gland secretes more FSH. FSH stimulates follicle development in the ovary.
Developing follicle secretes oestrogen.
Uterine lining thickens.
Secretion of FSH and LH is inhibited through negative feedback, preventing the development of other follicles and ensures only one ovum is released in each menstrual cycle.


Level of oestrogen continues to rise and peaks just before ovulation.
The pituitary gland is stimulated to secrete more FSH ad LH., stimulating ovulation to occur, where a mature follicle ruptures and releases an ovum into the oviduct.


A high LH level causes the ruptured follicle to develop into a yellow body (corpus luteum), which secretes oestrogen and progesterone. This also cause a rise in body temperature just after ovulation.
Progesterone together with oestrogen maintains the thickness of the uterine lining and stimulates blood vessel development in the lining in preparation for the implantation of an embryo.
A high oestrogen and progesterone level inhibit the secretion of FSH and LH from the pituitary gland, preventing the development of another follicle or further ovulation within the same menstrual cycle.
A low LH level causes the yellow body to degenerate, leading to low levels of oestrogen and progesterone in the blood. The uterine lining cannot maintain its thickness and breaks down by menstruation.
Low levels of oestrogen and progesterone no longer inhibit the pituitary gland, FSH secretion is increases, a new cycle begins.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Reproduction/Humans/Hormonal control/Hormonal control of menstrual cycle.md

item.title: Birth process
item.description:
A few weeks before birth, the fetus changes its position so that its head is downwards just above the cervix.
At the start of child birth, muscles of the uterus contract regularly when labour begins, with the contractions gradually becoming more frequent and powerful.


Dilation of the cervix

The cervix dilates to let the head of the fetus pass through.
The amnion breaks and amniotic fluid flows out through the vagina, which helps lubricate the vagina for the passage of the fetus.
Expulsion of the fetus

Muscles of the uterus and the abdominal muscles contract strongly, pushing the fetus head-first through the cervix and vagina (birth canal).
The baby takes its first breath after coming out of the internal environment. The umbilical cord is clamped and cut, and the remains of the cord on the baby’s body dries up and falls off a few days later, forming a scar called the navel.
Expulsion of the placenta

Continued contractions of the uterus cause the placenta to detach from the uterine lining, passing out through the vagina eventually.



Increases the survival chance of the young
Promote healthy development


During pregnancy, mammary glands in mother's breasts enlarge and become able to produce milk.
Babies are born with the instinct to suck. When the baby sucks the nipples, the breasts are stimulated to produce and release milk in a process called lactation.
Benefits of breast-feeding for babies:

Breast milk contains the right amounts of all essential nutrients for the baby.
Proteins in breast milk is easy for babies to digest and absorb.
Breast milk contains enzymes (e.g. amylase, lipase, protease) to help digest food. This is because babies are born with an immature pancreas, so they get most of this essential digestive enzyme through breast milk.
Breast milk contains antibodies that help protect babies against some infectious diseases (e.g. pneumonia, ear infections, etc).
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Reproduction/Humans/Birth process and parental care.md

item.title: Implantation
item.description:
A zygote divides by repeated mitotic cell division during when it travels along the oviduct, forming an embryo.
Warning The woman is not considered pregnant before the embryo then implants into the uterine lining.

The embryo reaches the uterus around seven days after fertilization, containing 200 to 300 cells. It embeds itself in the uterine lining in a process called implantation. This marks the start of pregnancy.


As the embryo continues to develop in the uterus, some cells of the embryo form a membrane called the amnion.
The amniotic cavity between the amnion and embryo is also filled with amniotic fluid. It has the following functions:

Act as a shock-absorber, protecting the embryo from mechanical injury.
Prevents the embryo from drying out (desiccation).
Provides a stable environment (e.g constant temperature, pH, etc.) for the embryo.
Allows the embryo some freedom of movement.
Helps lubricate the birth canal during childbirth.


The placenta is composed of tissues from both the mother and the embryo, and has villi containing the embryo's capillaries that grow into blood spaces in the uterine lining and are bathed in the maternal blood after implantation, allowing for the exchange of materials between the embryo and the mother without mixing their blood.
Benefits of the adaptation:

It prevents the clumping of embryo's blood and maternal blood when their blood groups are incompatible.
It prevents the high blood pressure of maternal blood from damaging the embryo's delicate blood vessels.
It prevents large pathogens and toxins in the maternal blood from entering the embryo's blood.
The placenta also secretes hormones (oestrogen & progestrone) to help maintain the uterine lining throughout pregnancy, so menstruation will not occur and the embryo can develop in a stable environment.

Materials that diffuse from maternal blood into embryo's blood:

Nutrients (e.g. glucose, amino acids, minerals and vitamins)
Oxygen
Antibodies
Materials produced by the embryo and diffuses into the maternal blood:

Metabolic wastes (e.g. urea and carbon dioxide)

The embryo is connected to the placenta by the umbilical cord, which contains:

An umbilical vein, carrying oxygenated blood and nutrients.
Two umbilical arteries, carrying deoxygenated blood and waste products.


Presence of numerous villi
This provides a large surface area for the exchange of materials.
Embryo's blood is close to the maternal blood
This reduces the distance for diffusion of materials.
Richly supplied with blood vessels
This allows an efficient transport of materials away from the placenta by maintaining a steep concentration gradient of materials between the embryo's blood and the maternal blood.

Identical twins are genetically identical twins that look alike and are of the same sex. They are formed from one zygote which divides into two separate cells and each cell grows into an embryo.
Fraternal twins are genetically different twins and can be of the same sex or different sexes. They are formed from two ova are released from the ovaries and are fertilized independently by two sperms.

The gestation period refers to the period from fertilization to birth, which takes about 38 weeks in humans until the fetus is ready to be born.
The embryo becomes a fetus eight weeks after fertilization, with all major organs formed. It contains to grow and develop in the mother's uterus till birth.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Reproduction/Humans/Development of embryo and fetus.md

item.title: Structures
item.description:
'

The ovary in a female produces ova (female gametes) and female sex hormones.
The oviducts are thin-walled muscular tubes with funnel-shaped opening near the ovary to receive the ovum. Its inner wall is lined with ciliated epithelium, the beating action of the cilia and wave-like muscular contractions of the oviduct move the ovum along the tube. Fertilization usually occurs in the oviducts.

The uterus is a thick-walled muscular organ with soft, smooth inner lining called the uterine lining. The embryo attaches to the uterine lining during pregnancy. During pregnancy, the uterus can expand to accommodate the fetus, providing it with protection and a stable environment to develop.
The cervix is a ring of muscle located at the lower end of the uterus.

The vagina is a muscular but elastic tube that receives the penis during sexual intercourse. It also serves as the birth canal through which the baby is born.



Ova are spherical cells about 0.1 mm in diameter.

The cell membrane is covered by a protective jelly coat.
The cytoplasm contains food reserves (yolk) which nourish the developing embryo for about two weeks after fertilization. This makes the ovum much larger than the sperm.
The nucleus is large and contains a haploid number of chromosomes.


Thousands of potential ova are already present in a baby girl before birth, and remain immature until puberty. Each immature ovum is surrounded by follicle cells, forming a follicle.
Starting from puberty, female sex hormones are secreted to stimulate follicles and immature ova within them to develop. One mature ovum is released from one of the ovaries each month, about 500 ova would become mature and be released during the lifetime of a female.
Tip Sometime, an ovary releases more than one egg during the same menstrual cycle. This is referred to as hyperovulation. If they are both fertilized by a sperm, it can lead to fraternal twins.

item.title: Structures
item.description:
The testes produces sperms (male gametes) and male sex hormones (e.g. testosterone).
The scrotum hangs outside the abdominal cavity in order to keep the temperature inside slightly lower than the body temperature (by ~2°C), which is essential for sperms to develop properly in the testes.

The epididymis is a tightly coiled duct lying outside the testes. It stores sperms temporarily and allows sperms to become mature and motile.
The sperm ducts, or vas deferens, transfer sperms from the epididymis to the urethra during ejaculation.
The urethra carriers semen and urine out of the body.

The accessory glands are a series of glands that secretes seminal fluid, which includes the seminal vesicles, prostate gland and Cowper's glands. Seminal fluid mixes with sperms during ejaculation to form semen.
The functions of seminal fluid are listed below:

It contains nutrients (e.g. sugars; fructose) which nourish the sperms.
It provides a liquid medium through which sperms can swim.
It neutralizes the acidic secretions of the female's vagina.

The penis contains spongy erectile tissues and many blood vessels. It becomes erect when sexually stimulated so that it can be inserted into the vagina for sexual intercourse.
Note The penis is similar in function to the pollen tube in flowering plants as they both bring the male gametes closer to the female gametes.



Sperms are tadpole shaped male gametes about 0.06 mm in length. It comprises of three distinct regions:

The head, which has a nucleus with a haploid number of chromosomes.
In front of the nucleus is a cap-like structure called the acrosome, it contains enzymes that help the sperm penetrate an ovum.
The midpiece is packed with numerous mitochondria to carry out aerobic respiration to supply energy for the movements of the tail.
The tail brings about movements to propel the sperm forward.


Starting from puberty, male sex hormones stimulate the cells in the walls of seminiferous tubules to produce sperms through meiotic cell division. The newly formed sperms are passed into the epididymis, where they are stored temporarily, and become mature and motile.
Sperm production occurs continuously, producing more than 100 million sperms daily well into old age.

item.title: Menstruation (Day 1 - 5)
item.description:
Thickened uterine lining breaks down when fertilization does not occur.
Menstrual blood (including blood, mucus, uterine tissues, unfertilized ovum) is passed out of the body through the vagina.


Secretion of oestrogen (a type of female sex hormone)
The follicle in the ovary develops and secretes oestrogen, which causes the uterine lining to repair and thicken to prepare for implantation of the embryo.
The uterine lining is also richly supplied with blood vessels to prepare for supplying the embryo with oxygen and nutrients.


The mature follicle ruptures and releases an ovum into the oviduct.
The beating action of cilia lining the oviduct creates a current to suck the ovum into the oviducts.


The uterine lining further thickens and is ready for the implantation of the embryo.
The ruptured follicle becomes the yellow body. It later degenerates if the released ovum is not fertilized.
If fertilization occurs and the woman becomes pregnant, the uterine lining does not break down. Menstruation will occur only after the birth of the baby.
Note
Menarche refers to a woman's first menstruation, which usually occurs at the age of about 11.
Menopause occurs when a woman reaches 45 to 55 years of age. As a woman's ovary contain only a set number of follicles, her ovaries will stop releasing ova and menstruation will no longer occur.


Hormonal control of menstrual cycle

item.title: Sexual intercourse
item.description:
The male is sexually stimulated (arousal).
More blood is pumped into his penis (dilation of blood vessels) and the outflow of blood is reduced.
Erectile tissues inside the penis are filled with blood. Penis becomes hard and rigid.
Now, it can be inserted into the vagina of a female for sexual intercourse.
Eventually, muscular contractions of the epididymis, sperm ducts and urethra expel semen out of the penis. The discharge of semen through the penis is called ejaculation.


Note Only a few hundred sperms will reach the oviducts. This is because:
Some sperms are trapped by mucus in the vagina.
Some sperms are killed by the acidic secretion of the vagina.
Some sperms may be defective and immotile.


Sperms will try to penetrate an ovum.
Enzymes are released from their acrosomes to breakdown the jelly coat of the ovum.
Once the head of a sperm enters the ovum, the jelly coat changes to prevent other sperms from entering.
Finally, the nucleus of the sperm fuses with the nucleus of the ovum, forming a zygote.

item.title: Artificial vegetative propagation
item.description:
Methods: Cutting, grafting, layering

Cutting: A short length of stem, root or a leaf from the parent plant (e.g. African Violet, Hong Kong Orchid Tree) is cut and cultivated into a new plant.
Advantages:

Can be used to propagate plant varieties quickly, especially those with desirable or rare characteristics.
Daughter plants obtained will have consistent quality, because they are genetically identical to the parent plant.

item.title: Examples of the methods for dispersal
item.description:
In the dispersal of seeds and fruits, external agents (e.g. animals, wind, water) are often required.
This process is important because it avoids overcrowding, while also allowing the plant species to colonize new areas.



Use of brightly coloured, fleshy and scented fruits (e.g. tomatoes)
Attract animals to feed on, then discarding or swallowing the seeds.
Swallowed seeds
Seeds are usually small and have hard seed coats to withstand the actions of digestive enzymes. By the time they are expelled in animals' faeces, the seed coats are softened.
Hooks or spines
These structures allow the fruit to stick to the fur of animals.
(e.g. burdock fruits can cling to the fur of dogs)

Some plants produce fruits that are very light, and has structures to act as 'parachutes' or 'wings' to float or glide in the wind. They can be dispersed by wind.
(e.g. dandelion, sugar maple)
This method of dispersal allows them to transport seeds or fruits over long distances.

Fruits of some freshwater and coastal plants depend on water for dispersal.
For example, coconut fruit has air spaces that allow it to float and be dispersed by water currents.

Seeds of pea pods are distributed by this method:

When pea pods are mature, their fruit walls dry up and shrink.
This gradually builds up pressure within the pods, eventually causing the pods to 'explode', scattering the seeds away.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Reproduction/Plants/Dispersal of seeds and fruits.md

item.title: Stem tubers
item.description:
See also: Mechanisms of vegetative propagation

Swollen storage organ formed at the tip of an underground stem.
'Eye' on the surface: Contains a bud and scar of a scale leaf.
The old tuber shrinks and dries up after the stem tuber develops aerial roots.
Examples: potato, Chinese yam



Short, vertical underground stem with layers of fleshy scale leaves.
Scale leaves contain food reserves. It also encloses and protects the buds.
Examples: onion, tulip, daffodil



Short, vertical underground stem swollen with food reserves.
Usually covered by brown, protective scale leaves with no fleshy scale leaves.
Examples: Gladiolus, Crocus, water chestnuts



Horizontal underground stem swollen with food reserves.
Examples: Ginger, Iris, lotus

item.title: Fertilization in flowering plants
item.description:
When a pollen grain reaches a stigma, it is stimulated by the sugary solution on the stigma to develop a pollen tube.
The pollen tube secretes enzymes to digest tissues of the style and the ovary, bringing the male gamete towards the ovule through the micropyle.
The male gamete is released into the ovule and fuses with the female gamete, forming a zygote.



Ovary: Swells and develops into a fruit.
Ovary wall: Develops into the fruit wall.
Ovule (containing the zygote): Develops into the seed containing the embryo.
Integuments: Develops into the seed coat.
Sepals, petals, stamens, stigma, style: Wither and fall off

item.title: Mechanisms of vegetative propagation
item.description:
Example with stem tubers ⤴

Under adverse conditions (e.g. cold winder), the aerial part of the plant dies, the storage organ remains dormant.
Under favourable conditions, a bud grows and develops a new shoot and adventitious roots using the food reserves in the storage organ.
Green leaves carry out photosynthesis and passes down some of the food to form new storage organs.

item.title: Self-pollination & Cross-pollination
item.description:
Key:
→ Blue: Cross-pollination
→ Pink: Self-pollination

Self-pollination occurs when pollen grains are transferred from the anther to the stigma of the same flower, or another flower of the same plant.

This can increase the chances of fertilization when a plant species is rare or its members are separated by long distances.
However, it results in inbreeding and less genetic variation.
Cross-pollination occurs when pollen grains are transferred from the anther of one plant to the stigma of a flower in another plant of the same species.

This results in more genetic variations among the offspring, as the gametes from two different parents are brought together.
Some offspring may have characteristics that enable them to survive environmental changes better, increasing the chance of survival of the species.

Insect-pollinated flowers have their pollen grains pollinated by insects.

Wind-pollinated flowers have their pollen grains pollinated by wind.

item.title: Asexual reproduction
item.description:
Summary
Some flowering plants can carry out asexual reproduction under favourable conditions. The plants can produce a large number of offspring in a short period of time.
Flowering plants usually carry out sexual reproduction under unfavourable conditions. The plants can produce offspring with more genetic variations. Some offspring may be able to survive better in changed conditions, this increases the chance of survival for the species.

Main article: Asexual reproduction


Fast — one parent plant can produce a large number of offspring under favourable conditions.
Desirable characteristics of the parent are retained in the offspring.
Large amounts of food reserves are available in storage organs for the growth of the offspring.


All offspring are identical and there is no genetic variation.
The species is less able to adapt to environmental changes.
Overcrowding may occur because all offspring are near to the parent plant.
This lead to intense competition for resources.
The chance for disease transmission from parent plants to offspring is higher.

*Main article: Sexual reproduction


Genetic variation exists among offspring. This allows the species to adapt to environmental changes.
Fruits and seeds are usually dispersed away from the parent plants. This can prevent overcrowding and reduce competition for resources.
The chance of disease transmission from parent plants to offspring is lower.


Slower — two parents are involved and external agents are required.
Large amounts of resources and energy are required in producing flowers and fruits, and many seeds are wasted if conditions for germination are poor.
Seeds only contain limited food reserves to support growth of offspring.
item.guid: Biology/Reproduction & Genetics/Reproduction/Plants/Significance of asexual and sexual reproduction in flowering plants.md

item.title: Sepals, petals & nectaries
item.description:
Sepals are the outermost ring of a flower. It makes up the calyx. They are leaf-like structures and are usually green, protecting the flower bud.
Petals are the second ring of a flower. It makes up the corolla. In many flowers, it is brightly coloured and scented to attract insects. There are insects guides (lines or marks) to direct insects to the nectaries.
Nectaries are glands that produce nectar, a sugary liquid insects feed on.

Stamens are the male reproductive parts. Each stamen has a filament (a thin stalk) that supports an anther at its tip.
An anther consists of four pollen sacs where meiotic cell division occurs to produce pollen grains, containing the male gametes. When the anther is ripe, the pollen sacs split open, exposing their pollen grains.
Warning Pollen grains are not the male gametes, they act as structures that facilitates the male gametes to reach the female gametes.


Carpels are the female reproductive parts.

The stigma is the tip of a carpel that receives pollen grains. A mature stigma may secrete a sugary solution to pick up pollen.
The style is a stalk that connects the stigma to the ovary.
The ovary encloses one or more ovules that contain the female gametes of ova.
The ovule is connected to the inner wall of the ovary by a short stalk called funicle, and is surrounded by integuments (a protective layer). There are tiny holes in the integuments called micropyle.
Info In bisexual flowers, there exists both stamens and carpels.
Flowers containing either stamens or carpels only are called unisexual flowers.

item.title: Examples
item.description:
Asexual reproduction is the production of offspring from one single parent without the fusion of gametes. It involves mitotic cell division only, all offspring have identical genetic make-up as the parent.


Binary fission is commonly carried out in prokaryotes (e.g. bacteria) and certain unicellular eukaryotes (e.g. Amoeba & Paramecium).

Vegetative propagation occurs in flowering plants where a new plant develops from the vegetative parts (e.g. stems, roots or leaves) of the parent plant through fragmentation and regeneration.
Vegetative parts of plants form storage organs underground, swollen with food reserves (usually starch), for vegetative propagation.
Sections:

Mechanisms
Examples
Artificial vegetative propagation


Significance of asexual and sexual reproduction in flowering plants
Fungi

item.title: Sections
item.description:
Sexual reproduction is the production of offspring through the fusion of gametes (fertilization). These gametes are usually derived from two parents of different sexes and produced by meiotic cell division.
Upon fertilization, a zygote is formed. It then undergoes mitotic cell division into an offspring.


Sexual reproduction in flowering plants
Sexual reproduction in humans

item.title: Choice of suitable acid-base indicator
item.description:
Titration curves are used for describing the acid-base reaction process.
Example: Addition of into


Equivalence point is the moment when the acid and base completely react.
Details of indicators:

The colour of the indicator can indicate the environment of the reaction mixture.
End point is the moment when the indicator change its colour (to a neutral colour).
Limitation / Source of error: The end point is assumed to be the equivalence point.

The end point and the equivalence point usually occur at slightly different times during a titration.

Titration curve of different experiments:

Principle for choosing an indicator:

The indicator needs to change its colour within the pH range of the vertical part of the titration curve.
The end point of the indicator needs to be within the pH range of theequivalence point.
Conclusion:

Strong acid only: Methyl orange
Strong alkali only: Phenolphthalein
Strong acid and alkali: Methyl orange or phenolphthalein
Weak acid and alkali: No suitable indicator
↪️ Use a method in pH scale, acidity and alkalinity > Determining pH value
Reason for avoiding litmus solution:

It does not give a sharp colour colour change at the end point.
Litmus solution changes from red through purple to blue.

item.title: Cleaning of apparatus
item.description:
Procedure:

Wash / rinse all of them with distilled water.
Only wash the burette and the pipette with the solution to be held, but not the conical flask.
Reason for cleaning:

Impurities or dirt may be present in the apparatus.
It may affect the concentration of the solutions under testing.
Reason for rinsing the burette / pipette again with the solution:

To prevent the dilution of solution in the burette / pipette.
Reason: The burette / pipette is used for holding a fixed concentration of a species.
Reason for rinsing the conical flask with only distilled water:

To prevent the addition of moles of substances into the conical flask.
Reason: The conical flask is used for holding a fixed mole of a species, while the concentration may vary.

An acid ionizes in water to give hydrogen as the only cation.

item.title: Reactions
item.description:
Neutralization occurs when the right amounts of an acid and a base is mixed to react completely to produce a salt and water only.


Equations:



Ionic equation:
Note and are spectator ions. They do not take part in the reaction.

Equations:



Ionic equations:



Note Any insoluble bases needs to be written in an ionic equation, because they are not solutions with mobile ions.

Neutralization is an exothermic reaction.
For a neutralization reaction involving strong acids and alkalis, the same reaction occurs:


The heat released is the same () even when the reactants are different.
However, the heat change of neutralization involving weak acid or weak alkali will be different because part of the energy is used for the ionization of weak acid / weak alkali.
Note The same mole of strong and weak acid requires the same mole of alkali to carry out complete neutralization. The ionization process for weak acid / weak alkali is reversible, a decrease in during reaction causes the equilibrium position to shift to the product side, and the neutralization reaction goes to completion.

Consider the neutralization reaction:

Explaining change in temperature:


The temperature increases as the neutralization between and is exothermic.
The temperature reaches the maximum as the neutralization has just completed. (equivalence point)
The temperature decreases as the addition of excess cools down the reaction mixture.
Explaining change in electrical conductivity:


The electrical conductivity decreases as the concentration of mobile ions decreases during neutralization.
The electrical conductivity reaches the minimum as the neutralization has just completed. (equivalence point)
The electrical conductivity increases as the addition of excess increases the concentration of mobile ions in the reaction mixture.
