Insoluble salts are prepared by mixing water-soluble reactants. As the salt is insoluble, it will be precipitated out. The precipitate (salt) is obtained by filtration.
Procedure (to prepare ):

Mix and solution. Precipitation of occurs.
Filter the precipitate (salt) from the solution.
Wash the precipitate with small amounts of cold distilled water to remove any soluble impurities.
Dry the precipitate using filter paper / heating in oven / desiccator.
Preparation of :
Warning For preparation of , do not use reactants that will result in the formation of a barrier for the reactants that prevent further reaction.
Optimal reaction route:

Add excess to dilute . Filter to remove unreacted .
Add the filtrate to excess dilute to form powder.
Filter to obtain powder, wash with a small amount of cold distilled water and dry with filter paper / desiccator / heat in oven.

Soluble salts that are not formed by , , ions are prepared by reaction of water-insoluble base / alkali / metal carbonate with acid to give the soluble salts. The salt is then separated by crystallization.
↪️ See also: HKDSE 2023 Paper 1B Q9
Note
The reactants cannot both be solutions. One should be an insoluble base / metal / carbonate and one should be an acid.
In a laboratory setting, dilute acids / alkalis should be used for safety.
Procedure (to prepare ):

Add excess into dilute .
Heat can be provided to increase the rate of reaction.
Note
Addition of excess ensures all has reacted (so that pure will be produced / no soluble impurities) (/ is the limiting reagent).
If is in excess, unreacted will contaminate obtained. will be impure.

Filter to remove excess .
The filtrate collected will be solution. (first filtration)
Heat the solution until it becomes saturated.
Allow the heated saturated solution to cool down in order to allow the gradual formation of crystals / crystallization.
Filter to obtain the solid of crystal as residue. (second filtration)
Wash the crystals with a small amount of cold distilled water to remove any water-soluble impurities on the crystal surface.
Dry the crystals using filter paper to obtain (hydrated; blue in colour).
Dry the crystal using oven to obtain (anhydrous; white in colour).


Soluble salts that are formed by , , ions are prepared by reaction of acids and alkalis through titration.
Reason for titration:

The compounds of , , ions are soluble in water.
It is not possible to determine when the complete neutralization of an acid and alkali occurs.
Excess reactant will be added and contaminate the salt formed.
Procedure (to prepare ):


Place of dilute solution into a conical flask.
Add a few drops of methyl orange / phenolphthalein to the flask.
Place dilute solution in a burette.
Run the acid from the burette until the the colour of the indicator changes from yellow to orange / pink to very pale pink.
Record the volume of acid needed for complete neutralization (end-point).
Repeat the experiment without the addition of the indicator.
Mix the same volumes of acid and alkali together in a clean conical flask without indicator added.
Heat the reaction mixture until it is saturated.
Cool the reaction mixture to allow the gradual formation of crystals / crystallization.
Filter to obtain the crystal.
Wash the crystals with a small amount of cold distilled water to remove any water-soluble impurities.
Dry the crystal with filter paper.

item.title: Strength of acid and alkali
item.description:
The strength of acid and alkali depends on the extent of ionization / dissociation of the acid and alkali.
For acids:

A strong acid completely ionizes in water to give hydrogen ion as the only cation. (e.g. / / )
A weak acid partially ionizes in water to give hydrogen ion as the only cation. (e.g. / organic acids)
For alkalis:

A strong alkali completely ionizes / dissociates in water to give hydroxide ion as the only anion. (e.g. / )
A weak alkali partially ionizes / dissociates in water to give hydroxide ion as the only anion. (e.g. / amines)
Note Mobile molecules exist in the solutions of weak acids / alkalis.

The concentration of acid or alkali depends on the amount of acid or alkali per unit volume of the solution.
Changing concentration:

Change the mole of the solute
Change the volume of the solution



There is no relationship between the concentration and strength of an acid or alkali.

item.title: Principles
item.description:
Colorimetry
Colorimetry is used for determining the concentration of a coloured substance with a colorimeter.



Visible light of suitable wavelengths are passed through the coloured sample solution.
The sample solution absorbs part of the light and transmits the remaining part of the light. The more concentrated the coloured sample solution, the larger amount of light it absorbs.
The fraction of light transmitted (light transmittance) is then detected, and the absorbance is shown in a meter.
By measuring the light absorbance of the sample solution, the value can be used to find the concentration of the solution by using a calibration curve.
Solution for low colour intensity In order to measure absorbance of solutions with low colour intensity, reagents that can increase the colour intensity can be added. For example:



A colour filter of a complementary colour to the colour of the sample is chosen (based on the colour wheel).
The coloured species samples absorbs the complementary colour to a large extent, so colorimetry can be more efficient.

Calibration curves show how the absorbance increases when the concentration of the corresponding coloured substance increases in a solution.

Example: HKDSE 2016 Paper 2 Q3(b)


Choose a suitable colour filter which is of complementary colour of the solution.
Put a test tube containing distilled water only (blank solution) into the colorimeter and set its absorbance to zero.
Prepare a set of standard solutions of the sample with different concentrations. Record their absorbance by colorimetry separately.
Plot a calibration curve of absorbance against concentration.


Following the progress of reactions involving colour changes
Determining the amount of certain ingredients in food and drugs
Determining the amount of certain substances in blood and urine

item.title: Infrared spectrum
item.description:
Infrared spectroscopy is used for identifying bonds and functional groups in molecules. Infrared light is used to measure the vibration of atoms with different bonds.
Vibration frequency of atoms with different types of bonds is unique, so they have different characteristics of absorption, emission and reflection. Generally, stronger bonds and light atoms will vibrate at a high stretching frequency (wavenumber).

Infrared spectrum is a plot of percentage of transmittance (%) against the wavenumber () of infrared radiation.

Example: hexan-1-ol


The presence of (sharp) absorption peak at corresponds to bond.
The presence of (sharp) absorption peak at corresponds to bond for alcohol.
Info The range of absorption peak at is the fingerprint region.
Example: hexanoic acid


The presence of (sharp) absorption peak at corresponds to bond.
The presence of (broad) absorption peak at corresponds to bond for carboxylic acid.
The presence of (sharp) absorption peak at corresponds to bond.

item.title: Instruments
item.description:
Instrumental analytical methods can be used to determine the composition and concentration of substances in a sample using instruments.


Colorimetry: Determines concentration (amount) of coloured substances in a solution by measuring light absorbance.
Infrared spectroscopy: Identifies particular functional groups and bonds in an organic sample.
Mass spectrometry: Determines the relative atomic mass of an element, the relative molecular mass of a compound, and the structure of an unknown organic sample.


More rapid
More accurate, as instruments are more sensitive
Usually non-destructive
Lower possibility of human error
Problem with conventional analytical methods
A large amount of a sample is required to produce accurate results.
Chemical reactions usually occur in the sample, and cannot be recovered easily for reuse.
Results can be inaccurate due to human errors. Examples: titrimetric analysis

item.title: Mass spectrometry
item.description:
Mass spectrometry is used to determine the relative atomic mass of an element and relative molecular mass of a compound, as well as the structure of an unknown compound.
Advantages:

Time for analysis is short.
Very small amount of sample is needed.
The sample can be in gaseous, liquid or solid states.
High accuracy in determining molecular mass of compounds.



Vaporization
The sample is first vaporized to gaseous form.
It can be an element or a compound.
Ionization
The gaseous sample is bombarded by a beam of fast-moving electrons.
Electrons from the molecules of the sample are knocked out, forming positive molecular ions ().
When molecular ions collide with electrons, they will undergo fragmentation, producing fragment ions.
Acceleration
The positive ions. including molecular ions and fragment ions, are accelerated by an electric field towards a magnetic field.
Deflection
The positive ions are deflected by a magnetic field.
Ions with lower mass-to-charge ratio (m/e or m/z) are deflected more.
Ions with higher mass-to-charge ratio are deflected less.
By varying the electric field and magnetic field, ions of different m/e can enter the detector.
Detection
The detector produces electrical signals proportional to the number of ions detected.
The signals are recorded and presented in a mass spectrum.

A mass spectrum show the relative intensity (or relative abundance) of positive ions generated against the mass-to-charge ratio of positive ions.

item.title: Chromatography
item.description:
Chromatography can be used for separating different solutes in a solution.
Types:

Paper chromatography
Thin-layer chromatography (TLC)
Column chromatography
Phases:

Stationary phase (fixed in position)
Mobile phase (moves in one direction)



Phases:

A thin film of water is held by the cellulose fibres in the paper. The water film of the paper acts as the stationary phase.
The developing solvent (alcohol-water) mixture acts as the mobile phase.
Process:

A baseline is drawn with a pencil across the bottom of a strip of filter paper.
A drop of black ink is added on the baseline and allowed to dry.
The paper is then suspended in an alcohol-water mixture (developing solvent), with the ink spot above the solvent level.
Warning The level of the solvent should not be higher than the baseline.
Separation of components:

Different components (with different colours) have different absorptivities / solubilities in the mobile phase and stationery phase.

The more soluble the component in stationary phase, the slower it travels up the stationary phase.
The more soluble the component in mobile phase, the faster it travels up the stationary phase.
Example: HKDSE 2019 Paper 2 Q3(c)(iii)
Explain briefly why chromatography can be used to separate a mixture.

Different components have different solubilities / absorptivities in mobile phase and stationary phase.

values (retention ratio) can be used for identification of components.

Example: HKDSE 2018 Paper 2 Q3(a)(iii)
What is meaning of the ' value' of a substance in a paper chromatogram?

value is the ratio of distance traveled by the component to the distance traveled by the solvent front.
Example: HKDSE 2020 Paper 2 Q3(b)(i-iii)
The chromatograms from thin-layer chromatography (TLC) of aspirin, caffeine, acetaminophen and a drug Y are shown below.

(i) Draw a labelled diagram for the set-up in performing a TLC experiment.

(ii) Calculate the value for aspirin.

(iii) Based on the chromatograms provided, suggest whether drug Y would contain aspirin, caffeine or acetaminophen.

Aspirin
Caffeine


A thin layer of silica gel () or alumina powder (), usually coated on glass, aluminium or plastic plate, will be used as the stationary phase.
The developing solvent acts as the mobile phase.
Advantages over paper chromatograpy:

It has a higher speed.
It requires a smaller amount of sample.



Similar to thin-layer chromatography, but the amounts of the sample mixture and developing solvent used are much larger.
This method of chromatography allows for separation.
Set-up:

Column is held vertically.
Eluting solvent is kept adding from the top and it runs through the column under gravitational force.
Components are separated as they move down the column.
To perform the experiment in a small scale, a dropper containing alumina can be used instead of a column.

item.title: Fractional distillation
item.description:
Principle: (by ethanol and water)

When the mixture is heated, both ethanol and water vaporize.
The vapour contains more ethanol and less water.
Upon rising the column, more water condenses to liquid than ethanol.
After repeated vaporization and condensation, the vapour at the top contains mostly ethanol. The ethanol vapour condenses to liquid in the condenser.
Applications:

Fractional distillation of liquefied air
Fractional distillation of petroleum

item.title: Experimental procedure
item.description:
Liquid-liquid extraction, also solvent extraction, is a process to extract substance from one liquid to another liquid. The liquids used must be immiscible. A separating funnel is used for this extraction process.


Consider the extraction of iodine from aqueous iodine solution (brown in colour) in heptane (purple in colour):

Iodine is more soluble in organic solvents than in aqueous solvents.
(a): Water and heptane is immiscible, they remain as two separate layers.
(b): After shaking, most of the iodine will dissolve into the heptane layer.
Then, the tap is opened to run off the lower aqueous layer and the top layer of iodine dissolved in heptane can be obtained.
Traces of water can be removed by adding drying agents (e.g. anhydrous , anhydrous ) and then filtered.
The iodine dissolved in heptane can be further distilled to obtain iodine solid, as heptane has a lower boiling point than iodine solid.
Tip In the above experiment, haptane is less dense than water and forms the upper organic layer, while water forms the lower aqueous layer. However, students are not expected to deduce this.
Warning
The tap should be opened occasionally to remove vapour pressure, otherwise the stopper may be pushed away.
The stopper should be removed before running off the liquid from the separating funnel, otherwise the liquid may not run.



Example: HKDSE 2016 Paper 2 Q3(c)(ii)(1)
X and Y are isomeric compounds with their structures shown below:

Both of them are insoluble in water but soluble in dichloromethane. When treated with dilute , no reaction occurs for X but reaction occurs for Y to form a soluble salt.
You are provided with dilute and dilute . Outline an experimental procedure, based on solvent extraction, to separate solid Y from a solution of X and Y in dichloromethane.
Solution:

Add (in excess) into X and Y in dichloromethane.
Transfer the mixture into separating funnel. Shake thoroughly. (The mixture is allowed to settle.)
Run off to obtain aqueous layer which contains salt (/ anion) of Y.
Add dilute into the aqueous layer until no more precipitate is formed.
Filter to obtain the solid Y.
Tip When Y reacts with , a sodium salt is produced. Addition of an acid is to reform the original organic compound.

item.title: Process
item.description:
Pre-context: Crystallization
Recrystallization is a process to purify impure solid products prepared in chemical reactions.


Choose a suitable solvent that does not react with the solid product.
Water, ethanol, propanone (acetone) are commonly used solvents.
Dissolve the crude solid product in a minimum amount of hot solvent. Filter to remove the insoluble impurities.
Allow the hot filtrate to cool down to room temperature, the solute comes out as crystals.
Collect the crystals by filtration under reduced pressure and dry crystals.
Simple filtration can be sped up by connecting the set-up to a suction pump (suction filtration).
Wash the crystals with a little amount of cold distilled water or any other suitable solvents to remove any soluble impurities. Then, the crystals are dried with a piece of filter paper or in an oven.

item.title: Energy profile
item.description:
Pre-context: Effective collisions
Activation energy is the minimum amount of energy possessed by the reactant particles in order for a reaction to occur. It is the energy barrier that the reactant particles have to overcome before a reaction can occur.



Activation energy must be positive.
Energy is needed to break bonds at the beginning of reaction.
Activated complex (or transitional state) is highly unstable.
It contains partially broken and partially formed bonds.
Note can be positive, zero or negative.

Definition of catalyst:
Catalyst is a substance that can change the rate of reaction with itself being chemically unchanged after the reaction.
Working principle of positive catalyst:

It increases the rate of reaction by providing an alternative reaction pathway with lower activation energy.
More reactant particles have energy equal to or greater than the activation energy. The collision frequency and effective collisions increase.


Rate determining step is the slowest step of a chemical reaction that determines the speed (rate) at which the overall reaction proceeds.
The slower step also have a higher activation energy.

item.title: Characteristics
item.description:
A catalyst is a substance which changes the rate of reaction with itself being chemically unchanged after the reaction.
Catalyst may undergo chemical change during reaction, but it must be regenerated after the reaction.
Catalyst increases the rate of reaction by providing an alternative reaction pathway with lower activation energy.
↪️ See also: Activation energy and energy profiles
A catalyst is needed in a very small amount.
A catalyst is very specific in action.
A catalyst is easily poisoned by a small amount of impurities. The catalytic effect will be decreased once the catalyst is contaminated.
catalyst in catalytic converter in motor cars is easily poisoned by lead compounds, leaded fuels cannot be used.
↪️ See also: Combustion > Catalytic converters
The catalytic effect will be increased when the surface area of the catalyst is increased (e.g. using porous / finely divided catalysts).
Increasing the surface area of a catalyst will increase the collision frequency between the catalyst and reactant particles.
The effective collision (per unit time) increases and the rate of reaction is increased.
The use of catalyst doesn't change the enthalpy change () of the reaction.
The amount of total energy released / absorbed will be the same as that in uncatalysed reaction.

To allow the concentration of to be directly proportional to the volume of used.

The produced will be consumed by immediately.

Time can be found by measuring the time to form the dark-blue complex.

item.title: Twelve principles of green chemistry
item.description:
Green chemistry is important for achieving sustainable development. It investigates ways to maximize the efficiency of utilization of feedstock, raw materials and energy, while reducing the emission of toxic substances and waste produced during the production process.


Waste prevention
An industrial process is greener when no waste (side products other than products) is produced. (Maximizes atom economy)
Using less hazardous chemical synthesis
An industrial process is greener when hazardous reactants are not involved.
Using safer chemical products
Chemicals synthesized should be safe to use and not harm the environment.
Using saver solvents and auxillaries
Examples: Replacement of VOCs and CFCs
Designing for energy efficiency
When a catalyst is used, less energy is needed to heat up the reaction mixture.
Energy is used to heat liquid mixture and purifying productions by distillation.
When the reaction pathway consists of fewer steps, less processes of separation and purification are needed. Less energy is needed.
Using renewable raw materials / feedstock
Reliance on petroleum-based raw materials is non-renewable.
Renewable raw products mostly come from agricultural products or crops.
Example: Production of vitamin C, as glucose can be extracted from corn.
Reducing derivatives
Additional reagents should be minimized.
Using catalyst
Catalysts can speed up the reaction by providing an alternative reaction pathway with lower activation energy. Less energy will be needed for synthesis.
Warning Some catalysts are heavy transition metals, they can cause harm to the environment when disposed of into rivers.

Designing degradable products
Example: Biodegradable plastics
Developing real-time analysis for pollution prevention
Minimizing the potential for chemical accidents
Example: leakages, explosions, fires
Maximizing atom economy
Atom economy is based on the 100% conversion from reactants to products.

Warning Do not mix up atom economy and percentage yield.
Atom economy does not involve experimentation, it is based on a 100% completed reaction.
Percentage yield is based on experimental data.
Relationship of atom economy with percentage yield:
Atom economy and percentage yield do not show any relationships.

The calculation of atom economy is based on a 100% complete reaction.
However, most of the reactions do not go to completion, and the yield is related to the extent of reaction.

item.title: Maxwell-Boltzmann's distribution curve
item.description:
The Maxwell-Boltzmann's distribution curve is a curve showing the range of kinetic energies of the particles in a gaseous system at a particular temperature.
Characteristics:

The x-axis is the (molecular) kinetic energy, the y-axis is the number of molecules.
The area under the curve represents the total number of molecules in the system.
There are very few molecules with high kinetic energies, and no molecules with zero energy.
There is no maximum energy for a molecule.
Most probable kinetic energy: The kinetic energy possessed by the largest number of molecules.
Average kinetic energy: Always lies on the right of the maximum point.
The shaded region under the curve shows the number of particles having energy equal or greater than the activation energy, which can collide effectively and undergo chemical reaction.

Effects (increase):

There is greater portion of high kinetic energy molecules, distribution curve becomes flatter and lie to the right side.
Most probable kinetic energy and average kinetic energy increase, while the number of molecules having these kinetic energies decrease.
Range of kinetic energy increases as higher kinetic energies can be achieved.
Area under the curves are the same as the number of molecules remain unchanged.
Activation energy () remains unchanged.
Explanation (increase):

An increase in temperature can increase the (average) kinetic energy of molecules.
There is a larger portion of molecules having kinetic energy equal to or greater than activation energy.
The collision frequency and hence the effective collisions per unit time increase. Rate of reaction increases.
↪️ See also: HKDSE 2013 Paper 2 Q1(a)


Explanation:

Catalyst increases the rate of reaction by providing an alternative reaction pathway with lower activation energy.
More molecules will have energy equal or greater than , effective collisions per unit time increases.

Aluminium has a great corrosion resistance due to the formation of the aluminium oxide layer on its surface.

The thin layer of aluminium oxide sticks to the surface of aluminium very strongly (does not flake off) and is impermeable to both oxygen and water, protecting it from further corrosion.
Aluminium is less dense than iron and has weaker strength compared to iron.

item.title: Protection of metals
item.description:
Note This page mainly discusses the protection of iron.
The methods to prevent rusting are made in accordance with one of the following chemical properties:

To prevent contact of iron to oxygen and water in air
To prevent lost of electrons in iron

A protective layer has to be completely coated on an iron made object. This prevents the contact of iron to oxygen and water in air.

Coating with paint
Cheap way to protect iron made objects in bridges, car bodies and fences.
Coating with plastic
More expansive than paint, used in coat hangers and paper clips.
Coating with oil and grease
Used in moving parts of machines. It can also serve as a lubricant.
Protection of moving parts
A machine should be oiled from time to time, as the oil will rub off and dirt would stick to the oil or grease.
Paint or plastic should not be used on moving parts, as it would be scratched off easily.

Main article: Electroplating
Electroplating is a chemical process which uses electrolysis to place a metal onto the iron made object.
Chromium and copper are commonly used as plating metals as they give a shiny appearance. However, this method is expensive.

In tin-plating, the iron surface is completely coated by tin.

Tin prevents iron from contacting oxygen and water in air. Tin metal is corrosion resistant as it forms a protective oxide layer on the surface.
Tin-plating is widely used in food cans since tin and tin ions are non-poisonous.
Note Zinc ions are poisonous, they are not used for coating food cans.

When the tin metal is incomplete (e.g. being scratched), part of the iron will be exposed. Since tin is less reactive than iron, and iron is now in contact with tin, iron will rust even faster than without contacting tin.
↪️ Therefore, tin-plated food can should not be consumed when it is scratched or deformed.

Galvanization is zinc-plating, zinc loses electrons more readily than iron to prevent rusting.

By attaching a more reactive metal (e.g. zinc), the more reactive metal loses electrons more readily than iron. Therefore, iron will not lose electrons and will not rust.
The blocks of metal used in protecting iron needs to be replaced from time to time.
Examples:

Attaching zinc blocks to ship hulls
Most ships are made of steel and contains iron. Zinc blocks are attached to the ship hull to prevent iron from rusting.
Magnesium blocks connected to underground pipelines
Some underground water pipes are made of iron. Magnesium blocks are attached to the underground pipelines to prevent iron from rusting.

An alloy is a mixture formed by meting two or more elements (e.g. carbon and chromium) together, in which at least one of them is a metal.
Example:

Stainless steel is an alloy of iron made by mixing iron with specific amounts of carbon, chromium and nickel.
However, this method is the most expensive method.
Strength of alloys
The introduction of other elements disturbs the regular arrangement of metals in its giant metallic structure.
The metallic ions cannot slide over each other easily when force is applied.


In cathodic protection, the negative terminal (cathode) of a battery or power supply is connected to the iron object, providing electrons to the object and preventing the formation of ions.

item.title: Rusting
item.description:
Rusting is a chemical reaction that results in the corrosion of iron. Both oxygen and water are required in order for rusting to occur.
Consider the following experiment:

In tube A:

There is oxygen but no water.
Anhydrous calcium chloride absorbs water in air.
↪️ Rusting does not occur.
In tube B:

There is water but no oxygen in water.
Boiling the distilled water dries away dissolved oxygen, and the oil layer on top prevents air from dissolving in water again.
↪️ Rusting does not occur.
In tube C:

There is both water and oxygen.
Distilled water contains dissolved air.
↪️ Rusting occurs.
In tube D:

There is water, oxygen and dissolved ions.
Sea water contains dissolved air and ions, which increases the electrical conductivity and further speeds up rusting.
↪️ Rusting occurs, and faster than in tube C.

See also: Redox Reactions, Chemical Cells and Electrolysis
Upon rusting, iron would turn to rust. Rust is hydrated iron(III) oxide:
Overall chemical equation:

Tip Rusting is a redox reaction.
Reaction of iron:
Iron undergoes oxidation and loses electrons:


Warning Iron will not be directly oxidised to give iron(III) ion:

Reaction of oxygen and water:
Oxygen and water gain electrons to become hydroxide ion.


Rust () is a reddish brown solid.

Rust does not attach firmly on the iron metal.
It flakes off easily and exposes the inner iron.
The rust is also permeable to oxygen and water in air.
Even if the rust does not flake off, oxygen and water can penetrate and contact the inner iron.

Rust indicator is an aqueous solution potassium hexacyanoferrate(III) () and phenolphthalein.

Addition of to the rust indicator can speed up rusting by increasing electrical conductivity.
Consider the following experimental set-up:

Acid rain contains dissolved and , which can form acids and increases the rate of rusting. This can happen in industrial areas.
Note Alkaline solution will not speed up rusting, but inhibit rusting in contrast. The ions in an alkaline solution shifts the equilibrium position of the following reaction to the reactant side. See also: Chemical Equilibrium


Soluble ionic compounds contain mobile ions, which increase the electrical conductivity of substances in the environment.
Since rusting involve electron transfer, soluble ionic compounds speed up rusting.
Tip Iron objects near sea will rust faster since seawater contains salts, which are soluble ionic compound.

Higher temperature increases the rate of chemical reaction.
Tip Iron-made car exhaust pipes rusts easily since they become hot when the cars are running.


Iron loses electrons more readily than the less reactive metal.
When iron is attached to a less reactive metal (e.g. tin and copper), rusting speeds up.

item.title: Polyester
item.description:
Pre-context: Polymerization / Addition polymerization
Condensation polymerization is a reaction in which monomer molecules join together repeatedly to form polymer molecules, with the elimination of small molecules (e.g. , ).

Polyester are polymers with monomer units linked by ester linkage ().

Monomers should be dicarboxylic acid () and diol () such that repeated condensation reaction could occur between polymers to form a large polyester.
Monomers should be bifunctional, with the molecules able to react with neighbouring molecules to form a chain.

Example:

PET (Polyethylene terephthalate) is formed by repeated esterification between benzene-1,4-dioic acid and ethane-1,2-diol.
Note The stoichiometric ratio of the water produced can also be .
Intermolecular forces between PET chains:

There are only van der Waals' forces between PET chains.

PET has great strength as the groups in the polymer chains are polar and there is considerable intermolecular attraction between the polymer chains.
Note Even though the O atoms may have a lone pair of electrons, it is insoluble in water as the polymer chains are too long.
Properties of polyesters:

They do not have a sharp melting point
Each polyester contains a different number of monomers ().
Decomposition by acids and alkalis
PET undergoes hydrolysis in the presence of acids or alkalis, it breaks the ester linkages and lead to a formation of a hole on fabridcs made from polyester.
↪️ This allows them to be readily degraded in the environment.
Miscellaneous
Water & chemical resistance
Tough, Strong, Smooth, Lightweight
Uses of PET:

Synthetic fibres for clothing and bedding
Bottles of soft drinks
Lightweight sails

Polyamide are polymers with monomer units linked by amide linkage ().

item.title: Structure
item.description:
A detergent has an ionic head which is hydrophilic and a hydrocarbon tail which is hydrophobic.
Note
Detergents are essentially salt solutions.
The cation does not affect in the cleansing action of detergents.


Water is used to clean substances to wash away dirt on clothes or other surfaces, but it is an ineffective cleansing medium:

High surface tension (water only)
Water has a high surface tension due to its extensive (intermolecular) hydrogen bonds, causing the water molecules to always hold into a drop. This slows the wetting of fabric surfaces and inhibits the cleansing process.
Inability to dissolve and remove grease (water + oil)
When grease would bind to dirt particles on a surface, water cannot remove the grease and dirt, as grease is insoluble in water.
To enhance the cleansing ability of water, detergent acts as two agents:

Wetting agent (water only)
Emulsifying agent (water + oil)

Detergents are a wetting agent and reduce the surface tension of water, which spreads the water to wet the surface.
Detailed explanation:

When the detergent is added into water, the hydrophilic head of detergent would dissolve in the water molecule, and the hydrophobic tail would stick out of the water molecule.
The intervening detergent particles separate water molecules and weaken the hydrogen bonds between water molecules, hence decreasing the surface tension of water.
The water would wet the surface more thoroughly instead of beading up.


Detergents contain a hydrophobic hydrocarbon tail which dissolves in oil;
While it has a hydrophilic ionic head which dissolves in water.
Water molecules attract the hydrophilic ionic head and bring the oil into water.
Upon shaking, the oil will break into droplets and cannot come together again due to repulsion of negative ionic head of detergent.


Effectiveness:

Soapless detergents work much better than soapy detergent in hard water (water containing or ), since soapless detergents would not form scum while soapy detergents would with hard water.
Biodegradability:

Determined by its structure (not their source!)
A detergent is biodegradable when there is no branched chains in its structure.


Soapy detergents are made from natural fats and oils. Natural fats and oils are esters which consists of ester groups ().
Example: Lipids > Triglycerides

By alkaline hydrolysis of triglyceride, an alcohol and carboxylate salt can be obtained.

↪️ This process is called saponification.


Heat the vegetable oil with concentrated solution (which allows saponification).
After the reaction, add concentrated solution into the reaction mixture to help salting out of the soap.
Note
As soapy detergent is a salt with ionic bonds, it would be soluble in water.
Addition of concentrated solution decreases the solubility of soap in the reaction mixture to allow extraction of soapy detergent in the form of solid.

Filter to obtain the soap. Wash the soap with a little distilled water and allow it to dry.

Soapless detergents are made from hydrocarbons obtained from petroleum.
The hydrocarbons are first reacted with very concentrated and the product is then neutralized with .

item.title: Cracking
item.description:
Cracking is a thermal decomposition reaction to break down a larger chain hydrocarbon molecule into smaller alkanes and alkenes.
Importance of cracking:

Production of extra petrol to meet demands
Produce alkenes (raw material for making other chemicals, e.g. plastics)
Types of cracking:

Thermal cracking
Catalytic cracking
Tip When a long chain alkane is cracked, there aren't enough hydrogen atoms to make two alkanes. Hence, cracking will usually produce one alkane and one alkene.

Catalytic cracking breaks down the large alkanes to smaller alkanes and alkenes with the help of heat and catalyst in the absence of oxygen.


Thermal cracking is a process of cracking where vaporised long chain alkane is mixed with steam at very high temperatures, and does not involve a catalyst.

item.title: Dissolving halogen in organic solvent
item.description:
Pre-context: Solubility and miscibility
See also: Group VII elements
Halogen molecules are non-polar in nature. By the like-dissolve-like principle, they tend to be more soluble in non-polar organic solvents than in water.
Examples of non-polar organic solvents:

Tetrachloromethane ()
Hexane ()
Chloroform ()
Diethyl ether ()


When both water and non-polar organic solvent are present within a mixture, two distinct layers will be formed.
Upper layer — Non-polar / hydrocarbon solvent:

Higher in position because of lower density than water.
Water molecules can form extensive hydrogen bonds, while van der Waals' forces exist between non-polar molecules.
Darker in colour.
It contains dissolved halogen.
Lower layer — Polar / aqueous solvent:

Colour of aqueous halogens is lighter.

Carbon can form strong covalent bonds with itself to give chains and rings of carbon atoms.

Carbon can form multiple bonds (e.g. double / triple bonds).
Tip
Unsaturated compounds: Carbon compounds with double or triple bonds.
Saturated compounds: Carbon compounds with only carbon single bonds.

item.title: Set-ups
item.description:
Fractional distillation of petroleum separates the petroleum into fractions by physical method. It makes use of the different molecular sizes and boiling points of hydrocarbon fractions.




Heat the mineral wool soaked with petroleum very gently. Fraction with the lowest boiling point range distils off first.
Then, heat the mineral wool more strongly, fractions with higher boiling point ranges distill off one after the other.
Collect various fractions in turn in separate test tubes.



The petroleum is heated to ~400°C in a furnace. The hot liquid and partly vapour oil is then pumped into the bottom of a fractionating tower.
The liquid part (with the highest boiling point) sinks to bottom of the tower. Other fractions rises up the tower.
The temperature decrease up the tower. At the appropriate temperature, the fraction cools and condenses to liquid. Condensed hydrocarbons flows out and is collected.

item.title: Functional group
item.description:
A functional group is an atom or a group of atoms which determines most of the properties of a compound.
Refer to "Selected homologous series" for a full list of homologous series.

Homologous series is a family of compounds having the same general formula and functional group with adjacent members differing by a unit.
Compounds of the same homologous series have similar chemical properties because they have the same functional group. However, they have different physical properties (mass, boiling points, melting points, density and viscosity, soluble in ).
item.guid: Chemistry/Organic Chemistry/Homologous series and Functional groups.md

item.title: Types
item.description:
Hydrocarbons are organic compounds comprised exclusively of carbon and hydrogen.


Aliphatic hydrocarbons
Carbon compounds with carbon atoms are joined together in straight chains, branched chains or non-aromatic rings.
Aromatic hydrocarbons
Carbon compounds with one or more benzene rings.


Coal is a combustible sedimentary rock containing over 50% of carbon by mass, and also contains trace amounts of sulphur and nitrogen compounds.
Usage: Generating electricity
Tip Combustion of coal causes environmental problems (e.g. acid rain) as it contains impurities (elements S & N) that forms acidic oxides.
Formation:

Remains of ancient plants were deeply buried under layers of sand and mud.
High temperature, pressure and the action of bacteria slowly convert the plant remains into coal.

Petroleum, also crude oil, is a liquid mixture of hydrocarbons. Natural gas is a gaseous mixture of hydrocarbons, with the main component being methane ().
Formation:

Large quantities of dead marine organisms (e.g. planktons and algaes) are buried underneath sedimentary rocks.
Their remains are subjected to intense heat and pressure for a long time.

Main article: Fractional distillation of petroleum
Direct combustion of petroleum is wasteful. Petroleum fractions are usually obtained from refining petroleum as some fractions have useful purposes other than composition.

Petroleum is used as fuels for combustion or a source of hydrocarbons for the production of useful chemicals.

The demand for a petroleum fraction is closely related to their physical and chemical properties.
Generally, smaller chain hydrocarbons make better fuels as they are more volatile, more flammable and burn with a less sooty flame.

Tip Naphtha and natural gas is the raw material for production of town gas.

item.title: Structural isomerism
item.description:
Structural isomers all have the same molecular formula.

Chain isomers are isomers that have the same functional group but different carbon skeletons. In general, they have similar chemical properties because they possess the same functional group.
Examples:

Chain isomers of


Position isomers are isomers that have the same carbon skeleton and functional group. They differ in the position of the functional group. In general, they have similar chemical properties because they possess the same functional group.
Examples:

Position isomers of
O H O H

Functional group isomers are isomers that contain different functional group. They have different chemical properties as they have different functional groups.
Examples:

Functional group isomers of
O H O

Stereoisomers are isomers that have the same arrangement of atoms, but have different spatial arrangement.

Cis-trans isomers, also geometric isomers, are isomers with different spatial arrangements due to the restricted rotation of double bond.
C H Cl C Cl H cis-1,2-dichloroethene C H Cl C H Cl trans-1,2-dichloroethene
Chemical properties Cis-trans isomers show similar (or the same) chemical properties because they possess exactly the same functional group. C H C O O H C C O O H H Polarmolecule C H C O O H C H C O O H Non-polarmolecule
Melting point and boiling point Cis isomers would have a higher boiling point than trans isomers.
This is because cis isomers are polar, while trans isomers are non-polar.
The van der Waals' force between cis molecules is stronger than that in trans molecules in liquid state. Trans isomers would have a higher melting point than cis isomers.
This is because trans isomers have a higher packing efficiency than cis isomers.
The van der Waals' force between trans molecules is stronger than that in cis molecules in solid state.

Enantiomers are two non-identical molecules with atoms or groups of atoms arranged in different positions.
Properties:

Non-superimposable with mirror image
Chiral
No plane of symmetry

(* central C atom is the chiral centre)
Warning Students are only required to identify enantiomers with one chiral centre. However, carbon compounds with more than one chiral centres may not exhibit enantiomerism.
Enantiomers are composed by the same atoms, they have the same molecular size and molecular polarity. Therefore, they have the same physical properties.
However, there are differences in their interactions with polarized light (optical activity). This can be measured using a polarimeter.

Rotates clockwise: (+)-isomer
Rotates anticlockwise: (-)-isomer
Tip Enantiomers can rotate the plane of plane-polarized light in opposite directions.
They also have the same chemical properties as they have the same chemical bonds. They also have the same standard enthalpy change of formation.

item.title: Procedure
item.description:
Flame test is a physical test. When the metallic ion is burnt in a Bunsen flame, they will give off different colours. The metallic element in a compound can be identified by the flame colour produced.
Choice and cleaning of apparatus A platinum or nichrome (alloy of nickel and chromium) wire will be used for the test, as they have high melting point and corrosion resistance. The wire used should be cleaned before the experiment. To clean the platinum wire, dip the wire into concentrated hydrochloric acid and then heat it in the Bunsen flame until no characteristic flame colour is observed.


Dip a clean platinum / nichrome wire into concentrated hydrochloric acid and heat in Bunsen flame (until no characteristic flame is observed).
Dip the nichrome wire into the concentrated hydrochloric acid and then the solid sample. (If the sample is in aqueous form, use evaporation or crystallization first)
Put the end of the wire in the (non-luminous) Bunsen flame and observe the flame colour.
Warning The wire should be heated under naked flame. Heating the compound when it is placed inside of a test tube does not produce enough heat for the formation of the characteristic flame colours (spectral colours).

item.title: Physical change and physical property
item.description:
Physical change is a change without new substance formed. These changes can be reversed easily.
Examples:

Changing the state of a substance (e.g. boiling water)
Changing the appearance of a substance (e.g. grinding big lumps of limestone into fine powder)
Dissolving a solid in a liquid (e.g. dissolving sugar in water)

The physical properties of a substance are properties that can be observed or measured without changing the chemical composition of the substance.
Examples:

Melting point, Boiling point
Colour, Odour
State, Density, Hardness
Electrical conductivity
Note For example, ice melting into water at 0°C is a physical property of ice.

Chemical change is a change without new substance formed. These changes are difficult to reverse.
Examples:

Burning magnesium to form a white powder
Heating a mixture of iron fillings to sulphur to form a dark brown solid
Rusting of iron

The chemical properties of a substance are properties that can observed or measured only when the substance undergoes a chemical change to form new substance.
Examples:

Flammability, oxidizability
Toxicity
Reaction of substances with other matters

Iron powder has magnetic property. When iron is mixed with sulphur powder, no particular chemical reaction occurs and no new substances are formed. The mixing process is a physical change. When a magnet is placed near the iron powder, it would try to stick on the magnet and follow its movement.
However, when the iron is heated with sulphur, the heat provided triggers a chemical reaction to form a new substance (). The nature of iron has been changed, it can no longer exhibit the magnetic property.
item.guid: Chemistry/Planet Earth/Fundamentals of Chemistry/Chemical and physical changes and properties.md

item.title: Classification of matter
item.description:
Matter is anything that has a mass and occupies space. It can be classified into pure substance and mixture.

Note Comparing pure substances and mixture, pure substances would have sharp physical properties (such as boiling point and melting point) while mixtures do not.

Pure substances are single substances that has nothing else mixed with it.
Examples:

Copper ()
Chlorine ()
Distilled water ()

Elements are substances which cannot be broken down into anything simpler by chemical methods. Substances that can be broken down into simpler substances by electricity, for example, are not elements.
Examples:

Carbon ()
Aluminium ()
Copper ()

Compounds are substances composed of two or more elements chemically joined together. They can be broken down into simpler substances by chemical methods.
Examples:

Sodium chloride ()
Water ()
Ammonia ()

Mixtures consists of two or more substances which are not chemically joined together. Different pure substances in mixtures can be separated by a physical method.
Examples:

Soda water ( and )
Wine (, , and other substances)
Rock salt (, and other substances)

item.title: Experiments
item.description:
Particle theory states that all matter is made up of particles. These particles are so small that we cannot see them with the naked eye, but some simple experiments confirm that they do exist.



Experiment: Placing a potassium permanganate crystal (purple) in water.
Observation: The lump of potassium permanganate crystal dissolved in water gradually.
Deduced explanation: The particles of potassium permanganate leave the crystal and mix through the water particles.


Experiment: Placing a jar of air upside down on a jar of bromine vapour.
Observation: The bromine vapour has spread throughout both jars after a period of time.
Deduced explanation: The bromine particles and air particles move around randomly and fill both gas jars. (diffusion)

Note The states discussed here are measured at room temperature and pressure (25°C, 1 atm). Information regarding supercritical states or similar will not be included in the Knowledge Handbook at this time.

Particles in this state are tightly packed, usually in a regular pattern. Therefore, they have the highest density in general. Although the particles can vibrate in a solid, they generally do not move from place to place.

Particles in this state are close together with no regular arrangement. Therefore, they have lower density than solids in general. The particles in this state can vibrate, move about and slide past each other.

Particles in this state are well separated with no regular arrangement. Therefore, they have the lowest density in general. The particles in this state can vibrate and move freely at high speeds.

Change of states is an example of physical change.


Melting, evaporation and sublimation are all endothermic processes, as these types of state changes increase the temperature.
Freezing, condensation and deposition are all exothermic processes, as these types of state changes decrease the temperature.

Take water as an example:

At any temperature °C, the following conditions are true:

If (s): < m.p.

item.title: Calcium carbonate and its reactions
item.description:
Limestone is one of the most common types of rock found in Earth’s crust. It is composed primarily of calcite. The major composition of calcite is calcium carbonate.
Calcium carbonate () occurs naturally in mainly three forms:

Chalk
Limestone
Marble
Formation of chalk in the Earth's crust:

Chalk is formed from the skeletons and shells of animals containing calcium carbonate when their dead remains sink to the seabed.
The action of heat and pressure will gradually turn the dead remains into chalk. Earth movements (e.g. earthquakes) will bring these layers of chalk to the Earth's surface.
Differences in strength between chalk, limestone and marble:
Higher pressure and heat cause chalk to turn into much harder limestone. Even higher pressure and heat would turn limestone into marble.
↪️ Strength: marble > limestone > chalk


Calcium carbonate () is a white solid / powder, and is insoluble in water.

Thermal decomposition of calcium carbonate
Calcium carbonate will be decomposed on strong heating into calcium oxide (quicklime) and carbon dioxide.
↪️
Addition of little water to calcium oxide
When a few drops of water is added to calcium oxide (quicklime), it becomes crumbled and water is absorbed. Calcium hydroxide (slaked lime) is formed.
↪️
Addition of excess water to calcium hydroxide
When calcium hydroxide is added into excess amount of water, the amount of water is sufficient to dissolve the slightly soluble calcium hydroxide. Soluble aqueous calcium hydroxide (limewater) is formed. It is a colourless solution.
↪️
Saturated limewater is used to for chemical tests, it can be produced by adding excess slaked lime () into water, and filtered off to remove the excess undissolved solid.
Addition of excess carbon dioxide to limewater
See also: Test for carbon dioxide gas
Passing carbon dioxide gas into limewater turns it from colourless to milky due to the formation of insoluble calcium carbonate.
↪️


When excess carbon dioxide is passed into limewater, the solution turns from milky to colourless due to the formation of water soluble calcium hydrogencarbonate ().
↪️
Calcium can also react with carbonic acid () to form calcium hydrogencarbonate ().
↪️
Calcium can also react with hydrochloric acid () to give a dissolved salt of , colourless gas bubble of and .
↪️

Limestone:

For neutralising acidic pollutants in flue gas
For making glass
For construction of building and roads
For neutralising waste water
Quicklime:

For making steel from iron
For making cement
For neutralising soil acidity
Slaked lime:

For neutralising waste water

Air consists of carbon dioxide (some formed naturally while others are from industrial processes). When rain falls, the water reacts with carbon dioxide to form carbonic acid.

Normal rainwater is slightly acidic and has a pH level of 5.0 ~ 5.5. Carbonic acid is not the source to cause acid rain.
Acid rain is caused by other pollutants produced from industrial plants|. They dissolve in rainwater to make it more acidic (with a pH level lower than 4).
Corrosion of buildings:

When the carbonic acid in rainwater contacts with calcium carbonate structures, erosion may occur, as a reaction causes the calcium carbonate to form water-soluble calcium hydrogencarbonate ().
These structures will gradually dissolve. Constant repairs are required.

item.title: Fractional distillation of liquefied air
item.description:
Pre-context: Particle Theory > Relationship between temperature and physical states
See also: The atmosphere
Different components in air have different boiling points, they can be separated by a physical process called fractional distillation of liquefied air.


Purification
Water vapour, carbon dioxide and dust are removed as they might accumulate and block the pipes.
Liquefaction
Purified air is compressed at a very high pressure at the compressor, and passes through the cooling coils to cool down. It then passes through the expansion chamber and is expanded rapidly.
The process is repeated several times until the temperature of air drops to -200°C. The components of air becomes liquefied and the air becomes liquid.
Fractional distillation of liquefied air
Liquefied air is pumped into the bottom of a fractionating tower with its bottom warmer than its top.
Different components have different boiling points. When the temperature is higher than the boiling point of the component, the component would become gas and start vaporising up the column.

Separation of common gases:

Nitrogen is vaporized and is collected at the top as gas.
Argon is also vaporized but condenses at the centre and is collected as liquid.
Liquid oxygen flow to the bottom and is collected.

item.title: Crystallization
item.description:
Crystallization is a physical process that involves incomplete evaporation. A solution is first heated until it is saturated and let to cool down for crystals to form. Crystals obtained via this method are highly pure, they can be classified as pure substances.

Heat the solution to remove some solvent by evaporation until the solution becomes saturated.
Test whether a solution is saturated
Dip a glass rod into the solution and take it out. The solution is saturated if solid forms on the rod when it cools down.
Add solute (e.g. salts) into the solution. The solution is saturated when the solute can no longer dissolve.

Allow cooling of the hot saturated solution. Crystallization will start as some solute can no longer dissolve in the solution.
Warning The solution can either be cooled rapidly or slowly. However:
Rapid cooling provides less time to allow the crystallizing solute to form larger crystals, which leads to the formation of crumble crystals instead.
Slow cooling provides more time to allow the crystallization solution to form larger crystals.

Separate the crystals formed using filtration. The crystals are collected as residue.
Wash the crystal with small amount of cold distilled water to wash away any soluble impurities on the crystal surface. Dry the crystal with a filter paper or desiccator.
Note When crystals are dried in an oven, the high temperature causes the water inside the crystal to evaporate, leading the anhydrous salt in powdered form.

item.title: Decantation
item.description:
Decantation is a physical process used to separate a much denser insoluble solid from a liquid by gravitational force.

Problems:
This method is simple but not effective as some insoluble solid may be disturbed and may flow into another beaker.
Process:

The solution is settled down to allow time for the insoluble solid in the solution to precipitate by gravity.
Pour the solution into another beaker by the guide of a glass rod, insoluble solid is left undisturbed at the original container.

item.description:
Electrolysis of sea water would pass electricity through sea water to rearrange the constituent elements to make other useful substances.
When electricity is passed through sea water, chemical reactions are forced to occur.

Chlorine gas () is formed at the positive electrode.
Hydrogen gas () is formed at the negative electrode.
The solution in the set-up (sea water) becomes sodium hydroxide solution ().
↪️

item.title: Evaporation
item.description:
Evaporation is a physical process used to obtain powder form of soluble solids directly in a solution. It involves the evaporation of solvent by heat and leaves the solute behind.

Heat the solution to evaporate the solvent.
(Use a water bath instead of direct naked flame when needed)
The powder of dissolved salt is obtained when most of the solvent has evaporated.

item.title: Filtration
item.description:
Filtration is a physical process involving the use of filter paper and filter funnel to separate insoluble solids from a liquid. It is more efficient than decantation.
Tip Tiny holes exists on the filter paper that only allow small particles (e.g. water molecules, dissolved salts) to pass through. Sand and mud particles are too large to pass through.

The mixture is poured into a filter funnel fitted with a piece of filter paper.
The liquid that passes through is called filtrate, while the insoluble solid remaining on the filter paper is called residue.
Warning Do not add a very large amount of liquid at once, otherwise it may cause an overflow.

item.title: Simple distillation
item.description:
Simple distillation is a physical process which boils and evaporates the solvent, then condenses its vapour so that the pure solvent can be obtained.
Note Sea water mainly consists of water and dissolved salts, but the dissolved salts have much higher boiling points than water. Water will boil and vaporize upon heating while the dissolved salt will not. Thus, simple distillation is needed to obtain the solvent itself.
Procedures:

The solution is heated up slowly. The solvent (water) will vaporize and rise the distillation flask when the temperature has reached its boiling point.
The dissolved solutes (e.g. ) has a much higher boiling point than water / is non-volatile, they will not vaporize easily.
Eventually, the distillate will be collected at the end of the condenser in a conical flask / test tube.
Underlying principles:

Water boils at 100°C while the salts do not.
Water vapour condenses to liquid in the condenser.
↪️ See also: HKDSE 2013 Paper 1B Q1(b)(i)



The condenser will be connected to the distillation flash. It provides a lower temperature to condense water vapour.
Cold tap water is kept flowing in the outer layer of the condenser, while the inner layer would condense the water vapour that reaches the top of the distillation flask.
Cooling water enters at the lower end to increase the effectiveness of cooling.
The anti-bumping granules is to ensure even heating and prevents bumping of sea water.
The thermometer is to detect the boiling point of the vapour.
Tip For accurate control of heating, a water bath can be used as a heat source.



The main benefit of this set-up is its relative simplicity and cheapness, since it does not utilize any condenser.
However, the cooling effect is poorer.

item.title: Definitions
item.description:
A solute is a substance to be dissolved by the solvent.
A solvent is a substance to dissolve the solute.
A solution is formed when the solute dissolves in the solvent.
↪️ solute + solvent → solution


Substances that can dissolve in the solvent are soluble.
Substances that cannot dissolve in the solvent are insoluble.
The substances in sea water (fish, sand and water) are useful, separation of these substances is important for different purposes.

Forms of dissolved solids:

As a powder: Very small in size with no water (completely anhydrous)
e.g.
As a crystal: Have regular shapes and may contain water inside
e.g.


Decantation

A saturated solution is a solution that has dissolved all the solute it can at a given temperature. It can also be a concentrated solution, but may not necessarily be when the maximum degree of saturation at a given temperature is low (e.g. 10%).
A concentrated solution is a solution that has dissolved a relatively large percentage amount of solute. It may not necessarily be a saturated solution and could possibly dissolve more solute at the same temperature.

item.title: Conditions for effective collision
item.description:
Pre-context: [[]]
For a chemical reaction to take place, the reactant particles must collide. The collision must also be an effective collision.


The reactant particles must collide in a proper orientation.
The reactant particles possess kinetic energy equal or greater than the activation energy.

item.title: Concentration of reactant
item.description:
Generally, a higher concentration of reactants results in a higher rate of reaction.
Tip Some reactions are not affected by the concentration of reactants.
↪️ See also: Rate equation / Rate equation > Order of reaction
Consider the reaction:


Comparison of reaction rates at different times: (refer to curve A)

The reaction rate at the beginning of reaction is the highest as the initial concentration of the reactants is the highest.
The reaction rate then decrease progressively during the reaction as the concentration of reactants decreases with time.
Comparison of reaction rates at different curves:
Comparing curve A and B

The reaction rate for curve A is steeper than curve B as the concentration of of curve A is higher than curve B.
Curve A levels off earlier than that of curve B as the reaction completes earlier.
However, the same volume of hydrogen gas is produced, as is in excess, while is the limiting reagent.
Comparing curve A and C

The reaction rate for curve C is steeper than curve A as the mass of of curve C is higher than curve A.
More product is produced as is the limiting reagent.
Explaining effects of concentration from molecular level:

The number of reactant particles in a unit volume increases when the concentration is increased.
The collision frequency and hence the effective collision increases per unit time.
Note Changing only the volume of a reagent used (e.g. ) without a change in its concentration results in the same initial rate of reaction.
Same volume of reaction mixture In some instances, the total volume of the reaction mixture is kept the same between different trials, with a higher volume of the reagent and a lower volume of water in different trials.
To ensure fair comparisons between trials.
To allow the volume change to represent the concentration change of reactants.
To allow the concentration of the reagent to be directly proportional to the volume of the reagent used. See also: Determining initial rate of reaction > Example
Example: HKDSE 2016 Paper 1B Q11

With a solid reactant, a higher surface area results in a higher rate of reaction.
Compare the reaction using granules and powder:


The curve of the powdered reactant is steeper than the lumped (/ granular) reactant, as the surface area of the powdered form is higher than the lumped (/ granular) form.
The collision frequency increases and hence the effective collision increases.

See also: Maxwell-Boltzmann's distribution curve
When the temperature of the reaction increases, the rate of reaction increases.
Consider the reaction with the following curves:


The reactant particles move faster and collide with each other more frequently.
More reactant particles have energy equal or greater than the activation energy.
The collision frequency per unit time increases and hence the effective collision increases.


See also: Catalysts

Catalysts provide an alternative reaction pathway with lower activation energy required.
More reactant particles have energy equal or greater than the activation energy.
The effective collision increases.
Note The rate of reaction is independent of the amount of catalyst added.

Autocatalysis refers to a reaction which produces a product that can act as the catalyst of the original reaction.
The rate of reaction will increase rapidly in the middle period of the reaction due to the production of catalytic product.
Example: HKDSE 2017 Paper 1B Q14

item.title: Physical properties
item.description:
The methods to follow the progress of a reaction are classified by the following:

Methods based on physical properties of the reaction mixture
Method based on titrimetric analysis



Physical parameter: Volume (of gas)
Description: The production of a gaseous product increases the volume of gas. It is performed in a closed system.
Process: Volume of gas produced is measured at a regular time interval.
Requirements:

Ensure the set-up is airtight with no leakage of gas
Gas produced should not be highly soluble in water

Tip If a gas is highly soluble in water (e.g. ), the reaction mixture can be saturated with the gas before the reaction begins. As the gas is highly soluble in water, it makes sure that no gas produced from the reaction can dissolve in the solution.
Note There is a similar device used for measuring the rate of reaction, but uses the measured gas as a reactant instead.



Physical parameter: Mass (of set-up)
Description: The decrease in mass of reaction mixture is equal to the mass of gas given off. It is performed in an open system.
Process: Gas given off during a chemical reaction is allowed to escape from the reaction mixture, which causes mass to decrease.
Note
The cotton wool is used to prevent the spilling of the reaction mixture.
Release of hydrogen gas may not be followed accurately, it is too light () to be measured in an accurate way.



Physical parameter: Pressure (of closed reaction system)
Process: A closed system (airtight) is attached to a pressure sensor connected to a data-logger / computer.
Note
This method is suitable for measuring reactions involving hydrogen gas or unbalanced stochiometric ratio of gaseous reactants and products.
The reactants would firstly be separated (as setting up takes time). The vial (or similar) containing the reactants is then tilted to mix with other (solid) reactants.


Description: Useful for reactions involving a change in
Process: By using a pH meter, and measuring the change of pH value of the reaction mixture throughout the experiment at regular intervals.
Example:
Warning When both reactants and products contain acidic substances, inaccuracies can occur. It is not advised to employ this method in this situation.


Description: Useful for reactions involving the change in concentration / number of mobile ions, as electrical conductivity will change.
Process: An ammeter is used for measuring the electrical conductivity.
Example:

See also: [[]]

Physical parameter: Light absorbance (of the reaction mixture)
Description: Useful for reactions involving a coloured reactant or product.


Light absorbance is directly proportional to the colour intensity of the reaction mixture. The more intense the colour intensity of the solution, the higher concentration of coloured species in the reaction mixture.
The absorbance of a solution is measured by the colorimeter.
Example:

In reactions that consumes or produces a solid, the 'disappearing-cross' / 'cross-blocking' method can be used.

To reach the opaque / turbid stage of the reaction mixture, there must be an enough amount of solid sulphur formed to block the cross.

Physical parameter: Light transmittance / Turbidity
Calculation: (inversely proportional)
Disadvantages:

The method is not accurate as the average rate is only inversely proportional to the time, not directly equal to.
The initial rate can only be approximated as it is difficult to determine the time to reach the opaque stage.
Example:
↪️ : thiosulphate ion
Note
This method is not suitable for applying to reactions which is rapid, since it is not possible to measure the time for the precipitate to form. One example of such reaction is precipitation.
For more accurate measurements, use a light sensor to measure the light transmittance of the reaction mixture.

This method involves withdrawing and analysing small portions of known volumes at regular time intervals.
Quenching is a method used with this method. It prevents further changes in the concentration of the small portions.
Methods:

Cooling the sample in ice rapidly
Ice provides a low temperature which can slow down the reaction.
Diluting with large volume of ice-cold water
This can lower both the temperature and concentrations of reactants to decrease the rate of reaction.
Removing the catalyst
Removing the catalyst can slow down or stop any further reaction.
Advantages:

Titrimetric analysis can be applied to most reactions.
Only simple laboratory apparatus are required.
Disadvantages:

Withdrawal process of samples disturbs the reaction as the volume of the reaction mixture has changed.
Continuous measurement of concentration is impossible.
Titrimetric analysis takes time and thus cannot be used for rapid reactions.

Example: HKALE 1997 Paper 2 Q3(a)(i)

The progress of the reaction can be monitored by a titrimetric method. Outline the experimental procedure.

At regular time intervals, withdraw a known value of the reaction mixture.
Add it to excess to quench the reaction (in order to remove the catalyst).
Titrate against standard using starch as indicator.

item.title: Interpreting rate curves
item.description:
At time = 0
There are no products present. The reaction will proceed at the highest rate.
At time > 0 & time < T
Curve is steep at first, then become less steep. Product increases with time while the production of products slow down.
At time > T
No more products are produced. The curve becomes a flat line and level off.



Identification of chemical species
The reactant will decrease in amount while the product will increase in amount during the reaction.
↪️ is a reactant, while is a product.
Note In completed irreversible reactions, no limiting reagent is left.

Ratio of change of chemical species
Rate curves have to follow the stochiometric ratio of a chemical equation. In the above example, .
↪️ The change (increase) in amount of double the change (decrease) in amount of .


Comparing differences in the curves:

The curve of trial 2 is steeper / levels off earlier than the curve of trial 1.
Since the concentration of reactant of trail 2 used is higher than that in trial 1, the rate of reaction in trial 2 is higher than that in trial 1.

item.title: Average rate of reaction
item.description:
Average rate of reaction is the rate of reaction at a particular moment of time / from the beginning to the finished moment of reaction.
If not specified, the average rate of reaction usually refers to the rate of reaction at the time period from the beginning to the finished moment of reaction.
Formula: .

Instantaneous rate of reaction is the rate of reaction at a certain point of time.
To calculate the instantaneous rate of reaction, draw a tangent to the curve at that point of time. The slope of the tangent represents the instantaneous rate of reaction at that point of time.
Formula: (Slope of tangent)

Initial rate of reaction is the instantaneous rate at t = 0 (the beginning of the reaction).
To calculate the initial rate of reaction, draw a tangent to the curve passing through the origin. The slope of the tangent represents the initial rate of reaction.

item.title: Metal couple cells
item.description:
Metal couple cells are simple chemical cells consisting of two different metals, one is more reactive while one is less reactive.

An external circuit of an electrical wire connects the two electrodes.
An electrolyte is a substance that contains mobile ions to conduct electricity when in molten or aqueous states.
Oxidation occurs at the more reactive electrode, while reduction occurs at the less reactive electrode.
Consider the following chemical cell:

-ve electrode (anode / oxidation):

Species that can undergo oxidation: ,
Half equation:
Explanation: is a stronger reducing agent than .
(Higher in E.C.S. position)
+ve electrode (cathode / reduction):

Species that can undergo reduction: ,
Half equation:
Explanation: is a stronger oxidizing agent than .
(Lower in E.C.S. position)
Observations:

dissolves gradually.

Electron flow and current flow:

Electron flows from to through the external circuit.
Current flows from to through the external circuit.
Warning Electrons only flow through the external circuit. They do not flow through the electrolyte solution.


Displacement reaction occurs between strip and ions in the solution.
The electrons are directly transferred from to and they do not flow through the external circuit. This creates a waste of electrons.
Discharge of creates a build up of positive ions surrounding the anode.
This hinders the release of electrons from the strip through the external circuit.
Discharge of causes the conc. of negative ions to relatively increase.
This hinders the acceptance of electrons from external circuit to the strip.
In order to provide a more steady voltage, the following problems has to be solved:

Direct reaction between electrodes in the electrolyte
Imbalance (excess) charges in the chemical cell

The cell voltage of a chemical cell can be increased by increasing the difference in E.C.S. position between two metal electrodes.

If electrode is replaced by electrode, voltage decreases.
The differences of the metals in E.C.S. decreases.
If electrode is replaced by electrode, voltage increases.
The differences of the metals in E.C.S. increases.

When the terminals of the voltmeter is connected in the reverse of the polarity of the chemical cell, the voltmeter will show negative voltage.

item.title: Chemical cells
item.description:
Chemical cells consists of redox reactions that occur spontaneously, converting chemical energy to electrical energy.

There is no need to connect a battery into the set-up.
There will be electron flow in the external circuit of the chemical cell.
Warning
Electrons only flow through the external circuit. They do not flow through the electrolyte solution.
Current flow occurs in the reverse direction to the electron flow.
There is no attraction between electrodes and ions by charge.
The voltage produced by chemical cells are measured using voltmeter or multimeter.

Simple chemical cells:

Metal couple cells
Lemon cells
Two half-cells
Concentration cells
Daniell cell
Electrolyte redox cell using inert electrodes
Fuel cells:

Hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell
Proton exchange membrane fuel cell
Direct methanol fuel cell
Note
Fuel cells are primary cells.
They are not secondary cells as they cannot be recharged.




Chemical cells in daily life

item.title: Electroplating
item.description:
Pre-context: Protection of metals > Electroplating
Electroplating is an electrolytic process to plate metal onto an object in order to give the object an attractive appearance.

Details:

The electrolyte must contain the salt of the plating metal.
The object to be plated must be a cathode, as the metallic ion has to undergo reduction to be plated.
The anode can be graphite or other inert electrodes, and must not be a metal.

item.title: Electrolysis
item.description:
Electrolysis is a chemical process in which electricity is supplied in order to force the redox reaction to occur, converting electrical energy to chemical energy.

The cell undergoing electrolysis is called electrolytic cells.
Attraction of ions between electrodes Since electricity is supplied intentionally, charges are created in the electrolytic cell. In the electrolyte, cations will be attracted towards the negative electrode, while anions will be attracted towards the positive electrode. However, this is not the case in chemical cells, as it involves the creation of charges by supply electricity to force reactions to occur.
Basics of electrolysis:

The electrolytic cell must be connected to an electricity supply (e.g. chemical cell, battery or D.C. supply), with the positive terminal connected to the positive electrode, and vice versa.
When the electrolysis process involves aqueous solutions, consider the self-ionization of water:
Types of electrolytes Aqueous electrolytes contain water, so the self-ionization of water is considered. However, water will not be present in molten electrolytes. The mobile ions in the molten electrolyte will be in liquid state.

Consider the electrolysis of molten lead(II) bromide using graphite electrodes:

Solid lead(II) bromide is heated in the crucible until it turns molten.

Ions present: ,

At anode:

Reactive electrodes: (e.g. )

These electrodes may participate in the reaction, so they should be considered when determining the electrolysis process.
Inert electrodes: (e.g. platinum, graphite)

These electrodes do not participate in the reaction.
Usage of platinum
Platinum electrodes are readily attacked by halogens and halide ions, they must not be used for such reactions.

In a dilute or concentrated solution, the anions have concentration higher than hydroxide ions, so the anions are preferentially discharged.

Lithium, potassium, calcium and sodium cannot be used as an electrode, as they would react with water readily.

item.title: Determining oxidations and reductions
item.description:
Gain or loss of electrons


Loss of electrons → Reducing agent

Gain of electrons → Oxidizing agent
Gain or loss of oxygen atoms

Carbon gains oxygen atoms, so it is oxidized.
Oxygen is reduced.
Gain or loss of hydrogen atoms

Oxygen gains hydrogen atoms, so it is reduced.
Hydrogen is oxidized.
Increase or decrease of oxidation number (O.N.)
Free elements have O.N. = 0.
O.N. of simple monoatomic ions is equal to its charge.
Group I and II metal ions have O.N. = 1 and O.N. = 2 respectively.
O.N. of hydrogen is +1, except for hydride ions which has O.N. = -1
O.N. of halide ions is usually -1.
O.N. of oxygen is -2, except for hydrogen peroxide () which has O.N. = -1.
Sum of O.N. = 0 for neutral compounds.
Some elements have variable O.N. (e.g. C, N, S and transition metals)

Answer pattern: The O.N. of {atom} is (increased / decreased) from __ in {species A} to __ in {species B}.

A reaction must be a redox reaction when there is a change in O.N. of any chemical species.
Some types of reactions are not redox reactions:

Neutralization
Precipitation
